headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, February 4, 2015. I would now like
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, February 4, 2015. I would now like to turn the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Ms. Valerie Finberg. Please go ahead.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
I'd like to draw your attention to the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com. On this site are the presentation materials that accompany this call, the earnings press release and supplemental financial information. As the acquisition of tw telecom closed on October 31, 2014, consolidated financial statements for the fourth quarter 2014 include a full quarter of Level 3 results in 2 months of tw telecom results. Information provided for both Level 3 and tw telecom on stand-alone basis exclude acquisition-related expenses, intercompany eliminations and acquisition accounting adjustment. Standalone tw telecom results are based on tw telecom's definitions for all metrics provided. 
Growth rates in our -- Growth rates disclosed in our presentation and remarks are on a year-over-year basis. Revenue comparisons to prior periods are provided on a constant currency basis, unless otherwise noted. 
I need to call your attention to our Safe Harbor statement that begins on Page 2 of our 4Q '14 earnings presentation. The presentation and remarks contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may vary significantly from those statements. A discussion of factors that may affect future results can be found in Level 3's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As you can see on Slide 3, 2014 was a solid year for Level 3. I'm pleased with our execution throughout the year and the strong finish from both teams, the standalone Level 3 and tw
componenttext:
Thank you, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As you can see on Slide 3, 2014 was a solid year for Level 3. I'm pleased with our execution throughout the year and the strong finish from both teams, the standalone Level 3 and tw telecom. 
At the beginning of 2014, we highlighted our focus on profitable revenue growth, improving adjusted EBITDA and generating free cash flow. We made significant progress with respect to those financial metrics. 
I'm also very pleased with the completion of the tw telecom acquisition late last fall. Since the close of the acquisition at the end of October, we've made steady progress against our integration plan. The acquisition is an important step in solidifying our place in the industry as we tied together one of the world's most sophisticated and extensive international networks with one of our nation's premier domestic networks. We are very focused on profitably integrating the organization, products, networks and support systems, and believe these efforts will position us well for 2016 and beyond. 
Integrating quickly and according to our plan is our highest operational priority for the year and we will not lose focus on those efforts. 
Per our usual process, soon it will provide an overview of our fourth quarter and full year 2014 results, and I will provide additional detail on the integration process and what we're targeting for 2015. After that, we will open the call up to your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Sunit.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. 2014 with a pivotal year for Level 3, setting us up on the back to sustainable and growing free cash flow. We performed well compared to our full year outlook for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. 2014 with a pivotal year for Level 3, setting us up on the back to sustainable and growing free cash flow. We performed well compared to our full year outlook for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow growth. Our focus right now is integrating tw telecom. In addition, we are investing for profitable growth in 2015 and beyond. 
Before I dive into the details, I'd like to start on Slide 4 and highlight Level 3's performance on a stand-alone basis for the year. Our Core Network Services revenue for the full year 2014 grew 6.1% year-over-year on a constant currency basis compared to 2.9% growth for the full year 2013. Our adjusted EBITDA grew 19% for the full year 2014 compared to our outlook of 14% to 18% growth. We generated free cash flow of $325 million for the full year 2014 compared to our full year outlook of $250 million to $300 million. Including all acquisition-related expenses, our free cash flow was $261 million for the full year. Additionally, we continue to lower our net debt to adjusted EBITDA leverage ratio, which is now at 4.4x on a pro forma basis to include tw telecom and excluding acquisition-related expenses. 
Turning to Slide 5. On a constant currency basis, CNS revenue grew 5.1% to $1.497 billion in the fourth quarter. On an as-reported basis, CNS revenue grew 3.7% due to the strength in the dollar. On a regional basis, North America continued to show good growth as CNS revenue grew 6.3% and enterprise CNS revenue grew 11%. In EMEA, for the fourth quarter, CNS revenue grew 0.5% on a constant currency basis and declined 2.2% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue grew 9% on a constant currency basis or 6.7% on a reported basis. 
In 2015, as we remain focused on profitability and as contracts come to an end with the U.K. government, we expect steeper declines in U.K. government revenue. As of the fourth quarter 2014, revenue for the U.K. government represented approximately 13% of EMEA CNS revenue. For reference, you can find fourth quarter and full year revenue for the U.K. government footnoted in the revenue table on Page 2 of our press release. We plan to disclose U.K. government revenue for every quarter in 2015. 
In Latin America, for the fourth quarter, CNS revenue grew 4.1% on a constant currency basis and declined 2.1% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise revenue grew 3.2% on a constant currency basis and declined 2.6% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise growth in the region was a bit weaker this quarter compared to earlier in the year because of a few large disconnects in datacenter services during the quarter. For the fourth quarter, most of CNS revenue grew 7.6% on a constant currency basis or 2.2% on an as-reported basis. 
Both our voice service and other or WVS revenue declined to $137 million in the fourth quarter 2014. For the full year 2014, WVS revenue declined 19% to $582 [ph] million.
Turning to Slide 6. For the fourth quarter 2014, CNS revenue churn was approximately 1.4%. 
Moving ahead to Slide 8. Fourth quarter 2014 adjusted EBITDA was $470 million. This compares to adjusted EBITDA of $448 million in the fourth quarter of 2013, which included a $10 million Latin America tax benefit. For the full year 2014, adjusted EBITDA grew 19% to $1.869 billion from $1.565 billion in 2013. Adjusted EBITDA margin improved to 28.8% in the fourth quarter 2014 compared to 28% for the fourth quarter of 2013.  Over the course of the full year 2014, we made great progress in expanding adjusted EBITDA margins from 24.8% in 2013 to 28.8% for the full year 2014. The improvement in full year margin was driven by growth in both high-margin CNS revenue and adjusted EBITDA and the benefit of the cost reduction actions taken in the third quarter of 2013. 
On Slide 9. In 2014, capital expenditures were $847 million, representing 13% of total revenue. This was in line with our full year expectation of 12% to 13% of total revenue and included some integration CapEx. As of December 31, 2014, the company had cash and cash equivalents of $580 million. 
Focusing on tw telecom results on a stand-alone basis. As you can see on Slides 10 and 11, tw telecom delivered another quarter of solid growth. Sequential improvement in EBITDA was primarily driven by synergies, including executive management headcount reductions, reduced cost from moving tw telecom traffic onto the Level 3 network and generally -- and general salary and benefit savings as all new hires being added to the Level 3 payroll. 
I'd like to note that going forward, we will no longer be providing separate disclosure for tw telecom results. 
Moving to Slide 12. On a pro forma combined basis, total revenue was $2.052 billion for the fourth quarter 2014 and $8.123 billion for the full year 2014. CNS revenue was $1.915 billion in the fourth quarter 2014, growing 5.8%, compared to the fourth quarter of 2013 on a constant currency basis. On an as-reported basis in the fourth quarter, CNS revenue grew 4.8%. Also, voice and other was $137 million for the fourth quarter with a very small contribution for tw telecom and represents 7% of total revenue. We expect continued double-digit rates of decline in WVS revenue in 2015. On a geographic basis for the fourth quarter, about 79% of our CNS revenues from North America, 11% from EMEA and 10% from Latin America. As a combined company, we have approximately 52,000 customers, of which 94% are in the enterprise segment and the remaining 6 are in the wholesale segment. From a revenue perspective, enterprise is 71% of our CNS revenue and wholesale is 29%. 
Turning to revenue results by product group on Slide 13. On a pro forma combined basis for the fourth quarter and all on an as-reported basis, we saw continued strength in our IP and data services group which grew 8.9% and represented 46% of CNS revenue.  Within that group, CDN revenues grew 7.6% and represent about 2% of CNS revenue. Transport and fiber grew 4.5% and represent 30% of CNS revenue. Within transport and fiber, dark fiber grew 1.7% and represents about 5% of CNS revenue. Dark fiber growth was slower this quarter compared to last quarter because of order period back bills collected in the fourth quarter of 2013. Normalizing for those back bills, dark fiber grew 6.4% and transport and fiber grew 5.2%. Voice services was flat year-over-year, representing 16% of CNS revenue. And colocation and data services, which make up 8% of CNS revenue, declined 5.5% driven by some larger -- large customer disconnects in LatAm and EMEA along with negative currency effects. 
Regarding pricing. As we've said for several quarters, we've seen little change in the pricing environment. We remain disciplined on pricing for Internet services as we manage for profitability and transitioned those services from wholesale to enterprise customers. 
Turning to Slide 14. Adjusted EBITDA, including acquisition-related expenses, was $469 million for the fourth quarter 2014 and $2.271 billion for the full year 2014. Excluding acquisition-related expenses, adjusted EBITDA was $625 million for the fourth quarter of 2014 and $2.443 billion for the full year 2014. Adjusted EBITDA margin, excluding acquisition-related expenses, was 30.5% for the fourth quarter 2014 and 30.1% for the full year 2014. 
Turning to Slide 15. For the fourth quarter 2014, the combined company spent $100 million on transaction-related expenses and $56 million on integration-related expenses. For the full year, the company spent $112 million on transaction-related expenses and $60 million on integration-related expenses. For 2015, we expect to spend roughly $50 million on EBITDA-affecting integration expenses with some remaining costs in 2016. From a CapEx perspective, we expect about $70 million of integration CapEx this year in 2015 as we invest for common Network Systems and product platforms globally. 
Moving to synergies. During the fourth quarter 2014, we achieved approximately $38 million of our targeted 200 million of run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies, with Network Access cost synergies of $1 million and operating expense synergies of $37 million. Going forward, I'll provide an update on both EBITDA-affecting integration expenses and annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies each quarter. 
Turning to Slide 16. As noted in our earnings release, we completed several Capital Markets transactions over the past few months and will continue to be opportunistic in managing our balance sheet. Related to those transactions, we expect to incur a $40 million charge for the extinguishment of debt in the second quarter of this year.  On a combined company basis, we exited the year with our net debt to adjusted EBITDA of 4.4x on a pro forma basis and excluding acquisition-related expenses. This compares to 4.8x at the end of 2013 on a stand-alone basis for Level 3. We remain focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 5x driven by growth in adjusted EBITDA. We ended the quarter with approximately 341 million shares outstanding. On a fully diluted basis, including the remaining 12 million shares associated with the converts that mature in March, our shares outstanding are approximately $358 million. The company's U.S. net operating loss carryforward or NOL balance was approximately $10.3 billion as of the end of 2014. 
Turning to Slide 17. I'd like to now focus on our business outlook, which is outlined in this slide and in this morning's press release. While we are not providing overall CNS revenue guidance, I did want to cover what we expect from a regional perspective on a constant currency basis. Our LatAm CNS revenues grew 8.5% in 2014 compared to full year 2013. We expect comparable performance in 2015. EMEA declined 2.2% in 2014. We expect a smaller percentage decline in 2015, driven by better performance in enterprise and wholesale, offset by a more rapid decline in U.K. government revenue. For reference, U.K. government revenue declined 17% in 2014. In North America, our CNS revenue growth will be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw for the pro forma combined company performance in the fourth quarter. This was because we had the benefit of incremental growth in 2014, including turning up the Starbucks contract revenue and some large federal contracts that we don't expect this year. With our focus on profitable revenue growth and synergy savings, we expect strong growth in adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow in 2015. Specifically, from the adjusted EBITDA starting point of $2.271 billion from 2014, we expect to grow adjusted EBITDA 12% to 16% for the full year 2015. In addition, we expect to generate free cash flow of $550 million to $600 million for the full year 2015.  In 2014, Level 3 spent 13% of revenue and CapEx, and tw telecom spent approximately 25%. On a blended basis, that's approximately 15.5%. In 2015, we expect to spend about 15% of total revenue on CapEx, which includes $40 million in capital expenditures synergies and integration-related CapEx of about $70 million. 
For the first quarter 2015, we expect CNS revenue to be up slightly on an as-reported basis relative to the pro forma combined company fourth quarter 2014 figure of $1.915 billion. Due to continued underlying growth in CNS revenue offsetting the typical soft sequential comparison from fourth to first quarter revenue. We expect first quarter 2015 adjusted EBITDA to be up slightly compared to the fourth quarter 2014 pro forma adjusted EBITDA of $625 million. Free cash flow in the first quarter will be slightly negative due to the payment of annual bonuses in cash for the combined company and higher net cash interest expense of $169 million in the first quarter. As a reminder, last year and in previous years for Level 3 standalone, we only paid 40% of annual bonuses in cash and the remainder in shares of common stock. 
In summary, 2014 was a good year for the company. In 2015, in addition to free cash flow growth, we're focused on integration, synergies and driving pocketable revenue growth. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sunit. As I noted earlier, 2014 was a good year for Level 3. As we look to 2015, we're confident in our ability to meet the revenues, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow outlook that Sunit described. To achieve our adjusted EBITDA and free cash
componenttext:
Thank you, Sunit. As I noted earlier, 2014 was a good year for Level 3. As we look to 2015, we're confident in our ability to meet the revenues, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow outlook that Sunit described. To achieve our adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow outlook and continue driving profitable revenue growth, I'd like to emphasize 3 key priorities: First and foremost is the successful integration of Level 3 and tw telecom. Second is enabling EMEA to live up to its full potential and support the growth we believe we can achieve in that region. Third is to position Level 3 for growth well into the future. 
While we have been, and will continue to be, an inquisitive company, right now, our #1 priority is integrating tw telecom. There are many definitions we could apply to when integration is complete but by my standard, it's a multiyear process and will not be completed in 2015. In broad terms, my definition of completely integrated includes a single set of products for our customers around the globe, a unified sales team capable of selling those products effectively in our target market and our target customer verticals, a network optimized to drive high margin products to high-margin locations, an integrated operational support platform that enables our employees to deliver the best customer experience in the industry and a global workforce acting seamlessly across international borders and diverse languages to meet the global needs of all of our customers.  We've begun initiatives across each of these areas. 
As an example, this week, we completed the go-forward sale structure for the North America sales team combining the best general managers from both companies and aligning these GMs and their teams around the opportunities our global capabilities create. Effective this month, all of our salespeople across the combined company have their go forward assigned customer account. In addition, as announced last year, we have formalized our global account management structure. This organization reporting to Andrew Crouch, is charged with providing a seamless customer experience to our largest multinational customers who buy services across the globe. From a product, network and systems planning perspective, the key to our approach is the word one. One product set, one network, one set of support systems. With several past acquisitions, we've made the decision to keep multiple instances of certain systems, products and even in some cases, duplicate networks. While this approach has several benefits, it created ongoing complexity in the sales, service delivery and service assurance environment. Due to the limited number of acquisitions by tw telecom, their systems environment was much more straightforward compared to Level 3's, especially for the quote-to-service delivery process. We will be scaling those capabilities and working to move the company to a single platform over time. 
In terms of the network, we have interconnected the tw telecom and Level 3 networks and are now beginning efforts to fully integrate them as a single unified network. We're also confident in our ability to deliver the synergy savings we've discussed in previous calls. 
Turning to EMEA. You've heard me say we need to do more to live up to our full potential in that region. I believe we now have the right leader in Andrew Crouch to implement the changes needed and provide the leadership to improve our performance. As many of you know, Andrew was a principal driver of our success in North America. Since taking the helm in November in EMEA, Andrew has moved quickly to make leadership changes and is focusing the team on improving sales, delivering profitable growth and returning the region to the success we've had in the past. 
Before I move on to what we're doing and where we're investing to position the company for the future, I wanted to take a moment to discuss performance and expectations in Latin America. We've had a long history of success and have confidence in the highly capable LatAm team led by Hector Alonzo. For several years in a row, we've seen LatAm delivered double-digit revenue growth. In 2014 and specifically, in the fourth quarter, growth was not a strong, in part due to the economic environment in the region. However, the underlying factors that drive growth in our business have not changed in Latin America. And with finance continue to grow at an extraordinary rate, the need for this capacity and connectivity is global in nature not solely within the region, and as a result, our subsidy systems give us a unique product set not easily matched by our competitors, and we have an outstanding team focused on the opportunities within the region and within each country we serve. 
Turning to future growth. We believe all of the work we're doing around integration is also critical for positioning the company to capitalize on future growth opportunities. One set of services over a combined network with a standard operating environment globally allows us to meet the ever-changing needs of our customers. Whether interconnecting the customers branch locations throughout the world over an Ethernet-based IP VPN, or connecting a corporate data center to cloud service providers via Level 3's cloud connect solutions or using Level 3's advanced DDOS mitigation services to protect the company from Internet attacks, Level 3 is well-positioned to meet the complex networking needs of our customers. We remain focused on meeting the wireline communication needs of our enterprise customers, and I'm confident that as we execute against our integration plans this year, we'll continue to position the company to take market share and further transform the business on an ongoing basis. With that, we will open it up for your questions. Operator, would you explain the process?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jeffries.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jeffries.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just, Sunit, following up on your commentary on the revenue side of the equation. I guess, a couple part question if I could. On your geographic outlook, I wonder if you could just talk a little bit about -- a little bit of more detail about the
componenttext: I guess, just, Sunit, following up on your commentary on the revenue side of the equation. I guess, a couple part question if I could. On your geographic outlook, I wonder if you could just talk a little bit about -- a little bit of more detail about the European strength that you are seeing in the enterprise side of the equation and I thought we were sort of behind some of the U.K. government stuff but it seems like that's coming back in. Also on the LatAm side of the equation, maybe just talk about what you saw on the datacenter disconnection and where those were going in your comfort around the 2015 guide. And then just for a bit of housekeeping, if you could just share with us what you're -- what impact of FX could be on a reported revenue and more importantly on EBITDA for 2015.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll start first with the question on EMEA. I think that prior to last year, our enterprise revenue growth in EMEA, excluding U.K. government, had been close to double-digit growth. It was a little softer last year and we see that picking up. We
componenttext: Sure. So I'll start first with the question on EMEA. I think that prior to last year, our enterprise revenue growth in EMEA, excluding U.K. government, had been close to double-digit growth. It was a little softer last year and we see that picking up. We also had a fairly steep decline in the wholesale business in EMEA last year. We think that is stabilizing in the sense of we won't see that kind of decline in the wholesale segment. So therefore, we expect better performance in enterprise and wholesale. I think the U.K. government revenue, we were hoping at this point, to win new government contracts in the U.K. government. What has actually happened, I think as you probably know from last year, with some of the cellphone tapping events in Europe, what we've seen as a business there is going to U.K. carriers, meaning principally, BT and Vodafone. So last year was a relatively stable for us with respect to U.K. government. Meaning, you saw the year-over-year decline but a lot of that happened in 2013. Over the course of 2014, U.K. government and EMEA are fairly stable. So what we are now seeing in '15 and '16 is those contracts going away, and so that's what's hurting us. So we will see the decline in the U.K. government revenue accelerate a little in 2015, which is why we are going to provide separate disclosure for that. But when you put it all together, the fact that it is a small percent of the CNS revenue in EMEA and with better performance on wholesale and in enterprise, we expect EMEA revenues to decline a little on a constant currency basis but not as much as a 2.2% decline we saw last year. In Latin America, I think that the datacenter business there is lumpier in the sense that we had some big customers there. We had some disconnect, as I said, some in EMEA, but bigger ones in LatAm. So we saw the impact of that in the quarter. We certainly feel our datacenter business and our assets in Latin America premier assets and they should be able to grow that back up again. And as we look at LatAm in general, in spite of the macroeconomic issues that we talked about, other than Venezuela, which I'll quickly touch upon, we expect comparable constant currency growth in LatAm. There continues to be a lot of opportunities, one particularly strong segment in that, as Jeff mentioned, was the sale -- the demand for subsea capacity to Latin America which has been a bright spot. Venezuela, just to touch up on that, I think that, in general, most companies are using the SICAD 2 rate, which is -- SICAD 1 rate, I'm sorry, which is VEF 12.1 to the dollar. The official rate is about 6. We've been -- we switched to that SICAD 1 rate sometime ago. Over the course of this year as we expect some more news out of the Venezuelan government which should reconcile SICAD 1 rate, which is at VEF 12 vs the SICAD 2 rate, which is at VEF 50.  So sometime later in the year, we'll have to address that as the government moves in that direction. But away from that, generally, we expect similar growth in LatAm that we saw last year. And then I think your question on currency and in EBITDA. Look, I think the bad news is the dollar a lot of business outside the U.S.. The good news is, less than -- about 20% of our CNS revenues are outside the U.S. A lot of strength in the dollar has already happened, so we certainly factored that into our outlook for EBITDA. So we feel very confident about the EBITDA outlook that we have provided given current exchange rates. Obviously, if the dollar strengthens some more, that could impact us on margin. But on the EBITDA level, we are more or better hedged, I would say, or have less exposure than the revenue side. As we've explained in the past, our biggest exposure from an EBITDA perspective is the Brazilian real and the euro. Not as much the sterling. We are profitable in U.K, but we also our regional headquarters. So we have a fair amount of sterling expense in the U.K.. And at this point, I think, we factored in -- we're assuming currency rates that are in effect right now for our outlook. So we feel quite confident about EBITDA.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: 2 questions if I may. The first one. You talked about going back to previous acquisitions and effectively fully integrating them or moving more towards the full integration. Where would that be reflected in the potential for synergies? So you've obviously
componenttext: 2 questions if I may. The first one. You talked about going back to previous acquisitions and effectively fully integrating them or moving more towards the full integration. Where would that be reflected in the potential for synergies? So you've obviously already outlined synergies that you anticipate from tw telecom specifically. That's within your traditional 10% to 20% of OpEx of the company acquiring. How should we think about the additional savings you're going to get from -- going back to some of these previous acquisitions? And then the second question, what if any refi have you assumed in your interest expense guidance? And I guess, it takes that you haven't any -- what might -- I guess, could we be potentially being considered?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question first. So on the refi, no, we've not assumed any further refinancing. Obviously, there are opportunities for us to do that later in the year. I think my summary is when we do them, it depends on interest rates at the time and
componenttext: I'll take the second question first. So on the refi, no, we've not assumed any further refinancing. Obviously, there are opportunities for us to do that later in the year. I think my summary is when we do them, it depends on interest rates at the time and timing. I don't see it impacting -- it certainly impacts our run rate interest expense on a go-forward basis, might have not as much impact within the year. So I think there are opportunities for us, we have about $1.5 billion of callable debt with coupons in the 8 [ph] so  that's certainly an opportunity for us later in the year. They're not callable currently, so I think these are more second half of the year type opportunities depending on where interest rates are at that time.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Colby, with respect to the integrations of previous acquisitions, we are looking at our business going forward and what we're trying to build for Level 3, with 1 network, 1 product, 1 systems that I talked about. And so I wouldn't put any additional savin
componenttext: Colby, with respect to the integrations of previous acquisitions, we are looking at our business going forward and what we're trying to build for Level 3, with 1 network, 1 product, 1 systems that I talked about. And so I wouldn't put any additional savings from previous integrations. But what I would say is that we are trying to integrate the operational support systems. So it's easier for our employees to do their job and satisfy our customers better. We're trying to make sure that we continue to evolve our network. If you look at our Ethernet product, we have different platforms around the globe in which we deliver the Ethernet service. We are moving to a single platform and we'll be able to deliver a unit -- a uniform product across the globe wherever the customers are located. And also, a uniform system for employees to use and deliver that product. And so that's what we're talking about, is really creating that one set of products, that one unified network and one set of operational support systems.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess just a follow-up then to that, Jeff. I mean, I listened to John Blount at the recent Metro Connect Conference, and part of what you said, you guys are doing that for is to make it easier to make additional acquisitions thereafter integrating t
componenttext: And I guess just a follow-up then to that, Jeff. I mean, I listened to John Blount at the recent Metro Connect Conference, and part of what you said, you guys are doing that for is to make it easier to make additional acquisitions thereafter integrating tw telecom. How quickly do you think you could be ready to be doing that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, and one I'm really not ready to answer. Right now, we're focused on tw telecom, and we'll always be opportunistic in looking for things going forward. But we're going to integrate tw telecom and Level 3 build that environment that
componenttext: That's a good question, and one I'm really not ready to answer. Right now, we're focused on tw telecom, and we'll always be opportunistic in looking for things going forward. But we're going to integrate tw telecom and Level 3 build that environment that I talked about. And then once completed, I think that we will be in a good position to layer on acquisitions in a more straightforward and streamlined fashion. But for today, we are focused on integrating tw telecom and delivering on the growth opportunities that we see out of that acquisition.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Frank Louthan with Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Frank Louthan with Raymond James.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up, could you -- it appears that your guidance does include your FX outlook. Can you quantify that the totals or the currency headwinds for '15? And then on the further integration with the sales in the IT systems, give us a little bit more
componenttext: Just a follow-up, could you -- it appears that your guidance does include your FX outlook. Can you quantify that the totals or the currency headwinds for '15? And then on the further integration with the sales in the IT systems, give us a little bit more color on exactly the types of systems that you're still looking to change over and sort of the time frame and what kind of cost savings will that represent when those are all switched over to the same platform?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on your first question. As we looked at -- as I said, we have assumed the current outlook on currencies with respect to EBITDA. From a revenue perspective, all my comments were driven by a constant currency basis, meaning assuming what the growth will
componenttext: So on your first question. As we looked at -- as I said, we have assumed the current outlook on currencies with respect to EBITDA. From a revenue perspective, all my comments were driven by a constant currency basis, meaning assuming what the growth will be on a constant currency basis. So as I said, I think unless the dollar continues to strengthen quite a bit more, we can talk about it. But even if it does strengthen a little from here, it doesn't have as much impact to the EBITDA line as it does from a revenue -- as reported revenue basis. So I think we've factored that in.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: From a sales and systems integration perspective. If you look at our sales efforts, we have -- we've gone through and aligned across the U.S. in John Blount's organization all of the GMs. We've taken about 60 of the GMs taking the best from both companies
componenttext: From a sales and systems integration perspective. If you look at our sales efforts, we have -- we've gone through and aligned across the U.S. in John Blount's organization all of the GMs. We've taken about 60 of the GMs taking the best from both companies, we've aligned their teams around the global opportunities that we have. Not only the local market opportunities, but the global capabilities to bring those to the local markets. We've gone through and changed our channel structures somewhat, moving some things inside sales, some things to the GAM, global account management team. And so, we've aligned that structure and we've gone through and made it clear to every single sales employee what accounts they have. We have a lot of change going on. All of that is a lot in addition, we're going to synchronize compensation plans and other things throughout the next few quarters. So there's a lot of opportunity in the integration of our sales team and making sure that we're in a position to sell our global capabilities in North America and in EMEA and in Latin America. With respect to systems. As you might imagine, Frank, we have a fairly robust and complicated roadmap for our various systems. Some things -- our ERP, we are standardizing ERP should be finished by the end of the year where we are globally operating on a single platform moving that towards the Level 3 systems that we've used. On the customer relationship management, we have a single platform we're moving to. That should be in a relatively short time frame so that our sales team can use a common platform and that we can interface with that through the rest of our systems. Now if you look at our platforms, I mentioned the Ethernet platform. But we are very actively and aggressively looking at our Ethernet platform, our IP VPN platform, our Internet services platforms and making sure that we synchronize those and build the product sets and then the network to deliver those fairly quickly. So there are a number of different initiatives that we have underway across all of those things and hopefully, that gives you a feel for it.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Kevin Smithen with Macquarie Capital.

componenttext: Just a quick housekeeping question first, if I may. The $550 million to $600 million of free cash flow, I want to -- does that include acquisition costs? Is that comparable to the $325 million or the $261 million for 2014?

componenttextpreview: So that includes everything. And that's comparable to the $261 million. And so yes, there's no exclusions in that. It's net-net bottom line number.
componenttext: So that includes everything. And that's comparable to the $261 million. And so yes, there's no exclusions in that. It's net-net bottom line number.

componenttext: No, that's looking everything. The reference point I was using was a pro forma combined company CNS revenue, which is in the press release, and the growth rate that I was talking about refer to the combined company for the fourth quarter.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Can you give us a little granularity on individual product strength in U.S. CNS, Ethernet, and POS, fiber to the cell, CBN, sonic wavelength? Any sort of color by product and on where you're seeing strength and where the risks are?
componenttext: All right. Can you give us a little granularity on individual product strength in U.S. CNS, Ethernet, and POS, fiber to the cell, CBN, sonic wavelength? Any sort of color by product and on where you're seeing strength and where the risks are?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the best place to look at that is combined company pro forma mix by product that we have. And I think the point there is that the product that is the largest on Page 13 or Slide 13. The -- our largest products are the fastest-growing ones. So
componenttext: Yes, I think the best place to look at that is combined company pro forma mix by product that we have. And I think the point there is that the product that is the largest on Page 13 or Slide 13. The -- our largest products are the fastest-growing ones. So if you look at 46% of the revenue in the fourth quarter, CNS revenues, IP and data services, that is the fastest-growing products. We expect that to continue to be the case. Voice services, I don't see much growth there. I mean, it's, I mean, somewhat stable. I think colocation and datacenter revenues, while they got hit by -- this last quarter, we generally expect them to perform better over time. And then transport and fiber, which is 30% of revenue basis, we see the growth there. So I think that within that I would say we generally think CDN should do better over time than the growth rate that we just reported. Fiber should continue to do well. And then as far as Fiber to the Tower, that's not a big business for us. It will grow in time. But again, that's not a --  Fiber to the Tower is not a product for us, it's within the fiber segment.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your capital spending outlook for 2015. Wondering if you could break it down maybe into some components of what you're spending on and how we should think about what would be a maintenance or ongoi
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your capital spending outlook for 2015. Wondering if you could break it down maybe into some components of what you're spending on and how we should think about what would be a maintenance or ongoing CapEx number relative to what you're spending on the growth initiatives.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I mean, if you look at the 15% of revenue guidance, it's more than $1.2 billion of CapEx roughly given an $8 billion [ph] revenue base. So about $300 million to $350 million dollars is maintenance I would say. We already said this year we'll spen
componenttext: Sure. So I mean, if you look at the 15% of revenue guidance, it's more than $1.2 billion of CapEx roughly given an $8 billion [ph] revenue base. So about $300 million to $350 million dollars is maintenance I would say. We already said this year we'll spend on top of that $70 million for integration CapEx. The rest of the CapEx is really success-based capital to drive revenue growth.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And for the growth initiatives, what's your biggest focus for the year? Is it connecting to new buildings? Is it building new routes? Maybe just a little bit more granularity on how to think about the...
componenttext: And for the growth initiatives, what's your biggest focus for the year? Is it connecting to new buildings? Is it building new routes? Maybe just a little bit more granularity on how to think about the...

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, so I think we -- our objective is to maintain or improve the number of building ads we've had. If you look at both the companies, Level 3 was adding about 500 [ph] or so -- or so buildings a year. TW was adding about 2,000. So we expect to main
componenttext: Sure. Yes, so I think we -- our objective is to maintain or improve the number of building ads we've had. If you look at both the companies, Level 3 was adding about 500 [ph] or so -- or so buildings a year. TW was adding about 2,000. So we expect to maintain or grow the amount of building ads generally. We will upgrade capacity. We'll need more capacity for subsea routes, trash rail routes. We are upgrading our infrastructure in many cases back 1 infrastructure from 10 gig to 100 gig. So we'll have -- money is going in towards there. We -- we're going to keep expanding our network in the Metropolitan area. So meaning our fiber network in the Metropolitan areas across all regions. We have money being spent for that. And there'll be some money for geographic expansion. So generally, as I've talked about and as Jeff talked about, we'll continue to invest for growth not just for 2015 but for future years. So it's across all fronts. And Jeff, I donâ€™t know if you want to add anything.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. And the main point there is we are continuing to invest our capital. We think there are great growth opportunities for us. If you look at the 5 new markets that we added last year on a combined company basis and the 28 markets th
componenttext: No, I think that's right. And the main point there is we are continuing to invest our capital. We think there are great growth opportunities for us. If you look at the 5 new markets that we added last year on a combined company basis and the 28 markets that we've been expanding, we think there are places and opportunities for us to invest capital. If you look at Latin America, we're build a landing station. In Colombia, we're continuing to investing in EMEA.  We want to continue to build closer and closer to our customers and add them on that because we could provide a differentiated experience and a very profitable opportunities for us.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, about 40,000 buildings on that. And we're adding about 2,500 [ph] hopefully, closer to 3,000 per year. So it's a pretty aggressive expansion.
componenttext: Yes, about 40,000 buildings on that. And we're adding about 2,500 [ph] hopefully, closer to 3,000 per year. So it's a pretty aggressive expansion.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just finally, is there a free cash flow level or a net debt leverage level? At which point when you hit it, that it would increase your interest to return capital to shareholders whether it's buybacks or dividends. Have you given thoughts on what thos
componenttext: And just finally, is there a free cash flow level or a net debt leverage level? At which point when you hit it, that it would increase your interest to return capital to shareholders whether it's buybacks or dividends. Have you given thoughts on what those levels might be that would give you some considerations on that front?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as we've talked about in the past, we continue to think about that. I think we made a couple of comments that once we hit our target leverage, which is at the low end of 3 [ph] to 5 [ph] and we generate lots of free cash flow, that is somethi
componenttext: Yes. I think as we've talked about in the past, we continue to think about that. I think we made a couple of comments that once we hit our target leverage, which is at the low end of 3 [ph] to 5 [ph] and we generate lots of free cash flow, that is something that we're going to think more actively about. So I think the right answer would be when we get to that low end of the 3 to 5 range on-net debt-to-EBITDA.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we've said that we are very focused on free cash flow per share growth. And we will continue to have that focus as a company.
componenttext: And we've said that we are very focused on free cash flow per share growth. And we will continue to have that focus as a company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And what has the sales force churn been since the integration? Can you give us some color whether it's an increase or stayed the same?
componenttext: Okay, great. And what has the sales force churn been since the integration? Can you give us some color whether it's an increase or stayed the same?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's a very good question. The -- since the closing, we've not seen an increase in churn, and it's been about what it was before. And if you look at our top performers, it's actually lower than it was before. And so our -- we've got a lot of chang
componenttext: Yes, so it's a very good question. The -- since the closing, we've not seen an increase in churn, and it's been about what it was before. And if you look at our top performers, it's actually lower than it was before. And so our -- we've got a lot of change going on and we're going to do a lot of things in the sales organization this year. But I think that our sales team sees the same thing that we see, which are great opportunities with the products and services we sell to take them to their customers and grow with our company. And so we have not seen an increase in churn and are very focused on that and very pleased in John Blount and the other regional presidents are working to make sure that we stay very in tune with our sales force.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Moran from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Moran from Oppenheimer.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe you can go through how -- what you expect a little bit more on revenues for the year, just maybe some timing? So it sounds like, Jeff, you don't really expect any dissynergies from customer overlap or redundancy, but can focus a little bit more on t
componenttext: Maybe you can go through how -- what you expect a little bit more on revenues for the year, just maybe some timing? So it sounds like, Jeff, you don't really expect any dissynergies from customer overlap or redundancy, but can focus a little bit more on the specific products that either company have had in the past? Maybe you can see some better cross-selling and how long that might take to take in? And then maybe just an update on where you are with overall NOL number is, if you can give any color on that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the NOL number is $10.3 billion of U.S. NOL. And in general, I think we've got a decent NOL position in EMEA. Really, the only place that we are incurring cash income taxes are in Latin America, mostly Brazil than any other place. And then back t
componenttext: Sure. So the NOL number is $10.3 billion of U.S. NOL. And in general, I think we've got a decent NOL position in EMEA. Really, the only place that we are incurring cash income taxes are in Latin America, mostly Brazil than any other place. And then back the revenue point. I think that the cross-selling opportunities are there, but we'll see them happen more later in the year and next year. because the sales force to be trained on the combined company's products and platforms is affected by say this month. Now every sales person knows what accounts they are covering. So whether it's things like CBN services that we have, collaboration services that we have or long-haul services, services being offered outside of the U.S. being offered to tw telecom's base will be a good cross-selling opportunities. Similarly, some of the smaller customers within the Level 3 on-net building footprint would be good customers to sell to given the capabilities that tw telecom has in terms of call centers to go focus on those segments. So there are quite a number of opportunities. But we think that, that will take a few quarters to get going and we'll probably start seeing -- if you see the benefit of that, we'll probably be seeing more next year or later this year, is what I would say. Jeff I don't know if you want to...

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add that if you look at things like Ethernet services, which is one of the fastest-growing products or cloud solutions, tw and Level 3, we're the 2 leaders in those areas. So for Ethernet services, we've been able to combine the capabili
componenttext: Yes, I would just add that if you look at things like Ethernet services, which is one of the fastest-growing products or cloud solutions, tw and Level 3, we're the 2 leaders in those areas. So for Ethernet services, we've been able to combine the capabilities that tw had with the capabilities of Level 3. And that brings a lot to our ability to grow that market and that those products and services. If you look at Constellation, which was the cloud product that tw had been building and the Cloud Connect Solutions that Level 3 have, we've been able to -- we're going to be able to take the best capabilities of both of those and deliver a product and a service over a footprint that is somewhat unmatched by anyone else in the industry. And so some of those has the capabilities that make us -- made us excited about the tw telecom acquisition back last fall, but they make us even more excited about them today as we see the real capabilities in it.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And not really word about revenue dissynergies from customer overlap, at this point, I know Global Crossing there was a little bit more of that.
componenttext: And not really word about revenue dissynergies from customer overlap, at this point, I know Global Crossing there was a little bit more of that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the Global Crossing side, there were a lot of wholesale Internet providers that bought services from both Global and Level 3. And that's where you see those revenue dissynergies. We had very little overlap in that area from tw telecom. We had a lo
componenttext: Yes, on the Global Crossing side, there were a lot of wholesale Internet providers that bought services from both Global and Level 3. And that's where you see those revenue dissynergies. We had very little overlap in that area from tw telecom. We had a lot of overlap from big wholesale customers, but if they're buying a local circuit from tw telecom and Atlanta, and they're buying something at a local circuit from Level 3 in Dallas, there is no real negative revenue synergies associated with that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

componenttext: This is Lisa for Simon. Thanks for taking the question. Can you talk a little bit more about the competitive environment that you're seeing? And just how you been seeing there'll be some booking trends given the -- that you just closed the acquisition during the -- late last year?

componenttext: Sure, so I think from a bookings perspective we're grappling with just constant, common definitions that's why we did make too much commentary on bookings. I would say sales were a little softer in the fourth quarter, some of not too surprising given the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. And then I'm trying to think what the other part of your question, Lisa.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So competitive environment.
componenttext: So competitive environment.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our competitive environment, I would say, there continues to be consolidation currents going through. So the competitive environment, I would say, is stable. [indiscernible] rumors of Verizon and tw and asset sales and we'll see what transpires there.
componenttext: So our competitive environment, I would say, there continues to be consolidation currents going through. So the competitive environment, I would say, is stable. [indiscernible] rumors of Verizon and tw and asset sales and we'll see what transpires there. I think that in summary, I would say the competitive environment is benign. But obviously would have to go out and make business every day. So you do have to be sharp. But no big changes that we are seeing in the environment. Jeff?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, and I think we like our competitive position. If you look at the breadth of our product portfolio, we have everything from infrastructure services of datacenter and colo and fiber, all the way up to CDN and DDOS protection and security services and ma
componenttext: No, and I think we like our competitive position. If you look at the breadth of our product portfolio, we have everything from infrastructure services of datacenter and colo and fiber, all the way up to CDN and DDOS protection and security services and managed services. Across that spectrum, it gives us the ability to solve each customers unique networking challenges and on a global basis. And so we like that competitive position and think that very few other companies are really in a position to deliver towards for the full networking needs that customers have.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

componenttext: Great. And then I guess in terms of since you brought it up with Verizon AT&T massive sales, do you have any opinions on how that would play out?

componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple here. First on integration. At least relative to my expectations, you're running a little bit ahead of the synergy front. Maybe you can comment on the achievement of synergies so far and are expectations for the shape of that during 2015.
componenttext: I have a couple here. First on integration. At least relative to my expectations, you're running a little bit ahead of the synergy front. Maybe you can comment on the achievement of synergies so far and are expectations for the shape of that during 2015. Second on the combined company ability maybe to address a different customer base, maybe some early anecdotal evidence of the attractiveness of a combined Level 3-tw telecom based on a larger footprint and improved financial strength.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the synergies. No, I think the synergy that we reported are sort of in line because obviously, in the first quarter, you do get benefits. The senior management level, you get a fair bit of benefit right there, and most of them were in the SG&A
componenttext: Okay. So on the synergies. No, I think the synergy that we reported are sort of in line because obviously, in the first quarter, you do get benefits. The senior management level, you get a fair bit of benefit right there, and most of them were in the SG&A side. I think that the nature of where the synergies come from will see start seeing a bigger contribution from network expense reductions and Network Access cost reductions over the course of the year. And so different quarters, you will see different levels of progress. But I would say that so far, the synergies we are attaining are in line with what we expected.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: From a -- from the different customer base, I think that you'll see tw telecom's side will tend to move up to larger customers than maybe they focused on in the past. If you think back, they didn't have a long haul network really to sell. And so when long
componenttext: From a -- from the different customer base, I think that you'll see tw telecom's side will tend to move up to larger customers than maybe they focused on in the past. If you think back, they didn't have a long haul network really to sell. And so when long-haul deals, nationwide deals were in the mix, they tended not to win those. When there were global deals in the mix, they tended not to will not all, and probably didn't even bid on many of those. So we'll see them -- that side of our business move up market a little bit from customers. If you look from the Level 3 side, the customer base probably stays the same. But our product capabilities improved. If you look at the 30,000 buildings that tw telecom had, we had very little overlap in those buildings in the Level 3. We now have a bigger footprint to sell our products and services to those customers. We know that when we sell on-net, it's better margin for us, it's better experience to the customer. It's easier for us to deliver services and maintain those services in a more reliable fashion that we have -- then when we have to use offset providers. And I touched on some of the product benefits already with respect to Constellation and the capabilities that brings to us, our CDN and the capabilities that brings to our other side of the tw telecom business.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One quick clarification. When you highlighted that the revenue starts is around 20% international, I think, the real EBITDA exposure is around high single digits, is that correct, to FX?
componenttext: One quick clarification. When you highlighted that the revenue starts is around 20% international, I think, the real EBITDA exposure is around high single digits, is that correct, to FX?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said it's lower because of how we are structured, yes. So whatever impact we see on the revenue side is tempered quite significantly on the EBITDA side.
componenttext: Yes, as I said it's lower because of how we are structured, yes. So whatever impact we see on the revenue side is tempered quite significantly on the EBITDA side.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of James Morman with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of James Morman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, back to the integration of the sales force. With the new sales assignments, is there any -- how much -- is there any like areas where there's a big impact like a big shift where people come and get new customers or is it more of a minor types of th
componenttext: First, back to the integration of the sales force. With the new sales assignments, is there any -- how much -- is there any like areas where there's a big impact like a big shift where people come and get new customers or is it more of a minor types of things so we should not really not see an impact from that? And also on CDN revenue, any comments about -- I know we won't know anything more possibly until tomorrow on the net neutrality, but how that might potentially benefit you or impact CDN going forward?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. With respect to the sales impact, and I'm going to give a broader statement. We have a lot of say change going on with our sales force and we are very aware of that. And whether it's the account moves or the compensation alignment or the new product
componenttext: Sure. With respect to the sales impact, and I'm going to give a broader statement. We have a lot of say change going on with our sales force and we are very aware of that. And whether it's the account moves or the compensation alignment or the new products that portfolio, we are very aware that we have a lot of change going on, and our leadership team is focused on making sure that we give the sales team what they need to be successful. We've seen, through my comment earlier on the churn, we've seen that that's working so far because that's the first indicator if a salesperson loses confidence in their ability to sell at Level 3, then they will leave us. And if we look at our top performers, churn is down. If we look at the average salesforce, churn is about the same as it was prior to the acquisition. And so we have a lot of change going on, but we're very confident about it and working very hard and very closely with the team to make sure that we are focused on the things that will drive our growth and drive our success in that integration. With respect to net neutrality and CDN, we'll -- let's wait and see. I don't want to speculate too much on where things might go to. But in general, we're pleased that the regulators are recognizing that interconnection is a bigger part of net neutrality than anything else, and we think that we're moving in the right direction. If we talk about dispute mechanisms, if you have a dispute with a local monopoly provider where you can have a process for resolving some of these issues. So we'll see where they turn out. But generally, the direction is positive for us.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Anna Bochco with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Anna Bochco with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Sunit and Jeff, I guess, this free cash flow guidance implies that you should end the year with over $1 billion of cash? That's a nice thing to have. So I'm wondering with that, much cash, how do you think about your targeted -- other target cash balan
componenttext: So Sunit and Jeff, I guess, this free cash flow guidance implies that you should end the year with over $1 billion of cash? That's a nice thing to have. So I'm wondering with that, much cash, how do you think about your targeted -- other target cash balance and even get minimal a cash balance? And you are asked about the potential to refi bonds. But you have -- with that cash, you could actually pay down callable bonds with cash and help reduce a debt in interest expense that way. So wondering if you this could be where you're actually seeing the actual debt reduction rather than refinancing?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, good question. I mean I think we said that for quite some time that we view cash balance of at least $500 million is like a minimum for us. I think nothing's changed there. Refinancing, that also costs money in terms of net premium and refinancing c
componenttext: Sure, good question. I mean I think we said that for quite some time that we view cash balance of at least $500 million is like a minimum for us. I think nothing's changed there. Refinancing, that also costs money in terms of net premium and refinancing costs. And we've -- we think our cash to do that so that our debt outstanding does not go up. I think you've seen that as a common thing going done so that will continue. And then as far debt pay downs go, we're not currently thinking of debt pay downs. But it is a question we would have to think about in the context next year of how -- what are the best ways to optimize free cash flow per share when its debt pay downs or share buybacks or any other mechanism so we would study that. So that'll be next year's question to study. This year, we're just focused on getting integrating tw telecom, hitting on the synergies, hitting our free cash flow targets. And as we indicated, our net debt-to-EBITDA target is at the low end of 3 to 5x. We think that a lot of that will come from adjusted EBITDA growth. We do see strong EBITDA growth this year and also next year, so I think that the combination of that should get us there even without any debt pay downs. But it is an option for us, and we have to look at that compared to other options that we have. And as I said, this is for next year's considerations.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the just a quick follow-up on the business. So in the North American segment, you talked about the lower growth rate versus last year and some of the reasons. What are you seeing on the wholesale side from carrier consolidation? I know in the pa
componenttext: Okay. And the just a quick follow-up on the business. So in the North American segment, you talked about the lower growth rate versus last year and some of the reasons. What are you seeing on the wholesale side from carrier consolidation? I know in the past, it -- there's a lag effect often. So we are carriers consolidate, particularly on the wireless space, it takes a while for that traffic to get migrated off. Is there still headwinds from that? Or you've seen the end of that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So a couple of points. I think last year was a decent year on the wholesale side for us in North America. We didn't see some of those impacts talking about. But I also remember we didn't have consolidation in the wireless sector and there is a couple of t
componenttext: So a couple of points. I think last year was a decent year on the wholesale side for us in North America. We didn't see some of those impacts talking about. But I also remember we didn't have consolidation in the wireless sector and there is a couple of things right now in front of the government for approval. We'll see how those transpire. But I think stepping back away from all of this, Jeff, I'll say that also, which is we expect our growth come from the enterprise segment over time. The wholesale business, in general, we see as kind of declining slightly every year. In any particular good year, it's tough to predict what happens for all the reason that you've mentioned, that we talk about, and I would say that this year is not different from any other year with that -- from that perspective. But we think the wholesale segment is a very valuable segment for us, gives us a lot to scale, demanding customers that make us better provider of services. But having said that, where all our growth is going to be coming from the enterprise segment over the next years.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Davidson.
componenttext: Our last question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 EMEA questions, one for Jeff and one for Sunit. For Jeff, I realize it's early days, the permanent leadership it has only been in place for a few months, but I was wondering if you talk about some of the specific changes you're starting to make
componenttext: I've got 2 EMEA questions, one for Jeff and one for Sunit. For Jeff, I realize it's early days, the permanent leadership it has only been in place for a few months, but I was wondering if you talk about some of the specific changes you're starting to make over? And I guess more importantly, your confidence in your ability to materially improve that segment's performance over the next few years? And then for Sunit, recognizing that you're focused on tw telecom right now, you've mentioned in the past that M&A could be attractive. Does the strength of the dollar make deals more appealing? Or you're thinking transactions currently in local currency [indiscernible] relevant duration.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll start -- actually Sunit, you do your question.
componenttext: Sure. I'll start -- actually Sunit, you do your question.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So with respect to M&A in Europe, as we said in the past, we had been our histories been built on acquisition. We're pretty much focused on tw integration right now. We think M&A in Europe continues to be an interesting landscape. And yes, while the dolla
componenttext: So with respect to M&A in Europe, as we said in the past, we had been our histories been built on acquisition. We're pretty much focused on tw integration right now. We think M&A in Europe continues to be an interesting landscape. And yes, while the dollar has strengthened, is a consideration, remember that any business we might look to buy there will be denominated in euros or sterling or those currencies. So I think we continue to be interested. It's tough to predict when and how and if something will happen, but as Jeff has mentioned in the past and as I have, we think that our business is not at the level of skill that we'd like it to be. And over time, we are -- we will look for opportunities there. Our near-term focus is tw telecom integration.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to EMEA. I won't go into a lot of the specific changes that Andrew is making, but he is making changes in the sales organization for enterprise, he's making changes in the strategy organization, the product organizations and continuing to loo
componenttext: With respect to EMEA. I won't go into a lot of the specific changes that Andrew is making, but he is making changes in the sales organization for enterprise, he's making changes in the strategy organization, the product organizations and continuing to look at how we serve our customers over there and improving our operations and all of the different things. If you look at Andrew's background just for a minute. A few [ph] years ago he ran our wholesale business. Sunit talked about North America wholesale performance this year. If you look at the challenge in EMEA, wholesale's been a big challenge for us in the last year. And so Andrew's ability and proven track record of working with wholesale customers and understanding the wholesale business and delivering wholesale result is something that I have high confidence in. If you look at where we're making progress in EMEA but we wanted to be better is on our enterprise. We've made good progress in selling to enterprise customers last year. But we do -- we think we can do better. And if you look at Andrew's background and history over the last couple of years in running North America, we've made tremendous progress in our ability to sell to enterprise customers. And so looking at Andrew and his background and the track record that he brings, I'm very confident in our ability to do some of the things that we've talked about. When it comes to the U.K. government, I have less confidence, and Sunit reflected that in our outlook. And I think that has as much to do with the buying pattern of the U.K. government. We thought a couple of years ago that they were going to change the way they bought and buy pieces from different carriers. It turns out that they tend to buy full breadth solutions, including a whole bunch of things that we don't do. They want to have full solutions from some of their providers. And so I think there's less opportunity for Andrew to make a huge difference in the U.K. government. But if you look at what we've done in North America and again, Andrew is responsible -- was a key driver in what we've done with the U.S. government, we've been very successful at getting into the business, starting small and growing and growing and growing our importance to the customer. And so I think that we will continue to do that. If you look at our network and our capabilities in Europe, we have a good network. We have good capabilities. We're continuing to introduce products and standardizing those products. And so I think that we have good opportunities in Europe. And again, one of the 3 key priorities from our company this year is to make sure that we live up to our potential. I want to -- before we end the call, I'd like to leave you all with a few thoughts. We are highly focused on the successful integration of tw telecom. We're focused on improving our performance in EMEA, and believe that we have the right leader in place and the right team in place to drive the results. We've reached the transformational point in our company's history in terms of free cash flow generation. And while 2015 is somewhat of a transitional year, we expect to significantly improve free cash flow and we remain focused on driving profitable growth and free cash flow per share. We look forward to a successful 2015 and sharing our results with you over the coming quarters. And as always, we really appreciate your questions and your interest in Level 3. Operator, this concludes the call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
