componenttext: This is Eric Pan for Phil. Just wanted to clarify, does the EBITDA guidance include the estimated $50 million of integration costs?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the EBITDA guidance does include that.
componenttext: Yes, the EBITDA guidance does include that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And what has the sales force churn been like since the integration? Can you give us some color on whether it has increased or stayed roughly the same?
componenttext: Okay, great. And what has the sales force churn been like since the integration? Can you give us some color on whether it has increased or stayed roughly the same?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a very good question. The -- since the closing, we have not seen an increase in churn, and it's been about what it was before. And if you look at our top performers, it's actually lower than it was before. And so our -- we've got a lot of chan
componenttext: Yes, that's a very good question. The -- since the closing, we have not seen an increase in churn, and it's been about what it was before. And if you look at our top performers, it's actually lower than it was before. And so our -- we've got a lot of change going on and we're going to do a lot of things in the sales organization this year. But I think that our sales team sees the same thing that we see, which are great opportunities with the products and services we sell to take them to their customers and grow with our company. And so we have not seen an increase in churn and are very focused on that and very pleased and John Blount and the other regional presidents are working to make sure that we stay very in tune with our sales force.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sunit, maybe you can go through how -- what you expect a little bit more on revenues for the year, just maybe some timing? So it sounds like, Jeff, you don't really expect any dissynergies from customer overlap or redundancy, but can you focus a little bi
componenttext: Sunit, maybe you can go through how -- what you expect a little bit more on revenues for the year, just maybe some timing? So it sounds like, Jeff, you don't really expect any dissynergies from customer overlap or redundancy, but can you focus a little bit more on specific products that either company didn't have in the past so maybe you can see some better cross-selling and how long that might take to kick in? And then, Sunit, just maybe an update on where you are with the overall NOL number is, if you can give any color around that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the NOL number is $10.3 billion of U.S. NOL. And in general, I think we've got a decent NOL position in EMEA. Really, the only place that we are incurring cash income taxes are in Latin America, mostly Brazil than any other place. And then back t
componenttext: Sure. So the NOL number is $10.3 billion of U.S. NOL. And in general, I think we've got a decent NOL position in EMEA. Really, the only place that we are incurring cash income taxes are in Latin America, mostly Brazil than any other place. And then back to your revenue point. I think that the cross-selling opportunities are there, but we'll see them happen more later in the year and next year because both the sales forces that are being trained on the combined company's products and platforms is effective, as I have said, this month. Now every sales person knows what accounts they are covering. So whether it's things like CDN services that we have, collaboration services that we have or long-haul services, services being offered outside of the U.S. to tw telecom's base would be good cross-selling opportunities. Similarly, some of the smaller customers within the Level 3 on-net building footprint would be good customers to sell to given the capabilities that tw telecom has in terms of call centers to go focus on those segments. So there are quite a number of opportunities, but we think that, that will take a few quarters to get going and we'll probably start seeing -- if you see the benefit of that, we'll probably be seeing more next year or later this year, is what I would say. Jeff I don't know if you want to...

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add that if you look at things like Ethernet services, which is one of the fastest-growing products or cloud solutions, tw and Level 3 were the 2 leaders in those areas. So for Ethernet services, we've been able to combine the capabiliti
componenttext: Yes, I would just add that if you look at things like Ethernet services, which is one of the fastest-growing products or cloud solutions, tw and Level 3 were the 2 leaders in those areas. So for Ethernet services, we've been able to combine the capabilities that tw had with the capabilities of Level 3. And that brings a lot to our ability to grow that market and with those products and services. If you look at Constellation, which was the cloud product that tw had been building, and the Cloud Connect Solutions that Level 3 had, we've been able to -- we're going to be able to take the best capabilities of both of those and deliver a product and a service over a footprint that is somewhat unmatched by anyone else in the industry. And so some of those are the capabilities that make us -- made us excited about the tw telecom acquisition back last fall, that they make us even more excited about them today as we see the real capabilities in it.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not really worried about revenue dissynergies from customer overlap, at this point, I know Global Crossing there was a little bit more of that.
componenttext: I'm not really worried about revenue dissynergies from customer overlap, at this point, I know Global Crossing there was a little bit more of that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the Global Crossing side, there were a lot of wholesale Internet providers that bought services from both Global and Level 3. And that's where you see those revenue dissynergies. We have very little overlap in that area from tw telecom. We have a
componenttext: Yes, on the Global Crossing side, there were a lot of wholesale Internet providers that bought services from both Global and Level 3. And that's where you see those revenue dissynergies. We have very little overlap in that area from tw telecom. We have a lot of overlap from big wholesale customers, but if they're buying a local circuit from tw telecom in Atlanta, and they're buying something at a local circuit from Level 3 in Dallas, there is no real negative revenue synergies associated with that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Lisa for Simon. Can you talk a little bit more about the competitive environment that you're seeing? And just how you've been seeing there'll be some booking trends given the -- that you just closed the acquisition during the -- late last year?
componenttext: This is Lisa for Simon. Can you talk a little bit more about the competitive environment that you're seeing? And just how you've been seeing there'll be some booking trends given the -- that you just closed the acquisition during the -- late last year?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, so I think from a bookings perspective, we're grappling with just constant, common definitions that's why we didn't make too much commentary on bookings. I would say sales were a little softer in the fourth quarter, some of that not too surprising g
componenttext: Sure, so I think from a bookings perspective, we're grappling with just constant, common definitions that's why we didn't make too much commentary on bookings. I would say sales were a little softer in the fourth quarter, some of that not too surprising given the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. And then I think -- I'm trying to think what was the other part of your question, Lisa.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just sort of a bit more detail...
componenttext: Sure. Just sort of a bit more detail...

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, competitive environment, sorry. So competitive environment, I would say, there continues to be consolidation currents going through. So the competitive environment, I would say, is stable. We've also seen rumors of -- with Verizon and [indiscernible]
componenttext: Oh, competitive environment, sorry. So competitive environment, I would say, there continues to be consolidation currents going through. So the competitive environment, I would say, is stable. We've also seen rumors of -- with Verizon and [indiscernible] asset sales, we'll see what transpires there. I think that in summary, I would say the competitive environment is benign. But obviously we have to go out and win business every day so you do have to be sharp. But no big changes that we are seeing in the environment. Jeff?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, and I think we like our competitive position. If you look at the breadth of our product portfolio, we have everything from infrastructure services, of datacenter and colo and fiber, all the way up to CDN and DDoS protection and security services and m
componenttext: No, and I think we like our competitive position. If you look at the breadth of our product portfolio, we have everything from infrastructure services, of datacenter and colo and fiber, all the way up to CDN and DDoS protection and security services and managed services. Across that spectrum, it gives us the ability to solve each customer's unique networking challenges and on a global basis. And so we like that competitive position and think that very other -- very few other companies are really in a position to deliver toward the full networking needs that customers have.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And I guess just in terms of you brought it up with the Verizon and AT&T asset sales, do you have any opinions on kind of how that would play out?
componenttext: Great. And I guess just in terms of you brought it up with the Verizon and AT&T asset sales, do you have any opinions on kind of how that would play out?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, other than what you read about in the papers and rumors, I don't think we have anything to add.
componenttext: No, other than what you read about in the papers and rumors, I don't think we have anything to add.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple here. First on integration. At least relative to my expectations, you're running a little bit ahead on the synergy front. Maybe you can comment on the achievement of synergies so far and your expectation for the shape of that during 2015.
componenttext: I have a couple here. First on integration. At least relative to my expectations, you're running a little bit ahead on the synergy front. Maybe you can comment on the achievement of synergies so far and your expectation for the shape of that during 2015. Second on the combined company ability maybe to address a different customer base, maybe some early anecdotal evidence of the attractiveness of a combined Level 3-tw telecom based on a larger footprint and improved financial strength.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the synergies. No, I think the synergies that we reported are sort of in line because obviously, in the first quarter, you do get benefit your own -- at the senior management level, you get a fair bit of benefit right there, and most of them w
componenttext: Okay. So on the synergies. No, I think the synergies that we reported are sort of in line because obviously, in the first quarter, you do get benefit your own -- at the senior management level, you get a fair bit of benefit right there, and most of them were in the SG&A side. I think that the nature or where the synergies come from, will change across the air [ph]. We'll start seeing a bigger contribution from network expense reductions and Network Access cost reductions over the course of the year. And so at different quarters, you will see different levels of progress. But I would say that so far, the synergies we are attaining are in line with what we expected.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: From a -- from the different customer base, I think that you'll see on the tw telecom's side will tend to move up to larger customers than maybe they focused on in the past. If you think back, they didn't have a long-haul network really to sell. And so wh
componenttext: From a -- from the different customer base, I think that you'll see on the tw telecom's side will tend to move up to larger customers than maybe they focused on in the past. If you think back, they didn't have a long-haul network really to sell. And so when long-haul deals, nationwide deals were in the mix, they tended not to win those. When there were global deals in the mix, they tended not to win at all, and probably didn't even bid on many of those. So we'll see them -- that side of our business move up market a little bit from customers. If you look from the Level 3 side, the customer base probably stays the same. But our product capabilities improve. If you look at the 30,000 buildings that tw telecom had, we -- and then very little overlap in those buildings with the Level 3. We now have a bigger footprint to sell our products and services to those customers. We know that when we sell on-net, it's better margin for us, it's a better experience for the customer. It's easier for us to deliver services and maintain those services in a more reliable fashion than we have -- then when we have to use off-net providers. And I touched on some of the product benefits already with respect to Constellation and the capabilities that brings to us, our CDN and the capabilities that brings to our other side of the tw telecom business.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One quick clarification. I know you highlighted that the revenue exposure is around 20% international, I think, the real EBITDA exposure is around high single digits, is that correct, to FX?
componenttext: One quick clarification. I know you highlighted that the revenue exposure is around 20% international, I think, the real EBITDA exposure is around high single digits, is that correct, to FX?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said it's lower because of how we are structured, yes. So whatever impact we see on the revenue side is tempered quite significantly on the EBITDA side.
componenttext: Yes, as I said it's lower because of how we are structured, yes. So whatever impact we see on the revenue side is tempered quite significantly on the EBITDA side.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, back to the integration of the sales force. With the newest sales assignments, is there any -- how much -- is there any like areas where there's a big impact like a big shift where people are kind of getting new customers or is it more of a minor t
componenttext: First, back to the integration of the sales force. With the newest sales assignments, is there any -- how much -- is there any like areas where there's a big impact like a big shift where people are kind of getting new customers or is it more of a minor type of thing so we shouldn't really not see much of an impact from that? And also on CDN revenue, any comments about -- I know we won't know anything more, I guess, possibly until tomorrow on the net neutrality, but how that might potentially benefit you or impact CDN going forward?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. With respect to the sales impact, and I'm going to give a broader statement. We have a lot of say change going on within our sales force and we are very aware of that. And whether it's the account moves or the compensation alignment or the new produ
componenttext: Sure. With respect to the sales impact, and I'm going to give a broader statement. We have a lot of say change going on within our sales force and we are very aware of that. And whether it's the account moves or the compensation alignment or the new product set and product portfolio, we are very aware that we have a lot of change going on. And our leadership team is focused on making sure that we give the sales team what they need to be successful. We've seen, through my comment earlier on the churn, we've seen that that's working so far because that's the first indicator if a salesperson loses confidence in their ability to sell at Level 3, then they will lead less [ph]. And if we look at our top performer, churn is down. If we look at the average sales force churn is about the same as it was prior to the acquisition. And so we have a lot of change going on, but we're very confident about it and working very hard and very closely with the team to make sure that we are focused on the things that will drive our growth and drive our success in that integration. With respect to net neutrality and CDN, we'll -- let's wait and see. I don't want to speculate too much on where things might go. But in general, we're pleased that the regulators are recognizing that interconnection is as big a part of net neutrality as anything else, and we think that they're moving in the right direction. We've heard talk about dispute mechanisms, if you have a dispute with a local monopoly provider where you can have a process for resolving some of these issues. So we'll see where they turn out. But generally, the direction is positive for us.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Ana Goshko with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Ana Goshko with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Sunit and Jeff, I guess, the free cash flow guidance implies that you should end the year with over $1 billion of cash? It's a nice thing to have. And so I'm wondering, with that much cash, how do you think about your targeted -- other target cash bala
componenttext: So Sunit and Jeff, I guess, the free cash flow guidance implies that you should end the year with over $1 billion of cash? It's a nice thing to have. And so I'm wondering, with that much cash, how do you think about your targeted -- other target cash balance and even minimum cash balance? And you were asked about the potential to refi bonds, but you have -- with that cash, you could actually pay down callable bonds with cash and help reduce a debt and interest expense that way. So wondering if this could be a year where we actually just see actual debt reduction rather than refinancing?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, good question. I mean I think we've said for quite some time that we view a cash balance of at least $500 million as like a minimum for us. I think nothing's changed there. Refinancing debt also costs money in terms of debt premiums and refinancing
componenttext: Sure, good question. I mean I think we've said for quite some time that we view a cash balance of at least $500 million as like a minimum for us. I think nothing's changed there. Refinancing debt also costs money in terms of debt premiums and refinancing costs. And we've been using our cash to do that so that our debt outstanding does not go up. I think you've seen that as a common thing we've done, so I think that will continue. And then as far as debt paydowns go, we're not currently thinking of debt paydowns. But it is a question we would have to think about in the context next year of how -- what are the best ways to optimize free cash flow per share whether it's debt paydowns or share buybacks or any other mechanism, so we would study that. So that'll be next year's question to study. This year, we're just focused on getting -- integrating tw telecom, hitting on the synergies, hitting our free cash flow targets. And as we indicated, our net debt to EBITDA target is at the low end of 3 to 5x. We think that a lot of that will come from adjusted EBITDA growth. We do see strong EBITDA growth this year and also next year, so I think that the combination of that should get us there even without any debt paydowns. But it is an option for us, and we have to look at that compared to other options that we have. And as I said, this is for next year's considerations.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up on the business. So in the North American segment, you talked about the lower growth rate versus last year and some of the reasons. What are you seeing on the wholesale side from carrier consolidation? I know in the p
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up on the business. So in the North American segment, you talked about the lower growth rate versus last year and some of the reasons. What are you seeing on the wholesale side from carrier consolidation? I know in the past, it -- there's a lag effect often. So when you have carriers consolidate, particularly in the wireless space, it takes a while for that traffic to get migrated off. Is there still headwinds from that? Or you're seeing the end of that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So a couple of points. I think last year was a decent year on the wholesale side for us in North America. We didn't see some of those impacts you're talking about. Some of that also remember we didn't have, consolidation in the wireless sector, and there
componenttext: So a couple of points. I think last year was a decent year on the wholesale side for us in North America. We didn't see some of those impacts you're talking about. Some of that also remember we didn't have, consolidation in the wireless sector, and there is a couple of things right now in front of the government for approval. We'll see how those transpire. But I think stepping back away from all of this, Jeff said that, and I'll say that, this also, which is we expect to see our growth come from the enterprise segment over time. The wholesale business, in general, we see as kind of declining slightly every year. Now, in any particular good year, it's tough to predict what happens for all the reasons that you've mentioned that we've talked about, and I would say that this year is not different from any other year with that -- from that perspective. But we think the wholesale segment is a very valuable segment for us, gives us a lot of scale, demanding customers that make us better provider of services. But having said that, where all our growth is going to be coming from the enterprise segment over the next few years.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Our last question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 EMEA questions, one for Jeff and one for Sunit. For Jeff, I realize it's early days, the permanent leadership has only been in place for a few months, but I was wondering if you could talk a bit about some of the specific changes you're startin
componenttext: I've got 2 EMEA questions, one for Jeff and one for Sunit. For Jeff, I realize it's early days, the permanent leadership has only been in place for a few months, but I was wondering if you could talk a bit about some of the specific changes you're starting to make over there. And I guess more importantly, your confidence in your ability to materially improve that segment's performance over the next few years? And then for Sunit, recognizing that you're focused on tw telecom right now, you've mentioned in the past that M&A in Europe could be attractive. Does the strength of the dollar make deals more appealing? Or you're thinking transactions strictly in local currency in which case it's not a relevant consideration?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll start and -- actually, Sunit, you do your question.
componenttext: Sure. I'll start and -- actually, Sunit, you do your question.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with respect to M&A in Europe, I think as we've said in the past, we had been -- our history has been built on acquisition. We're pretty much focused on tw integration right now. We think M&A in Europe continues to be an interesting landscape. An
componenttext: Sure. So with respect to M&A in Europe, I think as we've said in the past, we had been -- our history has been built on acquisition. We're pretty much focused on tw integration right now. We think M&A in Europe continues to be an interesting landscape. And yes, while the dollar has strengthened, it is a consideration. Remember that any business we might look to buy there will be denominated in euros or sterling or those currencies. So I think we continue to be interested. It's tough to predict when and how and if something will happen, but as Jeff has mentioned in the past and as I have, we think that our business is not at the level of scale that we'd like it to be. And over time, we are -- we will look for opportunities there. Our near-term focus is tw telecom integration.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to EMEA. I won't go into a lot of the specific changes that Andrew is making, but he is making changes in the sales organization for enterprise. He's making changes in the strategy organization and the product organizations and continuing to
componenttext:
With respect to EMEA. I won't go into a lot of the specific changes that Andrew is making, but he is making changes in the sales organization for enterprise. He's making changes in the strategy organization and the product organizations and continuing to look at how we serve our customers over there and improving our operations and all of the different things. If you look at Andrew's background just for a minute. A few years ago he ran our wholesale business. Sunit talked about the North America wholesale performance this year. If you look at the challenge in EMEA, wholesale's been a big challenge for us in the last year. And so Andrew's ability and proven track record of working with wholesale customers and understanding the wholesale business and delivering in wholesale results is something that I have high confidence in. If you look at where we're making progress in EMEA, but we want it to be better, is on our enterprise. We've made good progress in selling to enterprise customers last year, but we do -- but we think we can do better. And if you look at Andrew's background and history over the last couple of years in running North America, we've made tremendous progress in our ability to sell to enterprise customers. And so looking at Andrew and his background and the track record that he brings, I'm very confident in our ability to do some of the things that we've talked about. When it comes to the U.K. government, I have less confidence, and Sunit reflected that in our outlook. And I think that has as much to do with the buying pattern of the U.K. government. We thought a couple of years ago that they were going to change the way they bought and buy pieces from different carriers. It turns out that they tend to buy full-breadth solutions, including a whole bunch of things that we don't do. They want to have full solutions from some of their providers. And so I think there's less opportunity for Andrew to make a huge difference in the U.K. government. But if you look at what we've done in North America, and again, Andrew is responsible -- was a key driver in what we've done with the U.S. government, we've been very successful at getting into the business, starting small and growing and growing and growing our importance to the customer. And so I think that we will continue to do that. If you look at our network and our capabilities in Europe, we have a good network. We have good capabilities. We're continuing to introduce products and standardizing those products. And so I think that we have good opportunities in Europe. And again, one of the 3 key priorities for our company this year is to make sure that we live up to our potential. 
I want to -- before we end the call, I'd like to leave you all with a few thoughts. We are highly focused on the successful integration of tw telecom. We're focused on improving our performance in EMEA, and believe that we have the right leader in place and the right team in place to drive the results. We've reached a transformational point in our company's history in terms of free cash flow generation. And while 2015 is somewhat of a transitional year, we expect to significantly improve free cash flow and we remain focused on driving profitable growth and free cash flow per share. We look forward to a successful 2015 and sharing our results with you over the coming quarters. And as always, we really appreciate your questions and your interest in Level 3. Operator, this concludes the call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, April 29,  2015. I would now like to turn the con
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, April 29,  2015. I would now like to turn the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Ms. Valerie Finberg. Please go ahead.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice Presi
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'd like to draw your attention to the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com.
On this site are the presentation materials that accompany this call, the earnings press release and supplemental financial information.
Comparisons to prior periods are being presented on a pro forma basis, assuming that our acquisition of tw telecom took place on January 1, 2014. In addition, the growth rates disclosed in our presentation and remarks are on a year-over-year basis. Revenue and sales comparisons to prior periods are provided on a constant-currency basis unless otherwise noted.
I need to call your attention to our Safe Harbor statement that begins on Page 2 of our 1Q '15 earnings presentation.
The presentation and remarks contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties.
Results may vary significantly from those statements. A discussion of factors that may affect future results can be found in Level 3's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Level 3 had a good start to the year with solid execution and integration and continued focus on profitable growth. Over the past few quarters, we've outlined our 3 key priorities: f
componenttext:
Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Level 3 had a good start to the year with solid execution and integration and continued focus on profitable growth. 
Over the past few quarters, we've outlined our 3 key priorities: first and foremost is the successful integration of Level 3 and tw telecom; second is enabling EMEA to live up to its full potential and deliver the growth we believe we can achieve in that region; third is positioning Level 3 for growth well into the future. 
After Sunit reviews our financial results, I will briefly discuss each of these with most of my comments on the integration of tw telecom. After that, we'll open it up for your questions. 
Sunit, I'll turn the call over to you.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We started 2015 with a good quarter, and we made steady progress on capturing annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. Given the first quarter run rate performance on adjusted EBITDA, we are raising our
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We started 2015 with a good quarter, and we made steady progress on capturing annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. 
Given the first quarter run rate performance on adjusted EBITDA, we are raising our 2015 outlook for adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow. 
I'll start on Slide 3 of our first quarter earnings presentation. Our core network services revenue for the first quarter of 2015 grew 6% year-over-year. Our enterprise core network services revenue grew 8.1% year-over-year. Including integration-related expenses of $5 million, adjusted EBITDA grew to $635 million. 
We generated free cash flow of $51 million. And since the acquisition closed, we've now achieved $95 million in annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. 
Turning to Slide 4. CNS revenue grew 6% on a constant-currency basis and 3.9% on an as-reported basis. The difference in growth rates is due to the strengthening of the dollar. Outside of the U.S. dollar, which represents 88% of CNS revenue, our top 3 foreign currencies are the British pound, the euro and the Brazilian real, representing 5%, 3% and 3% of CNS revenues, respectively. 
On a revenue weighted average basis, those 3 currencies declined 13% against the dollar compared to the year-ago quarter and negatively affected our CNS revenue growth by approximately 2% this quarter. 
On a regional basis, North America CNS revenue grew 7%, and enterprise CNS revenue grew 8.8%. In EMEA, CNS revenue declined 0.8% on a constant-currency basis and 9.2% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 5.7% on a constant-currency basis and declined 2.6% on an as-reported basis. 
U.K. government revenue grew 4.5% in the first quarter but declined sequentially. For the full year, we expect U.K. government to decline a little less than the 17% decline we saw last year, which is a slight improvement from our previous outlook. U.K. government revenue should continue to decline sequentially the rest of this year. Overall, we still expect U.K. government to keep declining over the next several years. This revenue is now 1.4% of total CNS revenue. 
EMEA also CNS revenue declined 11% on a constant-currency basis and 20% on an as-reported basis, driven primarily by industry consolidation and associated customer disconnects as well as our focus on profitable growth. As we mentioned last quarter, we expect better performance and comparisons in wholesale over the remainder of the year. 
In Latin America, CNS revenue grew 6.2% on a constant-currency basis and declined 2.6% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue grew 5.8% on a constant-currency basis and declined 3.3% on an as-reported basis. 
For the first quarter, wholesale CNS revenue grew 7.4% on a constant-currency basis and was flat on an as-reported basis. We expect the Enterprise business to show stronger performance over the balance of the year. 
With respect to Venezuela, we moved to the SICAD 1 rate in the second quarter of last year. Currently, there is a 3-tiered exchange rate mechanism in Venezuela for exchanging bolivars into U.S. dollars. The first is the official exchange rate of VEF 6.3 per U.S. dollar. The second is the SICAD 1 rate that we are using, which is currently at VEF 12 to the dollar, and the third is a new open market foreign exchange system called the exchange rate that was established in February 2015 and was VEF 193 to the U.S. dollar at March 31, 2015. 
At this time, the majority of our transactions with customers and suppliers are at the SICAD 1 rate. We will continue to closely monitor activity in Venezuela with respect to exchange rates, and we expect the future changes regarding exchange mechanisms could result in a negative affect to our Venezuela operations, profit, cash flows and cash balance. 
At the end of the first quarter, the company's cash balance in Venezuela maintained in bolivars was USD 72 million at the SICAD 1 rate, and we had about $20 million in revenue in the period. 
Wholesale voice services and other or WVS revenue declined 16% to $126 million in the first quarter of 2014 (sic) (2015). We expect continued double-digit rates of decline in WVS revenue in 2015. 
Moving to churn. As many of you are aware, Level 3 had a slightly different methodology in calculating churn from tw telecom. As part of our integration activities, we have adopted tw telecom's methodology, which we believe provides a better representation of true churn or disconnects because that definition excluded churn or disconnects that were replaced by an upgraded service by the same customer between the same locations. 
On a combined company basis, CNS revenue churn was 1%. This was a slight improvement from 1.1% also on a combined company basis from both the first quarter of last year and the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Slide 5 provides an overview of the mix between CNS versus WVS revenue and CNS revenue on a geographic and customer basis. 
Turning to Slide 6 and revenue results by product group, which I'd like to note are shown on an as-reported basis. Because currency had a larger effect on our revenue this quarter, we also noted these results on a constant-currency basis. 
The company's growth continues to be driven by our IP and data services, which grew 9%. Within that group, CDN revenue grew 2.4%. We expect CDN performance to improve later in the year as we deploy more capacity. 
Transport and fiber grew 5.4%. Within transport and fiber, dark fiber grew 3.2%. Voice services grew 0.6%, and colocation and data center services grew 3.8%. 
Regarding pricing, as we've said for several quarters, we've seen little change in the pricing environment. We remain disciplined across our product portfolio and service regions in driving profitable growth. 
Turning to Slide 7. Network access margin expanded to 64.8% compared to 64% in the first quarter 2014. The improvement in network access margin was driven by integration-related network synergies with continued high-margin CNS revenue growth and low-margin WVS revenue declines. 
Network-related expenses, excluding noncash compensation, were $351 million for the first quarter of 2015 compared to $347 million in the first quarter of 2014. SG&A, excluding noncash compensation expenses and integration-related expenses, for the first quarter was $339 million. This compares to $342 million for the first quarter of 2014. 
Turning to Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA, including integration-related expenses, was $635 million for the first quarter of 2015. Excluding integration-related expenses of $10 million, adjusted EBITDA was $640 million. This compares to $625 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 and $593 million for the first quarter of 2014. The improvement in adjusted EBITDA was primarily driven by good progress in capturing operating expense synergies. 
Adjusted EBITDA margin, including acquisition-related expenses, improved to 30.9% compared to 29.6% for the first quarter of 2014. 
Moving to synergies. Since the acquisition closed, we achieved approximately $95 million of annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies with $14 million of network access cost synergies and $81 million of operating expense synergies. We've clearly made good progress capturing OpEx synergies thus far. For the remainder of the year, we expect to make more progress capturing network access-related synergies. 
On Slide 9, capital expenditures were $254 million in the first quarter of 2015, representing 12% of total revenue. For the full year 2015, we continue to expect capital expenditures of approximately 15% of total revenue. 
The company generated free cash flow of $51 million in the quarter. Cash flows saw a benefit this quarter, driven by timing of both capital expenditures and approximately $20 million in net cash interest expense that we had expected to incur in the first quarter but was pushed to the second quarter since we redeemed debt that we had refinanced out to April 1 in the second quarter versus our expectations of the first quarter. As of March 31, 2015, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $560 million pro forma for the redemption of the 9 3/8% senior notes on April 1, 2015. 
Turning to Slide 10. As noted in our earnings release, we completed several capital markets transactions over the past few months as we opportunistically managed the balance sheet. Related to those transactions, we expect to incur a $136 million noncash charge for the extinguishment of debt in the second quarter. These 2015 refinancing transactions in total saved us about $64 million in annualized cash interest expense. 
We exited the quarter with our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio at 4.2x on a pro forma basis. This compares to 4.4x at the end of last quarter. We remain focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 5x, driven by growth in adjusted EBITDA. Our average interest rate on our debt is now 5.3% compared to 6.8% a year ago for Level 3 standalone. 
Moving on to our outlook for the year on Slide 11. Based on first quarter performance, synergy attainment and continued focus on profitable growth, we are updating our outlook for the full year 2015. 
We now expect adjusted EBITDA growth of 14% to 17% for the full year 2015 compared to our previous outlook of 12% to 16%. We are also raising our full year 2015 free cash flow outlook to $600 million to $650 million, which compares to our previous outlook of $550 million to $600 million. 
Additionally, based on our recent capital markets activity, we now expect $660 million in GAAP interest expense and $645 million on net cash interest expense compared to our previous guidance of $680 million and $640 million, respectively. All other guidance measures remain unchanged and are listed here on this slide. 
Last quarter, in my remarks on the conference call, we had provided our outlook for 2015 CNS constant currency revenue growth performance on a regional basis compared to what we saw in 2014. That outlook remains intact. 
For North America, we expect CNS revenue growth to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For Latin America, we expect comparable performance to the 8.5% growth we saw in 2014. For EMEA, we expect a decline that will be smaller than the 2.2% decline we saw in 2014. 
In summary, we had a good start to the year and remain confident in our financial performance for the remainder of the year. We feel good about the progress we are making in achieving the synergies as we integrate tw telecom. We look forward to reporting our progress next quarter. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sunit. Since the acquisition of tw telecom, we've talked about 2015 as a transition year for Level 3. As I look back on the 6 months since the acquisition closed, I'm pleased with how much we've accomplished and the lack of surprises. To be c
componenttext:
Thank you, Sunit. Since the acquisition of tw telecom, we've talked about 2015 as a transition year for Level 3. As I look back on the 6 months since the acquisition closed, I'm pleased with how much we've accomplished and the lack of surprises. 
To be clear, no surprises is a good thing. The customer experience tw telecom provided is as good as we expected. Our combined portfolio of products and services address the ever-changing challenges our enterprise customers face and are well received in the market. 
The strength of the combined network provides a solid foundation for those products and services. And given the lack of customer overlap between the companies, there's been very little revenue loss driven by the need for diversity. 
Operationally, we've seen very few surprises as well. Maintaining the sales momentum we experienced pretty close has been a key focus area. While sales were a little light at the end of the fourth quarter and the beginning of the first quarter, overall, we've been pleased with the results, and March was a very good sales month. In spite of all the changes and all of the integration efforts, sales in the first quarter of 2015 improved over the same period last year. 
Service delivery intervals are always critical indicators of our integration efforts. Our North America service delivery team has done a very good job and maintained our installation performance. 
Looking at the acquisition synergies, we are ahead of schedule and are determined to capture synergies while also maintaining the customer experience. From a platform perspective, we have interconnected the networks. We've standardized our go-forward architectures globally and have begun implementing a unified network design. And lastly, the systems integration and development work has begun in earnest, and we are building a company-wide platform for growth well into the future. 
At the heart of our integration plans has been a focus on our people. Building one company culture is important to our success, and as a result, it receives a lot of our attention. Even prior to the close, we determined the go-forward organization structure and the leadership team and communicated those decisions to employees clearly and early. 
Shortly after close, we standardized our benefits for all of our North America employees. In early February, we began integrating the sales organization, solidifying the General Manager environment and assigning the go-forward accounts to all sales people. At that same time, we established our global account management team to provide a deeper focus on major customers doing business across multiple regions. 
At the beginning of this month, we rolled out a single customer relationship management or CRM system across North America and EMEA and have implemented a unified sales compensation structure in North America. This is a lot of change for a sales force. 
While there have certainly been issues along the way and it is way too early to declare success, leading indicators are important. Our sales team's confidence and the combined product and service portfolio remain strong. Voluntary sales force churn is consistent with premerger levels. The quality of the sales funnel continues to improve, and our first quarter sales results improved over the same period last year. 
I've discussed our key priority of positioning Level 3 for future growth. Many of the integration initiatives I've mentioned are really the foundation of the global company we are building. Whether in our product portfolio, our operational capabilities or our platforms, we're building Level 3 as a global solution for our customers networking needs. 
While we're focused on integration, we have not lost sight of the need for continual innovation. As an example, we announced the launch of our expanded DDoS platform this quarter. Our customers have very real and strategic security challenges, and they look to Level 3 to safeguard their networks and protect their capabilities. Level 3's unique position to the industry and our ability to see a comprehensive view of the threat landscape allows us to work with enterprises to effectively protect their networks. 
Turning to EMEA. We continue to make changes in management, improve our sales discipline, enhance our operational performance and focus our investments on profitable growth opportunities. I believe we're on the right path for improved performance, but it's still early in the process. We will share our progress in future calls. 
Sunit provided a commentary on our financial performance in Latin America, but I wanted to add a little bit. I spent time in LatAm last month, and I wanted you to know we have an excellent team there. They continue to be optimistic about our opportunity, and despite the macro pressures in those countries, the dynamics that drive our business in the region, dynamics like bandwidth growth, migration to cloud services and the evolution to new IP-based technologies, all of those dynamics remain intact in the region. 
Across our business, customers tell us they appreciate our intimate knowledge of their communications challenges, our ability to design solutions to meet their needs and the personal touch they see from our teams, all of these factors are helping to position Level 3 as the communications provider of choice. 
With that, we'll open it up for your questions. Operator, would you explain the process?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, a couple of questions. First, maybe you can just talk a little bit about the strength in the North American enterprise, what's driving the strength there? It seems as though on a constant-currency basis, North America, but you started the year at a
componenttext: Guys, a couple of questions. First, maybe you can just talk a little bit about the strength in the North American enterprise, what's driving the strength there? It seems as though on a constant-currency basis, North America, but you started the year at a faster growth rate than what your full year guidance would imply. And then second, Jeff, I appreciate your comments on LatAm. Maybe just talk a little bit about what contributed to the little bit slower start than what you might have been expecting for the full year there, and Sunit made a comment that he expected enterprise to get stronger in LatAm throughout the year. Just talk about what the drivers are of that in the region.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the LatAm question first. So I think in LatAm, we had a very strong sales quarter in the first quarter. And looking at the backlog they have and the strength they've seen the sales in the first quarter and the funnel, we see the Enterprise busin
componenttext: I'll take the LatAm question first. So I think in LatAm, we had a very strong sales quarter in the first quarter. And looking at the backlog they have and the strength they've seen the sales in the first quarter and the funnel, we see the Enterprise business growth improving over the balance of the year. They've also had quite a bit of strength in the Wholesale segment, and we think some of that will continue for the rest of the year. So when you put both of those together, we think that you'll see better performance. I think on the North American Enterprise business, as Jeff pointed out, we started off with a good sales quarter, and that helped. But on the revenue performance, as we pointed out last quarter, remember that last year as we said 3 months ago, we were turning up a lot of Starbucks revenue, and we had some fat contracts that we won in 2013 that we were turning up in '14 so we don't have that -- the benefit of those 2 things this year. But aside from those 2 things, I think the tone of the business across all segments, including federal, is pretty good. Jeff, if you could add anything to that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. I think Sunit's last statement is the one that I'll key on. The tone of the business is pretty good across our business. If you look at LatAm, the tone in the business, the drivers of our growth in the region, those are pretty st
componenttext: No, I think that's right. I think Sunit's last statement is the one that I'll key on. The tone of the business is pretty good across our business. If you look at LatAm, the tone in the business, the drivers of our growth in the region, those are pretty strong and pretty solid. The same is true in North America.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on that on the North American side. You definitely talked about Starbucks and the government though I think some government stuff that you won in 2014. Is there any sense for how we should be thinking about the timing of when tho
componenttext: If I could just follow up on that on the North American side. You definitely talked about Starbucks and the government though I think some government stuff that you won in 2014. Is there any sense for how we should be thinking about the timing of when those came in '14 so we can think about the anniversary of those and how that might impact growth on a go-forward basis?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well. So I mean, as I mentioned in my comments, we expect and as we said last quarter, we expect the North American business to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For this quarter, we were close to 6%. So obvious
componenttext: Well. So I mean, as I mentioned in my comments, we expect and as we said last quarter, we expect the North American business to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For this quarter, we were close to 6%. So obviously, the year-over-year comparison are softening. I think you'll see that continue for a little bit this year. And again, it's all tied into when last year, it's more last year story than this year's and that we were turning up those contracts that we won in early years in 2014. And now that they are more largely turned up, that's the impact you're seeing. But other than that, generally the business across the board, tone looks good.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sunit, when I saw you a couple of months ago, you were thinking about the potential for sales force disruption once you paid in your bonuses. What did you see as that sort of March and April came through?
componenttext: Sunit, when I saw you a couple of months ago, you were thinking about the potential for sales force disruption once you paid in your bonuses. What did you see as that sort of March and April came through?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jeff answer that question. The only thing I would say as we've talked about, we did look across the sales force at the bottom performance, and so we had some reductions, which we thought were helpful. But overall, I'll let Jeff talk about sales f
componenttext: I'll let Jeff answer that question. The only thing I would say as we've talked about, we did look across the sales force at the bottom performance, and so we had some reductions, which we thought were helpful. But overall, I'll let Jeff talk about sales force.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look at our sales force, we are down from where we were in the fourth quarter. Almost all of that was planned on our part, as Sunit mentioned, that we look at the bottom percentage of our sales force and continually manage low-performing peop
componenttext: Sure. If you look at our sales force, we are down from where we were in the fourth quarter. Almost all of that was planned on our part, as Sunit mentioned, that we look at the bottom percentage of our sales force and continually manage low-performing people either to make them better or to move them out of the business. But we also look at the skill set we need and the competency we need to fit our go-to-market strategy, and so we're continually evolving making sure that each of our various sales channels have the right people, are of the right size to match the opportunity of the best in front of them. So we'll continue to manage that. We haven't seen yet involuntary or excuse me, voluntary sales attrition outside of what we saw prior to the close of the merger. So we're feeling pretty good about that, but we've made a lot of change to the sales organization, and a lot of that change is just now implementing. And so in my comments, I said it's too early to declare success, but we are paying very close attention. Our sales team knows how critical they are. And rather than focusing on the number of sales people we have in our sales channels, we focus on the productivity of those sales channels, the overall output of those. And we know that the more productive we can make our sales people, the happier they are, the more they stay with us, the better we grow as a business. And so we're focused on making each and every sales person very productive and making sure that we give them the best place to work in the industry.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good to see progress on the synergy realization. Is this primarily a timing thing? Or do you think there might be ability to get upside? Are you seeing some opportunities that perhaps you haven't put in your $200 million guidance? And I know all the
componenttext: Yes. Good to see progress on the synergy realization. Is this primarily a timing thing? Or do you think there might be ability to get upside? Are you seeing some opportunities that perhaps you haven't put in your $200 million guidance? And I know all the guidance is really on the cost and CapEx side. What about revenue synergies? Have you seen any progress on trying to cross-sell products into each customer set?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of the question. Jeff can talk about the revenue synergies part. So on the cost side, I think it's timing mostly, Simon. I don't think we see more synergies per se at this point. I think what happened is all our various organizati
componenttext: I'll take the first part of the question. Jeff can talk about the revenue synergies part. So on the cost side, I think it's timing mostly, Simon. I don't think we see more synergies per se at this point. I think what happened is all our various organizations or functions within the company moved to and felt confident in moving a little earlier on the cost reductions, one part being the sales side as Jeff pointed out, and we haven't seen any loss in sales production there as we pointed out. And the second side and all the other functions just people taking out cost out earlier. So I'd say it's timing on the OpEx side. We expect more progress on the net side. So at this point, we don't see more synergies per se. I think we've just had a strong start and obviously, that's in the run rate, which is benefiting overall EBITDA.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you look at revenue synergies, Simon, we've described and view 2015 as a transition year, and we are focused on making sure that we integrated the 2 companies well, that we built a platform for our future success, that we do the basics that we need to
componenttext: If you look at revenue synergies, Simon, we've described and view 2015 as a transition year, and we are focused on making sure that we integrated the 2 companies well, that we built a platform for our future success, that we do the basics that we need to be doing today to position Level 3 for growth well into the future. That cross-selling and upselling is part of that. And as you guys know, most of our new sales come from existing customers, and so we will continue to focus on cross-sell and upsell opportunities but believe that 2015 is a transition year, where we are putting our sales force through an enormous amount of change and our customers through a fair amount of change as well. And so we are really focused on making sure that we make that transition well and that we work closely with our customers to satisfy their needs on a daily basis.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Two, if I may. First off, I just wanted to get the company's sense on comfort around doing additional M&A, particularly outside the United States as it seems like you're doing well with the tw telecom transaction and senior management's ability to
componenttext: Great. Two, if I may. First off, I just wanted to get the company's sense on comfort around doing additional M&A, particularly outside the United States as it seems like you're doing well with the tw telecom transaction and senior management's ability to focus on something like that. And then the second question, you did get refi-ed a little bit faster this year than we had anticipated. Can you just remind us what's still that could potentially be called in 2015 and even 2016?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question, and Jeff can answer the first one. So on the debt refi, I think you're right. We moved quickly to take advantage of the debt markets. We currently do not have any fixed-rate debt or bounds that are callable until next year.
componenttext: I'll take the second question, and Jeff can answer the first one. So on the debt refi, I think you're right. We moved quickly to take advantage of the debt markets. We currently do not have any fixed-rate debt or bounds that are callable until next year. So I think that at least on the bond side, not much to do this year. And then on the bank side, which is our floating rate debt, we continue to look at that to see if there might be opportunities there, but I think we're generally done with respect to bond refinancing for this year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with respect to M&A, M&A is part of our strategy. We look at gaps in our capabilities. We look gaps in our network. We look at opportunities to add customers and view M&A as a mechanism to do all those things. And so we'll continue to focus on emanate
componenttext: And with respect to M&A, M&A is part of our strategy. We look at gaps in our capabilities. We look gaps in our network. We look at opportunities to add customers and view M&A as a mechanism to do all those things. And so we'll continue to focus on emanate. It's opportunistic by the very nature of it. Outside the U.S. as you mentioned, Colby, it is probably more in our targets than maybe inside the U.S. we given that we've just done the tw telecom acquisition. The real comment I want to leave though in your mind about M&A is we will not do anything from an M&A perspective that causes us to the damage our integration with tw telecom. That is the highest priority for us as a business. I think you're right in saying that the North America team, management team is focused well on that, and so if we were to do something outside of North America, I think that it creates less of a distraction, but we will not do anything from an M&A perspective that harms our ability to integrate tw telecom effectively.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Nathanson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Nathanson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Actually I had 2. First, CapEx was below this quarter. I was wondering if we should expect a ramp over the next 3 quarters to get up to your 15% guidance range or if it's possible that during the year, it might come in a bit right? And second, I thi
componenttext: Okay. Actually I had 2. First, CapEx was below this quarter. I was wondering if we should expect a ramp over the next 3 quarters to get up to your 15% guidance range or if it's possible that during the year, it might come in a bit right? And second, I think there are 2 new transatlantic systems that are supposed to be coming online this year. It's been a long time since any of transatlantic systems have been built. So I was wondering if you could talk a bit about whether or not you think these are wishful thinking about transatlantic business and maybe talk a bit more generally those assets, what's revenue contribution and maybe overall business and their importance in terms of driving related sales.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start, and then Sunit probably has some maybe he wants to add to it. First of all, on the CapEx, our guidance, we gave guidance of 15% of revenue. We're still comfortable with that. CapEx spending is lumpy. If you look at the first quarter, it
componenttext: Yes, let me start, and then Sunit probably has some maybe he wants to add to it. First of all, on the CapEx, our guidance, we gave guidance of 15% of revenue. We're still comfortable with that. CapEx spending is lumpy. If you look at the first quarter, it's usually a little lighter than the rest of the year. And so we're still very comfortable with our 15% guidance as a percentage of revenue. With respect to transatlantic, there are new cables coming online over the next couple of years. That's not only true in transatlantic. That's true in South America and other places, and we view those assets, the assets that we have as a competitive strategic advantage in our ability to operate. Having said that, we're always looking at ways to lower our cost for the next capacity, and we'll work with those systems to see how it makes sense for Level 3 to take advantage of what's coming online. But those assets that we have, the subsea assets, are still an advantage for Level 3 and something that we continue to work hard to monetize effectively. Sunit?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Two quick questions. Just curious, how are you viewing the market outlook post the breakup of the Comcast, Time Warner Cable? Obviously, would have been up, more formidable competitor in the marketplace that change your outlook and you see opportun
componenttext: Great. Two quick questions. Just curious, how are you viewing the market outlook post the breakup of the Comcast, Time Warner Cable? Obviously, would have been up, more formidable competitor in the marketplace that change your outlook and you see opportunities there, and then are there any sort of noncore businesses that you might monetize? You've done a very good job at refinancing and using your cash for those purposes. Anything else you might streamline the business with jettison to get more focused on the core business and possibly delever some more.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, with respect to the first comment on -- the first question on Time Warner Cable and Comcast, we don't have any specific comments on that deal, don't really want to -- don't really changed our outlook for the year based on whether that deal went throu
componenttext: Yes, with respect to the first comment on -- the first question on Time Warner Cable and Comcast, we don't have any specific comments on that deal, don't really want to -- don't really changed our outlook for the year based on whether that deal went through or not. Both companies are very good customers of ours. Both companies we've worked very closely with to continue to evolve the industry and look forward to working with them in the future. With respect to noncore assets, nothing in particular. We look at all of our business and say, "How do we drive profitable growth, and how do we drive free cash flow on a per-share basis?" And so we will continue to look at things. If they're noncore assets, we will continue to look at interest expenses. We'll continue to look at all of the different things in our business that we think are levers to drive improving free cash flow per share.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
