componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a bit more about the competitive environment and what you're seeing in terms of other fiber providers and their ability to compete against you. Also, within that context, maybe talk a little bit about the products within
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a bit more about the competitive environment and what you're seeing in terms of other fiber providers and their ability to compete against you. Also, within that context, maybe talk a little bit about the products within enterprise and what's going really well with those products, and were there any products that you have in that portfolio that may actually be holding back the performance in revenue.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Sunit and I both have lots to comment on this topic. From a competitive environment perspective, we're in a very competitive industry, and there are lots of companies that sell the type of products and services that we sell. And so we are ver
componenttext: Yes, I think Sunit and I both have lots to comment on this topic. From a competitive environment perspective, we're in a very competitive industry, and there are lots of companies that sell the type of products and services that we sell. And so we are very accustomed to competing in a competitive industry with -- and competing on the strength of our products and the strength of our customer experience. If you look at our products from the competitive point of view, I think that is one of our big strengths. We have a variety of platforms and technologies to deliver for the networking needs of our customers. If you only have dark fiber then everything that you sell looks like a dark fiber solution. If you only have IP then everything looks like an IP solution. If you only have CDN, everything looks like a CDN solution. For Level 3, we have all of those things. We have those -- that robust set of products where we can look at a customers traffic and to pick not only the right platform for that customer but the right platform for some of that customers traffic may not be the right solution for all of other, and so we can bring to those customers the variety of products. And then after we've done that, we can wrap around those capabilities our security services and our DDoS protection. We can wrap around our managed services and professional services. And so we think we're in a very competitive, a good, competitive position because of the strength of our products, the breadth of our network, the sophistication of our network and ultimately driven by our employees, delivery of a great customer experience for our customers.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't have anything to add. I think the biggest thing is that given our network reach and the capillarity we have and the broad portfolio of services we have is a big advantage for us vis-a-vis others.
componenttext: No, I don't have anything to add. I think the biggest thing is that given our network reach and the capillarity we have and the broad portfolio of services we have is a big advantage for us vis-a-vis others.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, with your profitable growth focus and churn being down to 1%, are there any areas you think maybe you can actually start to raise prices now more than we've seen the last couple of years? And then secondly on CapEx, is there any shift in focus on Ca
componenttext: Jeff, with your profitable growth focus and churn being down to 1%, are there any areas you think maybe you can actually start to raise prices now more than we've seen the last couple of years? And then secondly on CapEx, is there any shift in focus on CapEx. I know Verizon announced SDN yesterday, but maybe just broadly speaking areas where you maybe see where you're going to spend more in the future.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. From a raising prices perspective, we look at our pricing strategically whether it's raising prices or lowering prices. We look at each product. We look at each geography. We look at each customer segment, and we try and match our pricing to the mar
componenttext: Sure. From a raising prices perspective, we look at our pricing strategically whether it's raising prices or lowering prices. We look at each product. We look at each geography. We look at each customer segment, and we try and match our pricing to the market and make sure that we are competitive in that market, and so I can't give you any specific products that we're planning on raising prices on, but we do look at pricing as one of the levers that we have to drive profitable growth, and we have done that in the past, and we'll continue to do that in the future. With respect to our CapEx strategy, I think you mentioned SDN, Software-Defined Networking and network function virtualization, NFV. Those are things that are very real in the Level 3 network, and we are investing in all of those things. We believe very strongly that our customers want to be able to dynamically insert networking capabilities on the fly. If you look at the tw telecom Constellation family of products and capabilities, we are incorporating that dynamic bandwidth capacity in the go-forward product that we have out for our customers. That is whether you're inserting capacity on demand or you're inserting our DDoS scrubbing network and our DDoS protection network on demand for customers' traffic or your inserting a network firewall, those are the types of SDN, NFV capabilities that we are building into our platform, and it's part of our CapEx program and has been part of our CapEx program.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I have 2 quick ones here. I appreciate the commentary about the direction of revenue growth, the different business segments that you gave. Maybe if you could synthesize that and help us think about the CNS run rate revenue and growth towards the end
componenttext: Yes. I have 2 quick ones here. I appreciate the commentary about the direction of revenue growth, the different business segments that you gave. Maybe if you could synthesize that and help us think about the CNS run rate revenue and growth towards the end of the year, given those factors you talked about. And then second, great job on the synergies on the EBITDA side. You also guided for $40 million CapEx savings when you announced the deal. I just wanted to review I guess how you got to that number whether or not that was just eliminating duplicative spending, if that was a zero-based budgeting approach, just wanted to get a better sense there.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So on the CapEx side, we looked at how much both companies were spending with various kinds of suppliers whether it was transport gear, voice gear, CDN gear, IP, and it was based upon where we think we could get by just leveraging our bigger pu
componenttext: All right. So on the CapEx side, we looked at how much both companies were spending with various kinds of suppliers whether it was transport gear, voice gear, CDN gear, IP, and it was based upon where we think we could get by just leveraging our bigger purchasing power. So I think, and I think we mentioned this last call that essentially, during the integration planning period and right after closing, we had agreements with most of our suppliers to essentially lock in the CapEx synergies for the year. And I think we sort of declared last quarter that we essentially with the agreements we worked out with various suppliers where we're generally hitting the CapEx synergies right in the first year over the course of this year. On your other question on CNS revenue growth, generally, we expect the CNS revenues in total to be growing sequentially every quarter over the rest of the year, and the reason we made our comments on a regional basis because North America was a little different as we stated the underlying business we feel is strong. It has more to do with what happened last year in terms of the Starbucks and ramping up the Starbucks and fellow contracts that we talked about. But generally even in North America, again we should see decent sequential performance over the course of this year. So I think overall, as we progress through the year, as Jeff said, it's a transition year, and so I think the CNS revenue performance should be steady, but we are working on a lot of elements in terms of network platforms, systems platforms, a lot of change going on which we think will position us pretty well for next year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, in terms of integration and what you just talked about with the network, how is the integration I guess of the intelligent network Constellation dynamic capacity going in terms of having that for TWTC customers, and then also I know you talked
componenttext: Yes. First, in terms of integration and what you just talked about with the network, how is the integration I guess of the intelligent network Constellation dynamic capacity going in terms of having that for TWTC customers, and then also I know you talked about a lot about the sales integration, but what about other positions? I mean, we've heard a lot from your competitors saying they're overseeing a lot of people, but that's expected from any merger. So would you say outside of sales again is attrition just kind of your normal? Or are you seeing anything a little different than normal?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take the second part first. On the nonsales attrition, I don't think we're seeing anything outside of what we expected to see. There is always a little bit of attrition as you combine 2 companies together. There are pockets where we have to pay
componenttext:
Sure. I'll take the second part first. On the nonsales attrition, I don't think we're seeing anything outside of what we expected to see. There is always a little bit of attrition as you combine 2 companies together. There are pockets where we have to pay particular attention. It's less to do with the combination of the companies and more to do with some big company opening an office right next door to our location and trying to attract people a way. So I think we're in pretty good shape. There is a natural reduction in force that you have as a result of integrating 2 companies, and to the extent we can, we like to see that happen through attrition as opposed to downsizing. And so we're pretty comfortable with what we're seeing in sales and outside of sales. With respect to the integration of our intelligent networking capabilities, now I talk about building a platform for the future and a platform that allows us to grow well into the future, and that's part of it. That is part of it because we have network elements that we now have our operational systems, operational support systems directly interconnected in a sophisticated way, not just a simple reporting mechanism but an ability to control those network elements. And as we move toward SDN, as we move toward NFV, as we move toward providing faster services to our customer, more seamless services to our customer, those capabilities are critical. And so it is a fundamental component of our platform strategy going forward, and it's the work that I mentioned in the comments that has now begun in earnest. We're looking at our platforms. We have been looking at them. We've looked at our products. We have been looking at our network infrastructure and how do we really tie all of those things together to provide a better customer experience with more sophisticated products than any of our competitors can do. And so it's absolutely important to us, Jim, and a key part of our strategy going forward.
I believe that was the last question, but before we end the call, I'd like to leave you with 3 key takeaways. First, integration is progressing as expected. And while there's a lot of work to do, we are very focused on continuing our solid execution. Second, we are highly intent on driving improved performance in EMEA and are taking the steps we believe will improve our growth in the region. Third, the overall market for our products and services remains strong, and we continue to make disciplined investments that drive profitable growth and improve free cash flow per share. Again, thank you for joining today's call and for your interest in Level 3. Operator, that concludes the call.

I would now like to turn the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Ms. Valerie Finberg. Please go ahead.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice Presi
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'd like to draw your attention to the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com. On this site are the presentation materials that accompany this call, the earnings press release and supplemental financial information.
Comparisons to prior periods are being presented on a pro forma basis, assuming that our acquisition of tw telecom took place on January 1, 2014. In addition, the growth rates disclosed in our presentation and remarks are on a year-over-year basis. Revenue and sales comparisons to prior periods are provided on a constant-currency basis unless otherwise noted.
I need to call your attention to our safe harbor statement that begins on Page 2 of our 1Q '15 earnings presentation.
The presentation and remarks contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may vary significantly from those statements. A discussion of factors that may affect future results can be found in Level 3's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Level 3 had a good start to the year with solid execution and integration and continued focus on profitable growth. Over the past few quarters, we've outlined our 3 key priorities: f
componenttext:
Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Level 3 had a good start to the year with solid execution and integration and continued focus on profitable growth. 
Over the past few quarters, we've outlined our 3 key priorities: first and foremost is the successful integration of Level 3 and tw telecom; second is enabling EMEA to live up to its full potential and deliver the growth we believe we can achieve in that region; third is positioning Level 3 for growth well into the future. 
After Sunit reviews our financial results, I will briefly discuss each of these with most of my comments on the integration of tw telecom. After that, we'll open it up to your questions. 
Sunit, I'll turn the call over to you.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We started 2015 with a good quarter, and we made steady progress on capturing annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. Given the first quarter run rate performance on adjusted EBITDA, we are raising our
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We started 2015 with a good quarter, and we made steady progress on capturing annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. 
Given the first quarter run rate performance on adjusted EBITDA, we are raising our 2015 outlook for adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow. 
I'll start on Slide 3 of our first quarter earnings presentation. Our Core Network Services revenue for the first quarter of 2015 grew 6% year-over-year. Our Enterprise Core Network Services revenue grew 8.1% year-over-year. Including integration-related expenses of $5 million, adjusted EBITDA grew to $635 million. 
We generated free cash flow of $51 million. And since the acquisition closed, we've now achieved $95 million in annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. 
Turning to Slide 4. CNS revenue grew 6% on a constant-currency basis and 3.9% on an as-reported basis. The difference in growth rates is due to the strengthening of the dollar. Outside of the U.S. dollar, which represents 88% of CNS revenue, our top 3 foreign currencies are the British pound, the euro and the Brazilian real, representing 5%, 3% and 3% of CNS revenue, respectively. 
On a revenue-weighted average basis, those 3 currencies declined 13% against the dollar compared to the year-ago quarter and negatively affected our CNS revenue growth by approximately 2% this quarter. 
On a regional basis, North America CNS revenue grew 7%, and Enterprise CNS revenue grew 8.8%. In EMEA, CNS revenue declined 0.8% on a constant-currency basis and 9.2% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 5.7% on a constant-currency basis and declined 2.6% on an as-reported basis. 
U.K. government revenue grew 4.5% in the first quarter, but declined sequentially. For the full year, we expect U.K. government to decline a little less than the 17% decline we saw last year, which is a slight improvement from our previous outlook. U.K. government revenue should continue to decline sequentially the rest of this year. Overall, we still expect U.K. government to keep declining over the next several years. This revenue is now 1.4% of total CNS revenue. 
EMEA, also, CNS revenue declined 11% on a constant-currency basis and 20% on an as-reported basis, driven primarily by industry consolidation and associated customer disconnects as well as our focus on profitable growth. As we mentioned last quarter, we expect better performance and comparisons in wholesale over the remainder of the year. 
In Latin America, CNS revenue grew 6.2% on a constant-currency basis and declined 2.6% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue grew 5.8% on a constant-currency basis and declined 3.3% on an as-reported basis. 
For the first quarter, wholesale CNS revenue grew 7.4% on a constant-currency basis and was flat on an as-reported basis. We expect the Enterprise business to show stronger performance over the balance of the year. 
With respect to Venezuela, we moved to the SICAD 1 rate in the second quarter of last year. Currently, there is a 3-tiered exchange rate mechanism in Venezuela for exchanging bolivars into U.S. dollars. The first is the official exchange rate of VEF 6.3 per U.S. dollar. The second is the SICAD 1 rate that we are using, which is currently at VEF 12 to the dollar, and the third is a new open market foreign exchange system called the Simadi exchange rate that was established in February 2015 and was VEF 193 to the U.S. dollar at March 31, 2015. 
At this time, the majority of our transactions with customers and suppliers are at the SICAD 1 rate. We will continue to closely monitor activity in Venezuela with respect to exchange rates, and we expect the future changes regarding exchange mechanisms could result in a negative effect to our Venezuela operations, profit, cash flows and cash balance. 
At the end of the first quarter, the company's cash balance in Venezuela maintained in bolivars was USD 72 million at the SICAD 1 rate, and we had about $20 million in revenue in the period. 
Wholesale Voice Services and other, or WVS, revenue declined 16% to $126 million in the first quarter of 2014 (sic) [  2015 ]. We expect continued double-digit rates of decline in WVS revenue in 2015. 
Moving to churn. As many of you are aware, Level 3 had a slightly different methodology in calculating churn from tw telecom. As part of our integration activities, we have adopted tw telecom's methodology, which we believe provides a better representation of true churn or disconnects because that definition excluded churn or disconnects that were replaced by upgraded service by the same customer between the same locations. 
On a combined-company basis, CNS revenue churn was 1%. This was a slight improvement from 1.1% also on a combined-company basis from both the first quarter of last year and the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Slide 5 provides an overview of the mix between CNS versus WVS revenue and CNS revenue on a geographic and customer basis. 
Turning to Slide 6 and revenue results by product group, which I'd like to note are shown on an as-reported basis. Because currency had a larger effect on our revenue this quarter, we also noted these results on a constant-currency basis. 
The company's growth continues to be driven by our IP and data services, which grew 9%. Within that group, CDN revenue grew 2.4%. We expect CDN performance to improve later in the year as we deploy more capacity. 
Transport and fiber grew 5.4%. Within transport and fiber, dark fiber grew 3.2%. Voice services grew 0.6%, and colocation and data center services grew 3.8%. 
Regarding pricing, as we've said for several quarters, we've seen little change in the pricing environment. We remain disciplined across our product portfolio and service regions in driving profitable growth. 
Turning to Slide 7. Network access margin expanded to 64.8%, compared to 64% in the first quarter 2014. The improvement in network access margin was driven by integration-related network synergies with continued high-margin CNS revenue growth and low-margin WVS revenue declines. 
Network-related expenses, excluding noncash compensation, were $351 million for the first quarter of 2015, compared to $347 million in the first quarter of 2014. SG&A, excluding noncash compensation expenses and integration-related expenses, for the first quarter was $339 million. This compares to $342 million for the first quarter of 2014. 
Turning to Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA, including integration-related expenses, was $635 million for the first quarter of 2015. Excluding integration-related expenses of $5 million, adjusted EBITDA was $640 million. This compares to $625 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 and $593 million for the first quarter of 2014. The improvement in adjusted EBITDA was primarily driven by good progress in capturing operating expense synergies. 
Adjusted EBITDA margin, including acquisition-related expenses, improved to 30.9%, compared to 29.6% for the first quarter of 2014. 
Moving to synergies. Since the acquisition closed, we achieved approximately $95 million of annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies with $14 million of network access cost synergies and $81 million of operating expense synergies. We've clearly made good progress capturing OpEx synergies thus far. For the remainder of the year, we expect to make more progress capturing network access-related synergies. 
On Slide 9, capital expenditures were $254 million in the first quarter of 2015, representing 12% of total revenue. For the full year 2015, we continue to expect capital expenditures of approximately 15% of total revenue. 
The company generated free cash flow of $51 million in the quarter. Cash flow saw a benefit this quarter, driven by timing of both capital expenditures and approximately $20 million in net cash interest expense that we had expected to incur in the first quarter but was pushed to the second quarter since we redeemed debt that we had refinanced out to April 1 in the second quarter versus our expectation of the first quarter. As of March 31, 2015, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $560 million pro forma for the redemption of the 9 3/8% senior notes on April 1, 2015. 
Turning to Slide 10. As noted in our earnings release, we completed several capital markets transactions over the past few months as we opportunistically managed the balance sheet. Related to those transactions, we expect to incur a $136 million noncash charge for the extinguishment of debt in the second quarter. These 2015 refinancing transactions, in total, saved us about $64 million in annualized cash interest expense. 
We exited the quarter with our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio at 4.2x on a pro forma basis. This compares to 4.4x at the end of last quarter. We remain focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 5x, driven by growth in adjusted EBITDA. Our average interest rate on our debt is now 5.3%, compared to 6.8% a year ago for Level 3 standalone. 
Moving on to our outlook for the year on Slide 11. Based on first quarter performance, synergy attainment and continued focus on profitable growth, we are updating our outlook for the full year 2015. 
We now expect adjusted EBITDA growth of 14% to 17% for the full year 2015, compared to our previous outlook of 12% to 16%. We are also raising our full year 2015 free cash flow outlook to $600 million to $650 million, which compares to our previous outlook of $550 million to $600 million. 
Additionally, based on our recent capital markets activity, we now expect $660 million in GAAP interest expense and $645 million on net cash interest expense, compared to our previous guidance of $680 million and $640 million, respectively. All other guidance measures remain unchanged and are listed here on this slide. 
Last quarter, in my remarks on the conference call, we had provided our outlook for 2015 CNS constant-currency revenue growth performance on a regional basis compared to what we saw in 2014. That outlook remains intact. 
For North America, we expect CNS revenue growth to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For Latin America, we expect comparable performance to the 8.5% growth we saw in 2014. For EMEA, we expect a decline that will be smaller than the 2.2% decline we saw in 2014. 
In summary, we had a good start to the year and remain confident in our financial performance for the remainder of the year. We feel good about the progress we are making in achieving the synergies as we integrate tw telecom. We look forward to reporting our progress next quarter. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sunit. Since the acquisition of tw telecom, we've talked about 2015 as a transition year for Level 3. As I look back on the 6 months since the acquisition closed, I'm pleased with how much we've accomplished and the lack of surprises. To be c
componenttext:
Thank you, Sunit. Since the acquisition of tw telecom, we've talked about 2015 as a transition year for Level 3. As I look back on the 6 months since the acquisition closed, I'm pleased with how much we've accomplished and the lack of surprises. 
To be clear, no surprises is a good thing. The customer experience tw telecom provided is as good as we expected. Our combined portfolio of products and services address the ever-changing challenges our enterprise customers face and are well received in the market. 
The strength of the combined network provides a solid foundation for those products and services. And given the lack of customer overlap between the companies, there's been very little revenue loss driven by the need for diversity. 
Operationally, we've seen very few surprises as well. Maintaining the sales momentum we experienced pre-close has been a key focus area. While sales were a little light at the end of the fourth quarter and the beginning of the first quarter, overall, we've been pleased with the results, and March was a very good sales month. In spite of all the changes and all of the integration efforts, sales in the first quarter of 2015 improved over the same period last year. 
Service delivery intervals are always critical indicators of our integration efforts. Our North America service delivery team has done a very good job and maintained our installation performance. 
Looking at the acquisition synergies, we are ahead of schedule and are determined to capture synergies while also maintaining the customer experience. From a platform perspective, we have interconnected the networks, we've standardized our go-forward architectures globally and have begun implementing a unified network design. And lastly, the systems integration and development work has begun in earnest, and we are building a company-wide platform for growth well into the future. 
At the heart of our integration plans has been a focus on our people. Building one company culture is important to our success and, as a result, it receives a lot of our attention. Even prior to the close, we determined the go-forward organization structure and the leadership team and communicated those decisions to employees clearly and early. 
Shortly after close, we standardized our benefits for all of our North America employees. In early February, we began integrating the sales organization, solidifying the General Manager environment and assigning the go-forward accounts to all sales people. At that same time, we established our global account management team to provide a deeper focus on major customers doing business across multiple region. 
At the beginning of this month, we rolled out a single customer relationship management, or CRM, system across North America and EMEA, and have implemented a unified sales compensation structure in North America. This is a lot of change for a sales force. 
While there have certainly been issues along the way, and it is way too early to declare success, leading indicators are important. Our sales team's confidence in the combined product and service portfolio remain strong. Voluntary sales force churn is consistent with premerger levels. The quality of the sales funnel continues to improve, and our first quarter sales results improved over the same period last year. 
I've discussed our key priority of positioning Level 3 for future growth. Many of the integration initiatives I've mentioned are really the foundation of the global company we are building. Whether in our product portfolio, our operational capabilities or our platforms, we're building Level 3 as a global solution for our customers' networking needs. 
While we're focused on integration, we have not lost sight of the need for continual innovation. As an example, we announced the launch of our expanded DDoS platform this quarter. Our customers have very real and strategic security challenges, and they look to Level 3 to safeguard their networks and protect their capabilities. Level 3's unique position in the industry and our ability to see a comprehensive view of the threat landscape allows us to work with enterprises to effectively protect their networks. 
Turning to EMEA. We continue to make changes in management, improve our sales discipline, enhance our operational performance and focus our investments on profitable growth opportunities. I believe we're on the right path for improved performance, but it's still early in the process. We will share our progress in future calls. 
Sunit provided a commentary on our financial performance in Latin America, but I wanted to add a little bit. I spent time in LatAm last month, and I wanted you to know we have an excellent team there. They continue to be optimistic about our opportunity, and despite the macro pressures in those countries, the dynamics that drive our business in the region, dynamics like bandwidth growth, migration to cloud services and the evolution to new IP-based technologies, all of those dynamics remain intact in the region. 
Across our business, customers tell us they appreciate our intimate knowledge of their communications challenges, our ability to design solutions to meet their needs and the personal touch they see from our teams, all of these factors are helping to position Level 3 as the communications provider of choice. 
With that, we'll open it up for your questions. Operator, would you explain the process?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, a couple of questions. First, maybe you could just talk a little bit about the strength in the North American enterprise, what's driving the strength there? It seems as though on a constant-currency basis, sir -- well, it's North America, but you st
componenttext: Guys, a couple of questions. First, maybe you could just talk a little bit about the strength in the North American enterprise, what's driving the strength there? It seems as though on a constant-currency basis, sir -- well, it's North America, but you started the year at a faster growth rate than what your full year guidance would imply. And then second, Jeff, I appreciate your comments on LatAm. Maybe just talk a little bit about what contributed to the little bit slower start than what you might have been expecting for the full year there. And Sunit made a comment that he expected enterprise to get stronger in LatAm throughout the year, just talk about what the drivers are of that -- in the region.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the LatAm question first. So I think, in LatAm, we had, had a very strong sales quarter in the first quarter. And looking at the backlog they have and the strength they've seen in the sales in the first quarter and the funnel, we see the Enterpr
componenttext: I'll take the LatAm question first. So I think, in LatAm, we had, had a very strong sales quarter in the first quarter. And looking at the backlog they have and the strength they've seen in the sales in the first quarter and the funnel, we see the Enterprise business growth improving over the balance of the year. They've also had quite a bit of strength in the wholesale segment, and we think some of that will continue for the rest of the year. So when you put both of those together, we think that you'll see better performance here. I think on the North American Enterprise business, as Jeff pointed out, we started off with a good sales quarter, and that helped. But on the revenue performance, as we pointed out last quarter, remember that last year, as we said 3 months ago, we were turning up a lot of Starbucks revenue and we had some Fed contracts that we won in 2013 that we were turning up in '14, so we don't have that -- the benefit of those 2 things this year. But aside from those 2 things, I think the tone in the business across all segments, including federal, is pretty good. Jeff, if you're going to add anything to that?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. I think Sunit's last statement is the one that I'll key on. The tone in the business is pretty good across our business. If you look at LatAm, the tone in the business, the drivers of our growth in the region, those are all prett
componenttext: No, I think that's right. I think Sunit's last statement is the one that I'll key on. The tone in the business is pretty good across our business. If you look at LatAm, the tone in the business, the drivers of our growth in the region, those are all pretty strong and pretty solid. The same is true in North America.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on that on the North American side. You've definitely talked about Starbucks and the government, though I think some government stuff that you won in 2014. Is there any sense for how we should be thinking about the timing of when
componenttext: If I could just follow up on that on the North American side. You've definitely talked about Starbucks and the government, though I think some government stuff that you won in 2014. Is there any sense for how we should be thinking about the timing of when those came in '14 so we can think about the anniversary of those and how that might impact growth on a go-forward basis?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well so, I mean, as I mentioned in my comments, we expect -- and as we said last quarter, we expect the North American business to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For this quarter, we were close to 6%, so obvi
componenttext: Well so, I mean, as I mentioned in my comments, we expect -- and as we said last quarter, we expect the North American business to be a little softer than the 6.8% growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014. For this quarter, we were close to 6%, so obviously, the year-over-year comparison are softening. I'll see -- I think you'll see that continue for a little bit this year. And again, it's all tied into when last year -- it's more last year story than this year's in that we were turning up those contracts that we won in earlier years in 2014. And now that they are more largely turned up, that's the impact you're seeing. But other than that, generally, the business across the board, tone looks good.

componenttext: Sunit, when I saw you a couple of months ago, you were thinking about the potential for sales force disruption once you paid in your bonuses. What did you see as that sort of March and April came through?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jeff answer that question. The only thing I would say, as we've talked about, we did look across the sales force at the bottom performance, and so we had some reductions, which we thought were helpful. But overall, I'll let Jeff talk about sales
componenttext: I'll let Jeff answer that question. The only thing I would say, as we've talked about, we did look across the sales force at the bottom performance, and so we had some reductions, which we thought were helpful. But overall, I'll let Jeff talk about sales force.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look at our sales force, we are down from where we were in the fourth quarter. Almost all of that was planned on our part, as Sunit mentioned, that we look at the bottom percentage of our sales force and continually manage low-performing peop
componenttext: Sure. If you look at our sales force, we are down from where we were in the fourth quarter. Almost all of that was planned on our part, as Sunit mentioned, that we look at the bottom percentage of our sales force and continually manage low-performing people either to make them better or move them out of the business. But we also look at the skill set we need and the competency we need to fit our go-to-market strategy. And so we're continually evolving, making sure that each of our various sales channels have the right people, are of the right size to match the opportunity that's in front of them. So we'll continue to manage that. We haven't seen, yet, involuntary -- or, excuse me, voluntary sales attrition outside of what we saw prior to the close of the merger. So we're feeling pretty good about that. But we've made a lot of change to the sales organization, and a lot of that change is just now implementing. And so, in my comments, I said it's too early to declare success, but we are paying very close attention. Our sales team knows how critical they are. And rather than focusing on the number of sales people we have in our sales channels, we focus on the productivity of those sales channels, the overall output of those. And we know that the more productive we can make our sales people, the happier they are, the more they stay with us, the better we grow as a business. And so we're focused on making each and every sales person very productive and making sure that we give them the best place to work in the industry.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good to see the progress on the synergy realization. Is this primarily a timing thing? Or do you think there might be ability to get upside? Are you seeing some opportunities that perhaps you haven't put in your $200 million guidance? And I know all
componenttext: Yes. Good to see the progress on the synergy realization. Is this primarily a timing thing? Or do you think there might be ability to get upside? Are you seeing some opportunities that perhaps you haven't put in your $200 million guidance? And I know all the guidance is really on the cost and CapEx side. What about revenue synergies? Have you seen any progress on trying to cross-sell products into each customer set?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of the question. Jeff can talk about the revenue synergies part. So on the cost side, I think it's timing mostly, Simon. I don't think we see more synergies per se at this point. I think what happened is all our various organizati
componenttext: I'll take the first part of the question. Jeff can talk about the revenue synergies part. So on the cost side, I think it's timing mostly, Simon. I don't think we see more synergies per se at this point. I think what happened is all our various organizations or functions within the company moved to, and felt confident in moving, a little earlier on the cost reductions. One part being the sales side, as Jeff pointed out, the other -- and we haven't seen any loss in sales production there as we pointed out. And the second side and all the other functions, just people taking our cost out earlier. So I'd say it's timing on the OpEx side. We expect more progress on the NetEx side. So at this point, we don't see more synergies per se. I think we've just had a strong start and, obviously, that's in the run rate, which is benefiting overall EBITDA.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you look at revenue synergies, Simon, we've described and view 2015 as a transition year, and we are focused on making sure that we integrated the 2 companies well, that we build the platform for our future success, that we do the basics that we need t
componenttext: If you look at revenue synergies, Simon, we've described and view 2015 as a transition year, and we are focused on making sure that we integrated the 2 companies well, that we build the platform for our future success, that we do the basics that we need to be doing today to position Level 3 for growth well into the future. That cross-selling and upselling is part of that. And as you guys know, most of our new sales come from existing customers, and so we will continue to focus on cross-sell and upsell opportunities but believe that 2015 is a transition year, where we are putting our sales force through an enormous amount of change and our customers through a fair amount of change as well. And so we are really focused on making sure that we make that transition well and that we work closely with our customers to satisfy their needs on a daily basis.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Two, if I may. First off, I just wanted to get the company's sense on comfort around doing additional M&A, particularly outside the United States as it seems like you're doing well with the tw telecom transaction and senior management's ability to
componenttext: Great. Two, if I may. First off, I just wanted to get the company's sense on comfort around doing additional M&A, particularly outside the United States as it seems like you're doing well with the tw telecom transaction and senior management's ability to focus on something like that. And then the second question, you did get refi-ed a little bit faster this year than we had anticipated. Can you just remind us what's still out there that could potentially be called in 2015 and even 2016?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question and Jeff can answer the first one. So on the debt refi, I think you're right, we moved quickly to take advantage of the debt markets. We currently do not have any fixed-rate debt or bounds that are callable until next year. S
componenttext: I'll take the second question and Jeff can answer the first one. So on the debt refi, I think you're right, we moved quickly to take advantage of the debt markets. We currently do not have any fixed-rate debt or bounds that are callable until next year. So I think that, at least on the bond side, not much to do this year. And then on the bank side, which is our floating-rate debt, we continue to look at that to see if there might be opportunities there, but I think we're generally done with respect to bond refinancing for this year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with respect to M&A, M&A is part of our strategy. We look at gaps in our capabilities. We look gaps in our network. We look at opportunities to add customers and view M&A as a mechanism to do all of those things. And so we'll continue to focus on M&A.
componenttext: And with respect to M&A, M&A is part of our strategy. We look at gaps in our capabilities. We look gaps in our network. We look at opportunities to add customers and view M&A as a mechanism to do all of those things. And so we'll continue to focus on M&A. It's opportunistic by the very nature of it. Outside the U.S., as you mentioned, Colby, there's probably more in our targets than maybe inside the U.S., given that we've just done the tw telecom acquisition. The real comment I want to leave, though, in your mind about M&A is we will not do anything from an M&A perspective that causes us to damage our integration with tw telecom. That is the highest priority for us as a business. I think you're right in saying that the North America team, management team is focused well on that, and so if we were to do something outside of North America, I think that it creates less of a distraction, but we will not do anything, from an M&A perspective, that harms our ability to integrate tw telecom effectively.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Actually I had 2. First, CapEx was still low this quarter. I was wondering if we should expect a ramp over the next 3 quarters to get up to your 15% guidance range or if it's possible that, during the year, it might come in a bit right? And second,
componenttext: Okay. Actually I had 2. First, CapEx was still low this quarter. I was wondering if we should expect a ramp over the next 3 quarters to get up to your 15% guidance range or if it's possible that, during the year, it might come in a bit right? And second, I think there are 2 new transatlantic systems that are supposed to be coming online this year. It's been a long time since any of your transatlantic systems have been built. So I was wondering if you could talk a bit about whether or not you think these are -- just what are you thinking about your transatlantic business. Maybe talk a bit more generally about those assets, what's their revenue contribution in maybe the overall business and their importance in terms of driving related sales.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start, and then Sunit probably has some that he wants to add to it. First of all, on the CapEx, our guidance, we gave guidance of 15% of revenue. We're still comfortable with that. CapEx spending is lumpy. If you look at the first quarter, it'
componenttext: Yes, let me start, and then Sunit probably has some that he wants to add to it. First of all, on the CapEx, our guidance, we gave guidance of 15% of revenue. We're still comfortable with that. CapEx spending is lumpy. If you look at the first quarter, it's usually a little lighter than the rest of the year. And so we're still very comfortable with our 15% guidance as a percentage of revenue. With respect to transatlantic, there are new cables coming online over the next couple of years. That's not only true in transatlantic, that's true in South America and other places. And we view those assets, the assets that we have as a competitive strategic advantage in our ability to operate. Having said that, we're always looking at ways to lower our cost for the next bit of capacity, and we'll work with those systems to see how it makes sense for Level 3 to take advantage of what's coming online. But those assets that we have, the subsea assets, are still an advantage for Level 3 and something that we continue to work hard to monetize effectively. Sunit?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just two quick questions. Just curious, how are you viewing the market outlook post the breakup of the Comcast, Time Warner Cable? Obviously, it would have been a more formidable competitor in the marketplace. Did that change your outlook? And see
componenttext: Great. Just two quick questions. Just curious, how are you viewing the market outlook post the breakup of the Comcast, Time Warner Cable? Obviously, it would have been a more formidable competitor in the marketplace. Did that change your outlook? And see -- do you see opportunities there? And then, are there any sort of noncore businesses that you might monetize? You've done a very good job at refinancing and using your cash for those purposes. Anything else you might streamline the business with jettison to get more focused on the core business and possibly delever some more.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. With respect to the first comment on -- the first question on Time Warner Cable and Comcast, we don't have any specific comments on that deal, don't really want to -- don't really think we changed our outlook for the year based on whether that deal w
componenttext: Yes. With respect to the first comment on -- the first question on Time Warner Cable and Comcast, we don't have any specific comments on that deal, don't really want to -- don't really think we changed our outlook for the year based on whether that deal went through or not. Both companies are very good customers of ours. Both companies we've worked very closely with to continue to evolve the industry and look forward to working with them in the future. Now with respect to noncore assets, nothing in particular. We look at all of our business and say, "How do we drive profitable growth, and how do we drive free cash flow on a per-share basis?" And so we will continue to look at things as if they're noncore assets, we will continue to look at interest expenses. We'll continue to look at all of the different things in our business that we think are levers to drive improving free cash flow per share.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a bit more about the competitive environment and what you're seeing in terms of other fiber providers and their ability to compete against you. Also, within that context, maybe talk a little bit about the products within
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a bit more about the competitive environment and what you're seeing in terms of other fiber providers and their ability to compete against you. Also, within that context, maybe talk a little bit about the products within enterprise and what's going really well with those products, and were there any products that you have in that portfolio that might may actually be holding back the performance in revenue.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Sunit and I both have a lot to comment on this topic. From a competitive environment perspective, we're in a very competitive industry, and there are lots of companies that sell the types of products and services that we sell. And so we are v
componenttext: Yes. I think Sunit and I both have a lot to comment on this topic. From a competitive environment perspective, we're in a very competitive industry, and there are lots of companies that sell the types of products and services that we sell. And so we are very accustomed to competing in a competitive industry with -- and competing on the strength of our products and the strength of our customer experience. If you look at our products from a competitive point of view, I think that is one of our big strengths. We have a variety of platforms and technologies to deliver for the networking needs of our customers. If you only have dark fiber, then everything that you sell looks like a dark fiber solution. If you only have IP, then everything looks like an IP solution. If you only have CDN everything looks like a CDN solution. For Level 3, we have all of those things. We have those -- that robust set of products where we can look at a customer's traffic and pick not only the right platform for that customer. But the right platform for some of that customers traffic may not be the right solution for all of it, and so we can bring to those customers the variety of products. And then after we've done that, we can wrap around those capabilities our security services and our DDoS protection. We can wrap around our managed services and professional services. And so we think we're in a very competitive -- a good, competitive position because of the strength of our products, the breadth of our network, the sophistication of our network and ultimately driven by our employees, delivery of a great customer experience for our customers.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't have anything to add. I think the biggest thing is that given our network reach and the capillarity we have and the broad portfolio of services we have is a big advantage for us, vis-a-vis others.
componenttext: No, I don't have anything to add. I think the biggest thing is that given our network reach and the capillarity we have and the broad portfolio of services we have is a big advantage for us, vis-a-vis others.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, with your profitable growth focus and churn being down to 1%, are there any areas you think you can maybe actually start to raise prices now more than we've seen in the last couple of years? And then secondly, on CapEx, is there any shift in focus o
componenttext: Jeff, with your profitable growth focus and churn being down to 1%, are there any areas you think you can maybe actually start to raise prices now more than we've seen in the last couple of years? And then secondly, on CapEx, is there any shift in focus on CapEx? I know Verizon announced some SDN yesterday, but maybe just broadly speaking, areas where you maybe see where you're going to spend more in the future.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. From a raising-prices perspective, we look at our pricing strategically, whether it's raising prices or lowering prices. We look at each product. We look at each geography. We look at each customer segment, and we try and match our pricing to the ma
componenttext: Sure. From a raising-prices perspective, we look at our pricing strategically, whether it's raising prices or lowering prices. We look at each product. We look at each geography. We look at each customer segment, and we try and match our pricing to the market and make sure that we're competitive in that market. And so I can't give you any specific products that we're planning on raising prices on, but we do look at pricing as one of the levers that we have to drive profitable growth, and we have done that in the past, and we'll continue to do that in the future. With respect to our CapEx strategy, I think you mentioned SDN, software-defined networking, and network function virtualization, NFV. Those are things that are very real in the Level 3 network, and we are investing in all of those things. We believe very strongly that our customers want to be able to dynamically insert networking capabilities on the fly. If you look at the tw telecom Constellation family of products and capabilities, we are incorporating that dynamic bandwidth capacity in the go-forward product that we have out for our customers. That is whether you're inserting capacity on demand or you're inserting our DDoS scrubbing network and our DDoS protection network on demand for customers' traffic or your inserting a network firewall, those are the types of SDN, NFV capabilities that we are building into our platform, and it's part of our CapEx program and has been part of our CapEx program.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I have 2 quick ones here. I appreciate the commentary about the direction of revenue growth, the different business segments that you gave. Maybe if you could synthesize that and help us think about the CNS run rate revenue growth towards the end of
componenttext: Yes. I have 2 quick ones here. I appreciate the commentary about the direction of revenue growth, the different business segments that you gave. Maybe if you could synthesize that and help us think about the CNS run rate revenue growth towards the end of the year, given those factors you talked about. And then, second, great job on the synergies on the EBITDA side. You also guided for $40 million CapEx savings when you announced the deal. I just wanted to review, I guess, how you got to that number whether or not that was just eliminating duplicative spending, if that was a zero-based budgeting approach, just wanted to get a better sense there.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So on the CapEx side, we looked at how much both companies were spending with various kinds of suppliers, whether it was transport gear, voice gear, CDN gear, IP. And it was based upon what we think we could get by just leveraging our bigger pu
componenttext: All right. So on the CapEx side, we looked at how much both companies were spending with various kinds of suppliers, whether it was transport gear, voice gear, CDN gear, IP. And it was based upon what we think we could get by just leveraging our bigger purchasing power. So I think, and I think we mentioned this last call that essentially, during the integration planning period and right after closing, we had agreements with most of our suppliers to essentially lock in the CapEx synergies for the year. And I think we sort of declared with you on that last call that we essentially, with the agreements we worked out with various suppliers, we're generally hitting the CapEx synergies right in the first year over the course of this year. On your other question on CNS revenue growth, generally, we expect the CNS revenues, in total, to be growing sequentially every quarter over the rest of the year. And the reason we made our comments on a regional base is because North America was a little different as we stated. The underlying business we feel is strong. It has more to do with what happened last year in terms of the Starbucks and ramping up the Starbucks and federal contracts that we talked about. But generally, even in North America, we should see decent sequential performance over the course of this year. So I think, overall, as we progress through the year, as Jeff said, it's a transition year, and so I think the CNS revenue performance should be steady, but we are working on a lot of elements in terms of network platforms, systems platforms, a lot of change going on, which we think will position us pretty well for next year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, in terms of integration and what you just talked about with the network, how is the integration, I guess, of the intelligent network, Constellation Dynamic Capacity, going in terms of having that for TWTC customers, and then also I know you ta
componenttext: Yes. First, in terms of integration and what you just talked about with the network, how is the integration, I guess, of the intelligent network, Constellation Dynamic Capacity, going in terms of having that for TWTC customers, and then also I know you talked about a lot about the sales integration, but what about other positions? I mean, we've heard a lot from your competitors saying, "We're seeing a lot of people coming." But that's expected from any merger. So would you say, outside of sales, again, is attrition just kind of your normal? Or are you seeing anything a little different than normal?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take the second part first. On the nonsales attrition, I don't think we're seeing anything outside of what we expected to see. There is always a little bit of attrition as you combine 2 companies together. There are pockets where we have to pay
componenttext:
Sure. I'll take the second part first. On the nonsales attrition, I don't think we're seeing anything outside of what we expected to see. There is always a little bit of attrition as you combine 2 companies together. There are pockets where we have to pay particular attention. It's less to do with the combination of the companies and more to do with some big company opening an office right next door to our location and trying to attract people away. So I think we're in pretty good shape. There is a natural reduction in force that you have as a result of integrating 2 companies, and to the extent we can, we like to see that happen through attrition as opposed to downsizing. And so we're pretty comfortable with what we're seeing in sales and outside of sales. With respect to the integration of our intelligent networking capabilities, now I talk about building a platform for the future and a platform that allows us to grow well into the future, and that's part of it. That is part of it because we have network elements that we now have our operational systems -- operational support systems directly interconnected in a sophisticated way, not just a simple reporting mechanism but an ability to control those network elements. And as we move toward SDN, as we move toward NFV, as we move toward providing faster services to our customer, more seamless services to our customers, those capabilities are critical. And so it is a fundamental component of our platform strategy, going forward. And it's the work that I mentioned in the comments that has now begun in earnest. We're looking at our platforms. We have been looking at them. We've looked at our products. We have been looking at our network infrastructure. And how do we really tie all of those things together to provide a better customer experience with more sophisticated products than any of our competitors can do. And so it's absolutely important to us, Jim, and a key part of our strategy, going forward.
I believe that was the last question, but before we end the call, I'd like to leave you with 3 key takeaways. First, integration is progressing as expected. And while there's a lot of work to do, we are very focused on continuing our solid execution. Second, we are highly intent on driving improved performance in EMEA and are taking the steps we believe will improve our growth in the region. Third, the overall market for our products and services remains strong, and we continue to make disciplined investments that drive profitable growth and improve free cash flow per share. 
Again, thank you for joining today's call and for your interest in Level 3. Operator, that concludes the call.
