headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think in EMEA as we said, yes, I think we said at the beginning of the year that declined 2.2% and we expect to do a little better than that kind of decline this year. So, so far, they're holding in. And then LatAm is a little weaker, as we ment
componenttext: Yes. So I think in EMEA as we said, yes, I think we said at the beginning of the year that declined 2.2% and we expect to do a little better than that kind of decline this year. So, so far, they're holding in. And then LatAm is a little weaker, as we mentioned, given the changes you've seen in the commodity markets. So oil prices, metals and the overall macroeconomic situation there. We have seen -- the growth has been a little lower than we thought and we'll see how it goes for the rest of the year. So we've seen a little more weakness in LatAm. EMEA is performing as we outlined and as we've been seeing in the last couple of years -- last couple of quarters, I'm sorry.

componenttextpreview: Wanted to go back to North America. So you mentioned in your response, I guess, to Simon's question, that sales were up on a year-over-year basis. I was wondering if you could talk about what the trend was quarter-over-quarter and I guess that was the one
componenttext: Wanted to go back to North America. So you mentioned in your response, I guess, to Simon's question, that sales were up on a year-over-year basis. I was wondering if you could talk about what the trend was quarter-over-quarter and I guess that was the one area, at least in our model, where we saw weakness relative to expectation. Curious, if that's simply a result of that salesforce integration in the first quarter and book-to-bill and how that impacted the second quarter? And if the sales are starting to improve, if we could start to see improvement in the back half of this year. And then my second question is on EBITDA. If you simply annualize the EBITDA that you just recorded in the second quarter, you'd effectively be at 17% year-over-year, which would be at the high end of year guidance. Is that meant to imply that we could be seeing flat EBITDA or even down EBITDA in the back half of the year or are you simply being conservative with your guidance?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, going to your question. So I assume you're talking about sales, not revenues. So our sales bookings were up sequentially and year-over-year. As far as the revenue goes, as we've been saying for 2 quarters now, that we're going to see a little softer p
componenttext: So, going to your question. So I assume you're talking about sales, not revenues. So our sales bookings were up sequentially and year-over-year. As far as the revenue goes, as we've been saying for 2 quarters now, that we're going to see a little softer performance over the balance of the year in North America because of the Starbucks and the fellow contracts that Starbucks revenue was ramping up this last year and some into the beginning of the year, and then we had some federal contracts that peeled off, that we talked about. So the performance is in line with what we -- with respect to North America. Enterprise is in line with what we've talked about. And so we're just seeing that, there's nothing that has changed fundamentally. I think the sales momentum is pretty good given the size of the combination of the 2 companies coming together, bringing them together in North America, and install the tools are holding up as you would expect for the kind of products and services we're selling. So the revenue performance again, we've been saying this for 2 quarters and you're just seeing that play out, we'll see that play out for the rest of the year as we talked about previously.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just reiterate what Sunit said. Our revenue sales -- our sales continue to improve sequentially and year-over-year. And given the number of changes that I've mentioned that we did in the first quarter, we're pretty pleased that. Now we're never
componenttext: Yes, I'll just reiterate what Sunit said. Our revenue sales -- our sales continue to improve sequentially and year-over-year. And given the number of changes that I've mentioned that we did in the first quarter, we're pretty pleased that. Now we're never satisfied. We'll continue to focus driving better sales performance. But it is a transition year. We've made massive changes in the first quarter to our sales organization, our product portfolio, all of the things that come with putting 2 large companies together. And on a year-over-year basis, our second quarter sales results were better. So we're overall please. But again, not satisfied with where we are yet.

Most of the other carriers seemed to be losing revenues and you seem to be gaining the margins, incrementally better there on the wholesale now.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the second question, first, which is on the wholesale side, I think you heard us say for quite a number of years that in general, for a longer period of time, we had expect wholesale to be flat to slightly down. And now we've benefited last c
componenttext: So I'll take the second question, first, which is on the wholesale side, I think you heard us say for quite a number of years that in general, for a longer period of time, we had expect wholesale to be flat to slightly down. And now we've benefited last couple of quarters, at least in North America, with some settlements, particularly in this past quarter. Our LatAm business is doing well because they're geared more towards consumer media and some of their wholesale customers. So I don't think anything's changed that for us. For us, the business continues to be a good profitable business for us, the margins in our wholesale business are comparable to what we've -- for our Enterprise business, we're happy with our profitability. In terms of the trends for the balance of the year, I mean, I think that -- there are 2 ways I'll look at it. One is with respect to our overall enterprise revenue, we do expect better sequential comparisons for the balance of the year. And we expect that the year-over-year enterprise trends will be consistent with what we've seen this quarter overall, specifically with respect to North America I think we'll see on the margin, slight improvement, but consistent with what we reported this quarter. So in answer to your question, yes. I mean the sales bookings should continue to benefit us. The year-over-year comparisons can get a little clouded by onetime things we had last year. As I mentioned, Starbucks and the federal contracts, which is why I mentioned the sequential point. So I think overall, given the size of the acquisition that we did and all of the changes we have going on, we're pretty -- we think performance is holding up as we expected in North America.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jeffries.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jeffries.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just one clarification on Phil's question earlier on Latin America. Jeff, you highlighted a little bit in your comments, and Sunit talked about the weakening macro there. But I just want to confirm that you still comfortable with the guidance tha
componenttext: I guess, just one clarification on Phil's question earlier on Latin America. Jeff, you highlighted a little bit in your comments, and Sunit talked about the weakening macro there. But I just want to confirm that you still comfortable with the guidance that you have for Latin America, particularly assuming that there's no sort of inflection on -- to the better -- on the macro, in the back half of the year, if you're still comfortable there. And then I guess, secondly, just the typical quarterly question around M&A, Jeff. You've obviously, focused a lot on integration. I think you've made a lot of progress on the sales force, still have more work to go. But as you start to think about inorganic opportunities, particularly with your leverage here at 4.1 and likely decline, and given EBITDA growth, what you're seeing out in the marketplace? And what you're appetite is, perhaps to do something outside of North America?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll cover the LatAm question first. So I think, again as I said, we've seen a little softer performance than we expected in the first half of the year. As we look at the balance of the year, overall in LatAm, we think we'll see stronger performance from
componenttext: I'll cover the LatAm question first. So I think, again as I said, we've seen a little softer performance than we expected in the first half of the year. As we look at the balance of the year, overall in LatAm, we think we'll see stronger performance from the Enterprise side and generally, better performance in the second half of the year. I think third quarter might be comparable to what we saw in the second quarter, it should pick up in the fourth quarter. So overall, running may be 1% or so, softer than what we outlined at the beginning of the year. Now obviously, we'll know more with every passing quarter, but that's what we currently released.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Scott, with respect to M&A, we're an inquisitive company and its part of our strategy to continue to acquire. We announced the Black Lotus transaction. Again, that one is very small, but it brought a capability that we wanted to have and now our produ
componenttext: And Scott, with respect to M&A, we're an inquisitive company and its part of our strategy to continue to acquire. We announced the Black Lotus transaction. Again, that one is very small, but it brought a capability that we wanted to have and now our product portfolio and the capability we want to have on our team. So we'll continue to look at M&A from a variety of different approaches. We believe in Europe and Latin America, we want to continue to grow scale. And so those are some drivers to look at things, internationally. Having said that, our focus is on integrating tw telecom and Level 3. And we're going to make sure that, that's the highest priority that we have as a business that we integrated effectively. It has global ramifications as we standardized our product set, as we standardize our network and as we standardize our system across the globe, we want to continue to drive that capability and take advantage of the acquisition we did with tw telecom. And so that remains our primarily focused, but we are an acquiring company, an inquisitive company, and we'll continue to look at opportunities to add scale or capabilities that we need, regardless of the region.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just back on the North American wholesale, so if you strip out a settlement this quarter, implies about I guess, $440 million x that, your commentary suggests maybe more pressure off the quarter, more sequential pressure. So how much of that is due to who
componenttext: Just back on the North American wholesale, so if you strip out a settlement this quarter, implies about I guess, $440 million x that, your commentary suggests maybe more pressure off the quarter, more sequential pressure. So how much of that is due to wholesale carrier grooming? Maybe versus other factors in there?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think again, consolidation has been the theme of the wholesale business for a long time, which is why we always said longer term, we expect wholesale to be flat to down, generally. And I think it's because our -- what we see in the quarter
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think again, consolidation has been the theme of the wholesale business for a long time, which is why we always said longer term, we expect wholesale to be flat to down, generally. And I think it's because our -- what we see in the quarter is consistent with that. Now in any given quarter, you might have some things moving around, but when I look at things on an overall year-over-year basis, I think it's consistent. Having said that, I think we still expect wholesale to be growing year-over-year, giving some of the benefits that we had [indiscernible] in North America and overall.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the free cash flow guidance for the year, I'm just curious what kind of typical help you will get in the second half of the year from working capital?
componenttext: And then on the free cash flow guidance for the year, I'm just curious what kind of typical help you will get in the second half of the year from working capital?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we have in the first half of the year, we have our annual bonus payments that happened in the first half of the year. We have a lot of prepaid payments for maintenance software that happened at the beginning of the year. So we see a favorable bene
componenttext: Yes, so we have in the first half of the year, we have our annual bonus payments that happened in the first half of the year. We have a lot of prepaid payments for maintenance software that happened at the beginning of the year. So we see a favorable benefit reversal from that and given our interest expense guidance obviously, the first half is running higher than what you'd expect from a full year basis, so we feel very, very confident about the free cash flow guidance.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi investment research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi investment research.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question for me would be if you could break out a bit more of the capital spending between growth and maintenance both in the second quarter, how you think about the guidance for 2015? And then just secondly, if you could tell a little bit
componenttext: I guess, first question for me would be if you could break out a bit more of the capital spending between growth and maintenance both in the second quarter, how you think about the guidance for 2015? And then just secondly, if you could tell a little bit more about what will be a realistic opportunity for sales productivity within your company to improve sales in the next 12 or 24 months. How are you thinking about the opportunities for [indiscernible] there?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think with respect to capital expenditures, most of the capital we spend is success-based capital. We have some level of maintenance CapEx probably in the $300 million or so range, a little more, but most of the others goes towards -- toward dr
componenttext: Sure. So I think with respect to capital expenditures, most of the capital we spend is success-based capital. We have some level of maintenance CapEx probably in the $300 million or so range, a little more, but most of the others goes towards -- toward driving new revenue growth. This, in particular, as we said in the beginning of the year, we had about -- the way we expected about $70 million in integration CapEx. So that's the only one difference this year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to sales productivity, we don't give out specific numbers on productivity. But if you look at the market, customers want the products and services that Level 3 sales. The need to transition to those products and services is accelerating in th
componenttext: With respect to sales productivity, we don't give out specific numbers on productivity. But if you look at the market, customers want the products and services that Level 3 sales. The need to transition to those products and services is accelerating in the market, and we expect that to continue over the next few years. If you look at the challenges that our sales force has, we're -- we put 2 together. We need to bring up the average productivity for the overall sales organization. We continue to move up market in parts of our company to make sure that we're selling to sweet spot customers at for Level 3, the customers that need Global Services, the customers that really rely on their network as a fundamental component of their ability to win in their markets. Those are the types of customers we do the best with and those are the types of customers that we continue to target and execute with. So we expect that as a lot of the changes that we've implemented through the integration process get behind us, we expect productivity to continue to improve.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we saw that in the Global Crossing situation [indiscernible] integration, we saw very nice increases in productivity.
componenttext: Yes, and we saw that in the Global Crossing situation [indiscernible] integration, we saw very nice increases in productivity.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just first a quick housekeeping question. Your merger integration expenses were a little lighter than we had expected for the quarter. Is that because you're actually getting integration done at a lower cost? Or is it timing? And then just wanted to expan
componenttext: Just first a quick housekeeping question. Your merger integration expenses were a little lighter than we had expected for the quarter. Is that because you're actually getting integration done at a lower cost? Or is it timing? And then just wanted to expand on some of the comments you made about being an inquisitive company. You say as a couple of growth regions as areas where you'd want to get more scale. Could you maybe define that a little bit when you say you want more scale? Does that mean you would like to have more assets? Similar to the type of assets you have in that region or you're actually thinking there are new asset classes, maybe data centers or some other type of category, you should spend more time bolstering up your scale?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll get the integration expense question. So I think it's both, I think the way it's been a little cheaper than we thought, but in addition, it's also timing. Now we're going through some of the tougher systems integration over the balance of
componenttext: All right. I'll get the integration expense question. So I think it's both, I think the way it's been a little cheaper than we thought, but in addition, it's also timing. Now we're going through some of the tougher systems integration over the balance of this year, some into next year. And so we'll have more to talk about it in the rest of the year. But so far, yes, you're right. The expenses have been running lower than what we thought at the beginning of the year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to the asset classes and the scale, if you look in EMEA, we have a very expensive pan-European network. We have great long-haul capabilities. In the U.K., we have very strong domestic fiber infrastructure. In the other 3 markets where I've me
componenttext: With respect to the asset classes and the scale, if you look in EMEA, we have a very expensive pan-European network. We have great long-haul capabilities. In the U.K., we have very strong domestic fiber infrastructure. In the other 3 markets where I've mentioned, France, Germany and Benelux, we want to continue to drive better domestic infrastructure in each of those markets and making sure that we build to our customers that we have fiber connectivity to our company and the pool of demand that exist within each of those territories. So we'll continue to focus on that. Asset classes, data center versus non-data center, those types of things. Our strategy varies a little bit market by market. If you look in Latin America, data centers are more part of our key strategy or our fundamental strategy in that market. We invest organically in all of those different asset classes as well as inorganic. And so I think it's just -- we will continue our strategy in each of those markets, investing organically to drive our scale, to drive better network facilities, better network utilization. And then when we look at inorganic activities, it will be some of the same types of things.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Moorman with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, in terms of North America, I know you said you expect the softness due to Starbucks. But I think you have mentioned that you could expect that Verizon ATT spending so much time on wireless that you might see -- have a competitive advantage over the
componenttext: First, in terms of North America, I know you said you expect the softness due to Starbucks. But I think you have mentioned that you could expect that Verizon ATT spending so much time on wireless that you might see -- have a competitive advantage over them. Is that kind of built into what you're expecting a little softness with Starbucks? Or is that something that could potentially surprise? And then also in terms of cross-selling, is that kind of something you don't expect until 2016 or is there's something that we can start to see early?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so with respect it to Verizon, I mean they've reported last week and you've seen mid- to high-single-digit percent declines in the enterprise and wholesale businesses respectively. And we think over time, that will continue to benefit us as they cont
componenttext: Yes, so with respect it to Verizon, I mean they've reported last week and you've seen mid- to high-single-digit percent declines in the enterprise and wholesale businesses respectively. And we think over time, that will continue to benefit us as they continue to put more capital to it, so wireless and consumer. And so over time, it should benefit us. I think that if you look at our enterprise performance in comparison to them for the last handful of years, it shows this gap, since we are uniquely focused on the wireline enterprise business whereas they are being increasingly dragged more and more into wireless in the case of AT&T consumer, entertainment and wireless in Mexico. So it should benefit us, as it has over time.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And cross-selling and up selling that's a fundamental part of our strategy. We go in and win a little bit of business from a customer, do an excellent job and then over time, drive more and more success through the customers. So we are continuing to focus
componenttext: And cross-selling and up selling that's a fundamental part of our strategy. We go in and win a little bit of business from a customer, do an excellent job and then over time, drive more and more success through the customers. So we are continuing to focus on that, not just as part of the tw telecom acquisition, but as part of our core approach to how we sell customers. And it includes cross-selling and up selling against infrastructures. So how do we get to drive better penetration and buildings that are on that? How do we continue to more efficiently and effectively utilize the infrastructure that we have in place? So it's absolutely, a key part of our strategy, a key part of our efforts to improve within the sales channel.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Davidson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with Moffat Davidson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, drilling down a bit into the product categories. It looks like transport and fiber and co-location and data centers, those are the constant currency growth rates ticked down pretty meaningfully versus last quarter. And I assume that Starbucks would
componenttext: First, drilling down a bit into the product categories. It looks like transport and fiber and co-location and data centers, those are the constant currency growth rates ticked down pretty meaningfully versus last quarter. And I assume that Starbucks would have been more in the IP and data category. Are there any specific drivers there or things that we should be cognitive when assessing those growth rates? And second, Jeff, with respect to your expectation that you can do better in terms of your deliver bolster sales growth. What are some of the factors you're targeting to get up the levels that you think you can achieve?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in general, on the product category, I think that with respect to data centers, we saw weakness in EMEA that we've expected from a large wholesale type of customers that disconnected Latin America, so a little bit of weakness with what I talked ab
componenttext: Yes, so in general, on the product category, I think that with respect to data centers, we saw weakness in EMEA that we've expected from a large wholesale type of customers that disconnected Latin America, so a little bit of weakness with what I talked about. I think North America, the business actually do a little. With respect to IP and data services, the whole collection in general, the revenues were up quite nicely. We did get that impacted as I mentioned by Starbucks and Fed, as we've been talking about for the last 2 quarters now. So it happened as we expected. Within transport and fiber as I mentioned, fiber grew strongly within transport. We saw growth in wavelengths with some decline in private line. But again, consistent with what we had outlined.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to some of the initiatives in areas of focus for driving better sales and better productivity, when you bring 2 telecom companies together for the -- for at the beginning, you're just selling -- what you are selling before to who you were sel
componenttext: With respect to some of the initiatives in areas of focus for driving better sales and better productivity, when you bring 2 telecom companies together for the -- for at the beginning, you're just selling -- what you are selling before to who you were selling it to before. We have a better footprint. We have a better product portfolio, but we got to migrate those things together. So we have focused very hard on making sure our product definitions of the products are uniform, and so that you can sell our Ethernet service regardless of the building, regardless of the geography meaning Europe or North America, you can sell a standard Ethernet product to your customer. We've also enhanced the capabilities making sure that the SDN capabilities that we've built into our Ethernet product are available to our customers and that they understand how to utilize that within their infrastructure to take advantage of those capabilities. And so it starts with the product definitions. It also has to include though, making sure that we have integrated the networks and the way that I talked about and again, I'll use the Ethernet example, but the way we talked about the Ethernet. Building the platform, so that across North America now, our customers, if they order new Ethernet services from us, they go across 1 system, they go across 1 network and they have 1 product definition regardless of where you're buying them -- we're deploying that as we speak in EMEA and we'll follow up in early parts of 2016, beginning deploying that in Latin America. And so the product definition, the infrastructure, the support system, all of those things are critical to drive better performance. We've already done a lot of the things that we needed to do in the sales organization. We've consolidated the customer relationship management systems, so we have 1 view of the customers. We've standardized our funneling process and we've standardized our compensation. And so we've already started, many of those activities and are starting to see the sales organization settled down into the new structure that we have and the new approach that we have. And then we also have to continue to move some of our lowering sales reps up market, and selling more to our sweet spot customers. So customer targeting and making sure we're effectively using our sales force time, our other areas that we're really focused on.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer & Co.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Horan with Oppenheimer & Co.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the notion of 1. Is this really incorporated with the integration of tw telecom? Or are you spending more on the notion of 1 and will it take a little bit longer? And are you still waiting for that to be completed for further acquisitions? And then jus
componenttext: On the notion of 1. Is this really incorporated with the integration of tw telecom? Or are you spending more on the notion of 1 and will it take a little bit longer? And are you still waiting for that to be completed for further acquisitions? And then just on the CDN, the acceleration growth, is this from new customers or just having more capacity on the network? And are you seeing any shift in pricing in CDN because I think AWS, from what we're hearing has been a little bit more aggressive lately.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. With respect to 1, there is a fundamental belief in the way that the tw telecom systems were built around the same concept of a single set of systems controlling a single network with a single product definition. And so certainly we are incorporatin
componenttext: Okay. With respect to 1, there is a fundamental belief in the way that the tw telecom systems were built around the same concept of a single set of systems controlling a single network with a single product definition. And so certainly we are incorporating that in our go forward approach. But what we have tried to do is take the best of both companies, and bring them together in a way that our systems support our overall strategy. So looking at CRM, which has the Salesforce.com implementation. There will be different components from Level 3, different components from tw telecom as we implement our operational support systems going forward. But it's all with the philosophy that we want to have a single product portfolio globally, that we can deliver it to our customers. We want to have infrastructure network components in place that are consistent across the growth to deliver that product and service, but they can't be controlled in an automated fashion by our higher layer operational support systems to build in the SDN capabilities going forward, to build in the flexibility and the ease of control that we've talked about and to simplify our operating environment for our employees and simplify the operating environment for our customers as well. So that's the notion of 1. it's part of our overall integration strategy.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So can we perceive more synergies from the notion of 1, than you got it to from the merger? When we incorporate everything?
componenttext: So can we perceive more synergies from the notion of 1, than you got it to from the merger? When we incorporate everything?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Over time, we expect the platform that we built will be far more efficient than the ones that we have in place today. And so we expect to be able to continue to grow and serve our customers in a very efficient way that will create more compelling offers i
componenttext: Over time, we expect the platform that we built will be far more efficient than the ones that we have in place today. And so we expect to be able to continue to grow and serve our customers in a very efficient way that will create more compelling offers in the marketplace.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then we continue to progress on that, a couple of quick examples this quarter and the third quarter will be on 1 set of financial systems worldwide, which means that we basically integrated the tw telecom financial systems at the Level 3 Financin
componenttext: Yes, and then we continue to progress on that, a couple of quick examples this quarter and the third quarter will be on 1 set of financial systems worldwide, which means that we basically integrated the tw telecom financial systems at the Level 3 Financing systems. Similarly in North America, we'll be on 1 billing platform by the end of the year. So as these progress, you do get efficiencies over time. With respect to your CDN question, yes, the situation that we faced at the beginning of this year was not having enough capacity on our network, which takes a couple of quarters to put in. And the second issue we faced was congestion on and peering length and you saw, we made quite a bit of progress in the second quarter, signing interconnection agreements with a number of carriers. So the combination of both those things, we think will lead to much better performance from existing customers and having said that, as Jeff pointed out earlier, with provider and enterprise based that we have in general, over time, we think we can do a better job of cross-selling in to that. But obviously, that 'll take a bit of time. For the balance of the year, you see a lot of it coming from, just the existing customers.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any change in the CDN pricing out there?
componenttext: Any change in the CDN pricing out there?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really. Pricing trends have been consistent. It's a profitable line of business. We like the margin so I think pricing has been okay.
componenttext: Not really. Pricing trends have been consistent. It's a profitable line of business. We like the margin so I think pricing has been okay.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. I think that's the last of our questions. So in closing, I'd like to end with a few highlights. Our results in this quarter are in line with expectations and we continue to focus profitable growth, expanding our margins of generating free cas
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. I think that's the last of our questions. So in closing, I'd like to end with a few highlights. Our results in this quarter are in line with expectations and we continue to focus profitable growth, expanding our margins of generating free cash flow. We're pleased with the progress. We made around integration and have confidence in our roadmap going forward. With our operating leverage, continued focus on synergies and ongoing cost optimization from a variety of simplification initiatives we have excellent momentum in growing free cash flow and we are focused on increasing free cash flow per share. We believe we're making the right investments to position the company for better growth. The market needs the products and services Level 3 provides and we believe the transition to these services continues to accelerate. As always, thank you, for joining today's call and for your support of Level 3. Operator, that concludes call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. We would like to thank everyone for your participation and for using the Level 3 conferencing service today. This does conclude the conference call and we ask that you please disconnect your lines. Have a great day, everyone.
componenttext: Thank you, Jeff. We would like to thank everyone for your participation and for using the Level 3 conferencing service today. This does conclude the conference call and we ask that you please disconnect your lines. Have a great day, everyone.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded on Wednesday, July 29, 2015. I would now like to turn the co
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded on Wednesday, July 29, 2015. I would now like to turn the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Ms. Valerie Finberg. Please go ahead.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice Pre
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.
With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I'd like to draw your attention to the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com. On this site are the presentation materials that accompany this call, the earnings press release and supplemental financial information. Comparisons to prior periods are being presented on a pro forma basis, assuming that the acquisition of tw telecom took place on January 1, 2014. Revenue and sales comparisons to prior periods are provided on a year-over-year and constant currency basis unless otherwise noted. 
I need to call your attention to our Safe Harbor statement that is on Page 2 of our 2Q '15 earnings presentation. The presentation and our remarks today contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may vary significantly from those statements. A discussion of factors that may affect future results can be found in Level 3's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As you can see from our expanding margins, our second quarter results demonstrate the company's continued focus on profitable growth. We also continue investing to position the company
componenttext:
Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As you can see from our expanding margins, our second quarter results demonstrate the company's continued focus on profitable growth. We also continue investing to position the company for the future initiatives to introduce new product capabilities, extend our network reach and simplify our operating environment, are all intended to drive long-term profitable growth. 
With respect to our integration efforts, solid execution and providing a differentiated customer experience remain the top priorities. I'll provide details on our progress after Sunit reviews our financial results. In addition, while Sunit will cover revenue performance by region, I'll share an update on what we're seeing from a business perspective in both Latin America and EMEA. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Sunit.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We continued to execute on integration during the quarter, and progressed nicely on synergies. Adjusted EBITDA margins expanded to 32.3% in the second quarter of 2015, up from 29.4% on a pro forma basis in the
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We continued to execute on integration during the quarter, and progressed nicely on synergies. Adjusted EBITDA margins expanded to 32.3% in the second quarter of 2015, up from 29.4% on a pro forma basis in the second quarter of 2014. Over the last quarter, we continued to invest in product, network and system capabilities to position the company for revenue growth. 
Moving now to the second quarter highlights on Slide 3. Core Network Services revenue for the second quarter of 2015 grew 5.4% year-over-year. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 6.7%. Including integration-related expenses, adjusted EBITDA grew to $665 million. The company generated free cash flow of $102 million. To our year-to-date refinancing activities, we have reduced annualized interest expense by approximately $84 million and our leverage ratio is now at 4.1x. As of the end of the second quarter, we have achieved $115 million in annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. 
Turning to Slide 4. CNS revenue grew 5.4% on a constant currency basis and 2.9% on an as-reported basis. As we saw last quarter, the difference in growth rates is due to the strong dollar compared to the year-ago period. Outside of the U.S. dollar, which represented 88% of CNS revenues as of the end of the second quarter, our top 3 foreign currencies are the British pound at 5%, the euro at 3%, the Brazilian real at 3%. On a revenue-weighted average basis, those 3 currencies declined 16% against the dollar compared to the year-ago quarter and negatively affected our CNS revenue growth by approximately 2.5% this quarter. On a regional basis, North America CNS revenue grew 6.7%. At the beginning of the year, we noted that we expected CNS revenue for North America to be a little softer than the 6.8% pro forma growth we saw in the fourth quarter of 2014 due to the incremental growth last year from Starbucks and some large federal contracts. Our outlook for the year remains consistent with these expectations. Enterprise CNS revenue grew 7.1% during the quarter, in line with our expectations. 
Turning to wholesale. CNS revenue grew 5.8% this quarter. In the quarter, we settled some disputes that led to an unusually strong performance in wholesale. In the third quarter, we expect wholesale CNS revenue to decline slightly year-over-year. For EMEA, we said that we expected a smaller decline compared to the 2.2% decline we saw last year in the region. For the first half of 2015, total CNS revenue for EMEA declined 1.8% on a constant currency basis. During the second quarter of 2015, CNS revenue declined 2.7% on a constant currency basis and 12% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 4.9% on a constant currency basis and declined 3.5% on an as-reported basis. Wholesale CNS revenue declined 9.8% on a constant currency basis and 20% on an as-reported basis. As we said previously, we expect better performance from EMEA also this year, and we did see slight improvement compared to the prior quarter decline of 11%. 
U.K. government CNS revenue declined 11% on a constant currency basis and 19% on an as-reported basis. In Latin America, CNS revenue grew 5.7% on a constant currency basis and declined 7% on an as-reported basis. At the beginning of the year, we said we expect comparable performance to the 8.5% CNS revenue growth we saw in 2014. For the year-to-date, CNS revenue in the region grew 5.9% on a constant currency basis, softer than we expected as macroeconomic and political issues persist. We continue to see headwinds in this area. Enterprise CNS revenue grew 5.6% on a constant currency basis and declined 7.6% on an as-reported basis. Wholesale CNS revenue grew 5.9% on a constant currency basis and declined 4.8% on an as-reported basis. 
Let me briefly touch on Venezuela. As we've been discussing, we are monitoring the situation in Venezuela and the macro environment has continued to worsen. At the end of the second quarter, at the SICAD 1 rate of VEF 12.8 to the dollar, the company had a cash balance equivalent of approximately USD 80 million. The June 30, 2015 Simadi exchange rate was VEF 197.3 to the dollar, but we're still transacting the majority of our business to the SICAD 1 rate. Our revenue in Venezuela in the second quarter was $24 million.
At the bottom of Slide 4, CNS revenue churn remained low at 1% during the quarter. On Slide 5, Wholesale Voice Services and other revenue, or WVS, declined 17% to $120 million in the second quarter 2015. We expect continued double-digit rates of decline in WVS revenue. 
Turning to Slide 6 and revenue results by product group. We have provided growth rates on a -- both on an as-reported basis and constant currency basis. My remarks reference the growth rates on a constant currency basis. IP and data services, which grew 8.1%, continue to drive the company's growth, led by growth in VPN services and managed and converged services. Within IP and data services, CDN declined year-over-year. We do expect CDN performance to improve for the balance of the year, given the increased investment I referenced last quarter and from the interconnection agreements we signed this past quarter, which should relieve peering congestion. Transport and fiber grew 3%. And within that group, dark fiber grew 5.7%. Voice services grew 7.1% as a result of the North America wholesale settlement I mentioned earlier. Colocation and data services declined 0.2%. 
Turning to pricing. We continue to see little change in the overall pricing environment. As a company, we spend a fair amount of time analyzing pricing dynamics. We take a market-based approach to pricing, looking at particular geographies, products, verticals and other factors. This has become an institutional capability for us as part of our focus on profitable growth. 
Turning to Slide 7. Network Access margin expanded to 66.2% compared to 64.3% in the second quarter of 2014. The improvement in Network Access margin was driven in part by the high-margin settlement revenue I noted earlier and by integration-related network synergies. Continued CNS growth and WVS revenue declines also contributed to the improvement. Network-related expenses, excluding noncash compensation, was $359 million for the second quarter of 2015 compared to $357 million for the second quarter of 2014.
SG&A, excluding noncash compensation and integration-related expenses for the second quarter of 2015, was $336 million. This compares to $344 million for the second quarter of 2014. Year-over-year, the reduction in SG&A have been driven by synergies. 
Turning to Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA, including integration-related expenses, was $665 million for the second quarter of 2015. Excluding integrated-related expenses of $5 million, adjusted EBITDA was $670 million. This compares to $597 million for the second quarter of 2014 or $605 million, excluding $8 million in transaction and integration costs that quarter. The improvement in adjusted EBITDA was primarily driven by good progress in capturing operating expense synergies. Adjusted EBITDA margin, including integration-related expenses, improved to 32.3% compared to 29.4% for the second quarter of 2014. We feel good about our ability to continue expanding adjusted EBITDA margins as we recognized synergies, further optimize our cost structure and add high-margin CNS revenues. 
Moving to synergies. Since the acquisition closed, we've achieved approximately $115 million of annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies with $25 million on Network Access cost synergies and $90 million of operating expense synergies. The focus going forward is around network synergies, which take a little longer to achieve compared to OpEx synergies. We continue to remain confident about our ability to achieve 70% or $140 million of our synergy targets by the end of the first quarter of 2016. 
On Slide 9, capital expenditures were $317 million in the second quarter of 2015 and are 14% of total revenue year-to-date. We continue to expect CapEx of 15% of total revenue for the full year 2015. The company generated free cash flow of $102 million in the quarter. As a result of the capital markets transactions completed during the quarter, our cash interest expense in the second quarter was a little higher than usual. Given our cash interest expense guidance was $640 million for 2015, we expect quarterly cash interest expense of about $160 million. In the second quarter, as a result of the refinancings, cash interest expense was $219 million. Year-to-date, our cash interest expense is $365 million. As of June 30, 2015, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $549 million. 
Turning to Slide 10. We exited the quarter with our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio at 4.1x. This compares to 4.2x at the end of last quarter. We remain focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 5x, which we expect to be driven by growth in adjusted EBITDA. Our average interest rate on our debt is now 5.1% compared to 5.3% in the first quarter of 2015 and 6% -- 6.8% for Level 3 stand-alone in the second quarter of 2014. 
Turning to business outlook on Slide 11. We remain confident in our performance for the remainder of the year. We are reiterating our outlook we've provided last quarter with 2015 adjusted EBITDA growth of 14% to 17% from a starting point of $2.271 billion pro forma for the tw telecom acquisition and including integration expenses. We also expect to generate free cash flow of $600 million to $650 million for the full year 2015. Given the capital markets activity in the quarter, we are lowering our interest expense outlook for the full year 2015 and now expect GAAP interest expense of approximately $650 million and net cash interest expense of approximately $640 million compared to our prior outlook of $660 million and $645 million, respectively. All other outlook measures remain unchanged. 
As we look to the third quarter of 2015, we expect to see our typical increase in utility costs generally in the high single-digit millions of dollars as a result of the higher summer cooling requirements in our data centers. Also, we don't -- we won't see the benefit of the second quarter dispute settlement that we saw in North America also in the quarter. 
In summary, we are pleased with our progress on adjusted EBITDA growth and the continued margin expansion we've been able to achieve. For the second half of the year, we remain focused on integration and continue to recognize additional synergies. We're continuing to invest in the business both to drive profitable revenue growth and optimize cost. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sunit. As I said at the beginning of the year, we look at 2015 as a transition year. The successful integration of our company remains our top priority. In the past, many of you may have heard me talk about the notion of one that is so integral
componenttext:
Thank you, Sunit. As I said at the beginning of the year, we look at 2015 as a transition year. The successful integration of our company remains our top priority. In the past, many of you may have heard me talk about the notion of one that is so integral to our approach, combining and simplifying our product capabilities to create one portfolio of products regardless of geography, standardizing our network technologies and architectures to create one comprehensive global network and selecting and integrating our operational support systems to provide one operating environment for our employees and customers around the world. Each of these are key integration initiatives. 
On our first quarter earnings call, I noted that there have been no major surprises as part of the integration process. I'm pleased to say this remains true for the second quarter as well. Last quarter, I updated you on the various initiatives to integrate 2 sales teams of roughly equivalent size in North America. Account moves and organization realignments, CRM and other systems migrations as well as restructuring of the compensation plans are a few of the changes that impacted our sales team during the first few months of the year. For the past 90 days, we have not introduced any significant changes for the sales organization. While unwanted sales, forced attrition has ticked up slightly, we're paying very close attention to it. Having said that, attrition is still within our expectations. We remain focused on maintaining the sales momentum the 2 companies experienced prior to close. 
In the second quarter, CNS sales increased slightly both sequentially and year-over-year on a pro forma basis. As you've heard me say before, we're pleased, but not satisfied. I believe we can do more to make it easier for the sales force to cross-sell, up-sell, and improve overall productivity. I've been asked questions before about the competitiveness of our new combined offering and whether we can win more business than either of the previous companies could as stand-alone entities. I thought I would share one example: A recent deal with a company that is an intermediary for the information exchange between health plans and providers. They help to ease the complexity of moving business and clinical information to health care stakeholders nationwide. As a customer, both Level 3 and tw telecom, the company came to us with the need for an updated solution across their network. Their current solution included circuits from Level 3, tw telecom as well as other carriers. As a result of Level 3's now broader product portfolio and larger on-net footprint, we updated their full branch network into a single-carrier solution with higher throughput speeds on that colocation and 100% physical diversity. This new solution is helping our customer keep pace with ever-changing regulatory and technology requirements. 
As we continue the integration of our products, networks and systems, we are laying the foundation for initiatives that are key to driving future profitable growth, making it easier for customers to do business with Level 3, while also optimizing our cost structure creates more compelling offers in the market. As examples, we've completed the integration of all core security services to our in-state products and platforms. We're continuing to add capabilities to our managed security portfolio. Just after the close of the quarter, we announced that we are strengthening our capabilities in this area with the acquisition of Black Lotus. While not financially material, the acquisition brings important proxy-based DDoS mitigation services along with additional scrubbing centers and talented security professionals to the Level 3 team. We've standardized on a single Ethernet platform. And by platform, I mean, the product definitions, the network to deploy those products and the systems to support them. We've completed our rollout of the new Ethernet platform in North America and expect to complete the rollout in EMEA by the end of the year and Latin America in 2016. As one of the largest SDN deployments in our industry, these unified global capabilities will provide a differentiated experience for our customers in doing business in multiple locations as well as streamline Level 3 operations. We're investing to add CDN capacity around the world to meet growing demand in support of video and other content distributed online. We've worked diligently with industry partners to redefine interconnection and ensure access to an open Internet for all of our customers. I'd like to spend a couple of minutes sharing my perspectives on our LatAm and EMEA businesses. 
I spend a lot of time traveling in each of our 3 regions, meeting with management, employees and customers. As I mentioned on our last call, I was in Latin America in March. While Sunit described the continued pressure we see from the economic and political environment in the region, we are still growing the business and I believe we are well positioned to achieve stronger growth when the regional economic conditions improve. I returned last week from EMEA. I believe we're making progress in our efforts to return EMEA to growth. As you may have seen from the announcement yesterday, Andrew Crouch has now filled out his management team and we've hired key executives in sales, marketing and strategy, supplementing our already strong leaders in operations, finance, human resources and legal. While we continue to take advantage of our pan-European footprint, the top priorities for the team are to improve sales discipline, enhance customer targeting and drive more on-net buildings and network expansions in 4 territories within EMEA, the U.K., France, Germany and Benelux. We clearly have a lot of work ahead of us, but I believe we're taking the right steps to grow our market share and provide for long-term growth in this large market. 
Across the globe, CIOs are asked to help their companies grow, manage increasingly complex and demanding user needs, protect their company's data and network capabilities in an escalating and hostile environment, while at the same time, reducing their overall cost to operate. Whether using our sophisticated security services to protect their enterprise or coupling Level 3 Ethernet services with their internal SDN capabilities or using IP VPNs to tie together their offices around the world, our customers continue to transition to the flexible, scalable IP and optical services we provide to meet their evolving needs. 
At this point, I'd like to open it up for your questions. Operator, would you explain the process?

componenttext: I think on North America, perhaps you could just give a little bit more color about sort of overall enterprise trends. We saw that Bell's numbers a little bit soft there. But Sunit, you mentioned pricing was stable, what's going on in terms of overall booking trends and sort of enterprise health in terms of ordering? And then Sunit, could you just provide a little bit more color around the dispute recognition? Is it $10 million, $15 million? Is that the sort of size we're looking at?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me -- I'll go ahead and start with the -- what we're seeing in the enterprise market in North America, we see a good strong market for the products and services that we sell. We see a continuing transition to IP and optical services as customers
componenttext: Sure. Let me -- I'll go ahead and start with the -- what we're seeing in the enterprise market in North America, we see a good strong market for the products and services that we sell. We see a continuing transition to IP and optical services as customers are trying to deal with all the complexities that I mentioned, that CIOs looking at, whether it's mobility or cloud computing, more online content, all of those types of things are driving the products and services we sell. If you compare -- I mentioned the sales in the first quarter -- excuse me, in the second quarter of this year compared to the second quarter of last year, we are -- our sales are slightly up compared to last year, so we're continuing the momentum that the 2 companies saw individually from a sales perspective.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Simon, to your question on the settlement. Yes, it's in the range. It's roughly about $10 million of benefit compared to last quarter.
componenttext: And Simon, to your question on the settlement. Yes, it's in the range. It's roughly about $10 million of benefit compared to last quarter.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: EMEA and LatAm growth on a constant currency basis seems to have weakened a bit in the quarter? Can you give us a little color on that? And does the previous growth guidance for those segments still apply?
componenttext: EMEA and LatAm growth on a constant currency basis seems to have weakened a bit in the quarter? Can you give us a little color on that? And does the previous growth guidance for those segments still apply?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think in EMEA as we said, yes, we stated at the beginning of the year that declined 2.2%, and we expect to do a little better than that kind of decline this year. So, so far, they're holding in. And then LatAm is a little weaker, as we mentioned
componenttext: Yes. So I think in EMEA as we said, yes, we stated at the beginning of the year that declined 2.2%, and we expect to do a little better than that kind of decline this year. So, so far, they're holding in. And then LatAm is a little weaker, as we mentioned, given the changes you've seen in the commodity markets, oil prices, metals and the overall political and macroeconomic situation there. We have seen the growth has been a little lower than we thought, and we'll see how it goes for the rest of the year. So we've seen a little more weakness in LatAm. EMEA is performing as we outlined and as we've been saying in the last couple of years -- last couple of quarters, I'm sorry.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. So I wanted to go back to North America. So you mentioned in your response, I guess, to Simon's question, that sales were up on a year-over-year basis. I was wondering if you could talk about what the trend was quarter-over-quarter. And I guess tha
componenttext: Great. So I wanted to go back to North America. So you mentioned in your response, I guess, to Simon's question, that sales were up on a year-over-year basis. I was wondering if you could talk about what the trend was quarter-over-quarter. And I guess that was the one area, at least in our model, where we saw weakness relative to expectation. Curious, if that's simply a result of that sales force integration in the first quarter and that book to bill and how that impacted the second quarter, and if the sales are starting to improve, if we could start to see improvement in the back half of this year. And then my second question is on EBITDA. If you simply annualize the EBITDA that you just recorded in the second quarter, you'd effectively be at 17% year-over-year, which would be at the high end of your guidance. Is that meant to imply that we could be seeing flat EBITDA or even down EBITDA in the back half of the year? Are you simply being conservative with your guidance?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So going to your question. So I assume you're talking about sales, not revenues. So our sales bookings were up sequentially and year-over-year. As far as the revenue goes, as we've been saying for 2 quarters now, that we're going to see a little softer pe
componenttext: So going to your question. So I assume you're talking about sales, not revenues. So our sales bookings were up sequentially and year-over-year. As far as the revenue goes, as we've been saying for 2 quarters now, that we're going to see a little softer performance over the balance of the year in North America because of the Starbucks and the federal contracts, the Starbucks revenue was ramping up this last year and some into the beginning of this year, and then we had some federal contracts that peeled off, that we talked about. So the performance is in line with what we -- in respect to North America. Enterprise is in line with what we've talked about. And so we're just seeing that. There's nothing that has changed fundamentally. I think the sales momentum is pretty good given the size of the combination of the 2 companies coming together, bringing them together in North America, and installing tools are holding up as you would expect for the kind of products and services we're selling. So the revenue performance, again, we've been saying this for 2 quarters and you're just seeing that play out. We'll see that play out for the rest of the year as we've talked about previously.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just reiterate what Sunit said. Our revenue sales -- our sales continue to improve sequentially and year-over-year. And given the number of changes that I've mentioned, that we did in the first quarter, we're pretty pleased with that. Now we're n
componenttext: And I'll just reiterate what Sunit said. Our revenue sales -- our sales continue to improve sequentially and year-over-year. And given the number of changes that I've mentioned, that we did in the first quarter, we're pretty pleased with that. Now we're never satisfied. We'll continue to focus on driving better sales performance. But it is a transition year. We've made massive changes in the first quarter to our sales organization, our product portfolio, all of the things that come with putting 2 large companies together. And on a year-over-year basis, our second quarter sales results were better. So we're overall pleased. But again, not satisfied with where we are yet.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: And I guess, on EBITDA?

componenttext: Yes. So on EBITDA, I mean, as we've said, we got benefit from the settlement. We won't see that next quarter. We also have utility costs going up in the third quarter, as has been the case ever since I've been at Level 3. So I think that we continue to feel comfortable with the guidance that we outlined last quarter.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So just to clarify, the sales are improving year-over-year, is that going to translate into sort of revenue trends improving year-over-year? And then on the wholesale side, are you all picking up share? Most of the other carriers appear to be
componenttext: Okay, great. So just to clarify, the sales are improving year-over-year, is that going to translate into sort of revenue trends improving year-over-year? And then on the wholesale side, are you all picking up share? Most of the other carriers appear to be losing revenue and you appear to be gaining -- the margins, incrementally better there on the wholesale now.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the second question first, which is on the wholesale side. I think you heard us say for quite a number of years that in general, for a longer period of time, we expect wholesale to be flat to slightly down. And now we've been benefited last c
componenttext: So I'll take the second question first, which is on the wholesale side. I think you heard us say for quite a number of years that in general, for a longer period of time, we expect wholesale to be flat to slightly down. And now we've been benefited last couple of quarters, at least in North America, with some settlements, particularly this past quarter. Our LatAm business is doing well because they're geared more towards consumer media and some of their wholesale customers. So I don't think anything's changed that for us. For us, the business continues to be a good profitable business for us, the margins in our wholesale business are comparable to what we've -- to our enterprise business, so we're happy with the profitability. In terms of the trends for the balance of the year, I mean, I think that -- there are 2 ways I've looked at it. One is with respect to our overall enterprise revenue, we do expect better sequential comparisons for the balance of the year. And we expect that the year-over-year enterprise trends will be consistent with what we've seen this quarter overall, specifically with respect to North America, I think we'll see on the margin, slight improvement, but consistent with what we reported this quarter. So in answer to your question, yes. I mean, the sales bookings should continue to benefit us. The year-over-year comparisons can get a little clouded by onetime things we had last year. As I mentioned, Starbucks and the federal contracts, which is why I mentioned the sequential point. So I think overall, given the size of the acquisition we did and everything -- all the changes we have going on, we're pretty -- we think performance is holding up as we expected in North America.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just one clarification on Phil's question earlier on Latin America. Jeff, you highlighted a little bit in your comments, and Sunit talked a bit about the weakening macro there. But I just want to confirm that you still felt comfortable with the g
componenttext: I guess, just one clarification on Phil's question earlier on Latin America. Jeff, you highlighted a little bit in your comments, and Sunit talked a bit about the weakening macro there. But I just want to confirm that you still felt comfortable with the guidance that you have for Latin America, particularly assuming that there's no sort of inflection on -- to the better -- on the macro, in the back half of the year, if you're still comfortable there. And then I guess, secondly, just the typical quarterly question around M&A, Jeff. You've obviously, focused a lot on integration. I think you've made a lot of progress on the sales force, still have some work to go. But as you start to think about inorganic opportunities, particularly with your leverage here at 4.1x and likely decline, and given EBITDA growth, what you're seeing out in the marketplace? And what you're appetite is, perhaps to do something outside of North America?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll cover the LatAm question first. So I think, again, as I said, we've seen a little softer performance than we expected first half of the year. As we look at the balance of the year, overall in LatAm, we think we'll see stronger performance from the en
componenttext: I'll cover the LatAm question first. So I think, again, as I said, we've seen a little softer performance than we expected first half of the year. As we look at the balance of the year, overall in LatAm, we think we'll see stronger performance from the enterprise side and generally better performance second half of the year. I think third quarter might be comparable to what we saw in the second quarter. It should pick up in the fourth quarter. So overall, running may be 1% or so, softer than what we outlined at the beginning of the year. Now obviously, we'll know more with every passing quarter, but that's what we currently believe.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Scott, with respect to M&A, we're an inquisitive company and it's part of our strategy to continue to acquire. We announced the Black Lotus transaction. Again, that one is very small, but it brought a capability that we wanted to have and now our prod
componenttext: And Scott, with respect to M&A, we're an inquisitive company and it's part of our strategy to continue to acquire. We announced the Black Lotus transaction. Again, that one is very small, but it brought a capability that we wanted to have and now our product portfolio and the capability we want to have on our team. So we'll continue to look at M&A from a variety of different approaches. We believe in Europe and Latin America, we want to continue to grow scale. And so those are some drivers to look at things, internationally. Having said that, our focus is on integrating tw telecom and Level 3. And we're going to make sure that, that's the highest priority that we have as a business that we integrated effectively. It has global ramifications as we standardize our product set, as we standardize our network and as we standardize our system across the globe, we want to continue to drive that capability and take advantage of the acquisition we did with tw telecom. And so that remains our primary focus, but we are an acquiring company, an inquisitive company, and we'll continue to look at opportunities to add scale or capabilities that we need, regardless of the region.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: I guess, just back on the North American wholesale, so if you strip up a settlement this quarter, implies about, I guess, $440 million x that, but your commentary suggests maybe more pressure off the quarter, more sequential pressure. So how much of that is due to wholesale carrier grooming maybe versus other factors in there?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, again, it could be -- consolidation has been the theme of the wholesale business for a long time, so -- which is why we've always said longer term, we expect wholesale to be flat to down, generally. And I think it's because our -- w
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, again, it could be -- consolidation has been the theme of the wholesale business for a long time, so -- which is why we've always said longer term, we expect wholesale to be flat to down, generally. And I think it's because our -- what we see in the quarter is consistent with that. Now in any given quarter, you might have some things moving around, but when I look at things on an overall year-over-year basis, I think it's consistent. Having said that, I think we still expect wholesale to be growing year-over-year, given some of the benefits we had.

componenttext: Yes, so we have in the first half of the year, we have our annual bonus payments that happened in the first half of the year. And given our interest expense guidance, obviously, the first half is running higher than what you'd expect from a full year basis, so we feel very, very confident about the free cash flow guidance.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
