headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could please, one of the large and compensating for the first time highlighted market share loss as a driver of their enterprise business declines. With that, being a significant commentary from them, I was wondering if you could make a comment on ne
componenttext: If I could please, one of the large and compensating for the first time highlighted market share loss as a driver of their enterprise business declines. With that, being a significant commentary from them, I was wondering if you could make a comment on new commentaries you guys are seeing in the enterprise space. If you are seeing opportunities for the larger customers, given the combination -- I'd love to hear more thoughts there. And then second, while I talk about Comcast, others coming into the fortune 1000 space. Historically, we have worked with Comcast to providing network infrastructure they might have themselves, but you signed an agreement back in '04 for dark fiber. So maybe your thoughts around kind of viewing Comcast as a competitor versus the opportunity to maybe leverage her own assets and help them move where already going anyway and benefit from that move.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, of market share loss of our competitors, I think that speaks for itself. So I mean, if you look at outperformance over the past 2 years, we've been growing revenue with enterprise customers. Overall we don't think enterprises spend is i
componenttext: Yes, first of all, of market share loss of our competitors, I think that speaks for itself. So I mean, if you look at outperformance over the past 2 years, we've been growing revenue with enterprise customers. Overall we don't think enterprises spend is increasing. So if we're growing revenue and spend is think that,let's say, then by definition, we're growing share. So we're very comfortable with our position there. Where have you with the opportunity we have in front of us. With figures a lot of opportunity for us to continue to help enterprises make the transition from older traditional technologies to IP optical services and to continue to drive growth. We're happy with our capabilities and the position that we have in the market now our competitive position and our market and it's -- we've said for a long time that our ability to grow is based in our ability to execute. We think the market going where we wanted to go, where we are good at serving them and we'll continue to try and drive that. When it comes to Comcast. Michael, you just described the wholesale provider dilemma and it's something that we're very good at. We enable our competitors each and every day. We sell services on a wholesale basis to many of the companies that you guys with this is our biggest competitors and we listened that our biggest competitors. So we're very good at that and recognize that we can win in 2 ways. We can win by making Comcast more successful by helping somebody else more successful, but we can also win because we have capabilities that others don't have and we can win directly with enterprise customers by providing those services in other ways that they can't. So we're pretty pleased with our overall position that we have. And again, Comcast is an excellent company but so are our other competitors.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we have important differentiators, if you look at the school -- I mean compared and you're not Comcast in particular, but if you look at the scope of our network and cobranded portfolio product and services, we have quite a number of differentiating e
componenttext: And we have important differentiators, if you look at the school -- I mean compared and you're not Comcast in particular, but if you look at the scope of our network and cobranded portfolio product and services, we have quite a number of differentiating elements that continue to help us and help us win in the marketplace versus our peers.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about interconnection. I know you signed some agreements recently, and just that you're starting to see any benefit there? Or you can expect with those new contracts. And then just in terms of M&A, what you're talking about mor
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about interconnection. I know you signed some agreements recently, and just that you're starting to see any benefit there? Or you can expect with those new contracts. And then just in terms of M&A, what you're talking about more opportunistically I guess, in Europe. But given what's going on in Latin America and the problems they're having there, do you think that kind of creates more probably inorganic opportunities down the road?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to interconnection, we have reached agreements with many of the large incumbents and cable companies in the U.S. We still have 1 or 2 holdouts in North America that we're working with to reach interconnection agreements with. But we still hav
componenttext: With respect to interconnection, we have reached agreements with many of the large incumbents and cable companies in the U.S. We still have 1 or 2 holdouts in North America that we're working with to reach interconnection agreements with. But we still have issues in other parts of the world as we try to interconnect with PTTs and others out there. So interconnection is not behind us. Do we see benefits? We see disadvantages to consumers and to the marketplace when companies refuse to interconnect. And so customers that want content to download when companies refuse to connect with Level 3, their customers suffer. And so as we go out and we talked to our peers in the industry and those other parties, that's what we focus on. It's not a benefit for Level 3, it's a benefit for their customers because their customers are the ones that are disadvantaged. And we deliver content that their customers want and their customers request.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have paid for.
componenttext: And have paid for.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have paid for and the better job that we do of interconnecting with them, recognizing -- we're not trying to ask anybody to build network on our behalf. We invest on our own capital to build our own network, but we're trying to help them deliver bette
componenttext:
And have paid for and the better job that we do of interconnecting with them, recognizing -- we're not trying to ask anybody to build network on our behalf. We invest on our own capital to build our own network, but we're trying to help them deliver better services to their customers. So that's really how we focus on interconnection. We'll continue to focus and there are a few standouts that we will continue to work on to get better interconnection with them. With respect to M&A. In any particular region, we just look at the opportunities that are out there and respond to those opportunities. I've said it before, but you have to have a willing buyer and a willing seller and so some markets, there may be more willing sellers than we're a willing buyer. In other markets, that may not be opportunity for us to buy something that we find compelling. So we're opportunistic. We stay in touch and engaged in all of the various regions across a range of things, not just fiber providers, but security, managed services, professional services. We pay attention to a range of different things to see if there's something out there that make sense for us. But we are opportunistic and we'll continue to be so. 
With that, thank you very much, James for the final question. I'd like to close the call with just a few thoughts. We delivered a solid quarter of growth in our enterprise business. While we have more to do, we made good integration progress since the closing of the tw telecom acquisition a year ago. We continue to demonstrate our ability and our discipline to ramp free cash flow through our focus on profitable CNS revenue growth, synergy realization, other cost optimization initiatives and reducing interest expense, we remain firmly committed to increasing free cash flow on a per share basis. At the same time, we're investing in the business for future revenue growth and to meet the demanding and evolving needs of enterprise customers. As always, thank you for joining today's call and for your support of Level 3. Operator, that concludes the call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded on Wednesday, October 28, 2015. It's now my pl
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for standing by, and welcome to the Level 3 Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded on Wednesday, October 28, 2015. 
It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Valerie Finberg, VP Investor Relations at Level 3. Please proceed.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today, are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice Presid
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With us on the call today, are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'd like to draw your attention to the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com. On this site are the presentation materials that accompany this call, the earnings press release and supplemental financial information. Detailed revenue and adjusted EBITDA results for Venezuela operations for the last 4 quarters are provided in the supplemental schedule. 
Comparisons to prior period are being presented on a pro forma basis, assuming that the acquisition of tw telecom took place on January 1, 2014. Revenue and sales comparisons to prior periods are provided on a year-over-year and constant currency basis unless otherwise noted. I need to call your attention to our safe harbor statement that begins on Page 2 of our 3Q '15 Earnings Presentation. The presentation and remarks contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may vary significantly from those statements. 
A discussion of factors that may affect future results can be found in Level 3's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We will be referring to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation.
With that, I'll turn it over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. With the 1-year mark of the tw telecom acquisition approaching, it's been an exciting and productive year for Level 3. We've made steady progress around integration and have moved clos
componenttext:
Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. With the 1-year mark of the tw telecom acquisition approaching, it's been an exciting and productive year for Level 3. We've made steady progress around integration and have moved closer toward our vision of one, one portfolio of products, one integrated network and one set of operational support systems. Following our normal approach, soon it will provide an update on our detailed results. I'll provide commentary on what we see in the market, and then we will open up the call for your questions. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Sunit.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to say we delivered a solid quarter of financial performance and continue to make progress from an integration and synergy perspective. I'd like to start with some of the highlights for the quarter,
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to say we delivered a solid quarter of financial performance and continue to make progress from an integration and synergy perspective. I'd like to start with some of the highlights for the quarter, which can be found on Slide 3 of our presentation. Core Network Services revenue for the third quarter 2015 grew 5.5%. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 8.5%. North America CNS enterprise revenue grew 8.3% year-over-year and 2.6% on a sequential basis. 
Excluding integration-related expenses, adjusted EBITDA grew to $675 million and was $657 million, including those expenses. The company generated strong free cash flow of $247 million. At the end of the third quarter, we achieved $170 million of annualized run rate adjusted EBITDA synergies. I'd also like to mention that earlier today, in our earnings release, we announced an accounting change in Latin America. In fact, in September 30, 2015, the company is deconsolidating its Venezuelan subsidiaries from future financial results. I'll give more detail regarding Venezuela in a moment. 
Additionally, based on our year-to-date performance, even with Venezuela excluded from our fourth quarter results and the higher integration expenses this quarter and currency headwinds in Brazil, we now expect full year adjusted EBITDA growth of 15% to 17% compared to our previous outlook of 14% to 17%, and continue to expect free cash flow of $600 million to $650 million. 
Turning to Slide 4. CNS revenue grew 5.5% on a constant currency basis and 2.6% on an as-reported basis. As we have seen in previous quarters this year, the difference in constant currency and as-reported growth rates can be attributed to the strength of the dollar compared to the year-ago period. Outside of the U.S. dollar, which represented 89% of CNS revenue as of the end of the third quarter, the British pound represented 5%, the euro 3% and the Brazilian real, 2%. All of the currencies are included in the remaining 1%. 
On a revenue-weighted average basis, the 3 largest currencies outside of the U.S. dollar declined 17% against the dollar compared to the year-ago quarter and negatively affected our CNS revenue growth rate by approximately 2.8% this quarter. Additionally, in the third quarter, we saw the Brazilian real weakened 13% against the dollar compared to an average rates in the second quarter 2015. 
On a regional basis, North America CNS revenue grew 5.6%. From an enterprise perspective, we had a particularly strong third quarter with revenue growing 8.3% year-over-year and 2.7% on a sequential basis. We saw particular strength in professional services from the Federal segment that tends to be lumpy in nature. Also, CNS revenue declined 1.5% year-over-year, in line with our expectations. 
In EMEA, CNS revenue increased 2.2% on a constant currency basis and declined 4.5% on an as-reported basis. Enterprise CNS revenue, excluding U.K. government, grew 8.3% on a constant currency basis and 2.6% on an as-reported basis. The sequential performance this quarter was driven by increases in CDN, professional services revenue and dispute settlements. Also, the CNS revenue declined 5.7% on a constant currency basis and 14% on an as-reported basis in line with our expectations. 
U.K. government CNS revenue saw a slight increase of 0.4% on a constant currency basis and a decline of 7.1% on an as-reported basis. Despite this quarter's increase, we still expect double-digit percentage declines in U.K. government revenue on a year-over-year basis. 
In Latin America, CNS revenue grew 9.1% on a constant currency basis and declined 9.0% on an as-reported basis. The sequential and year-over-year growth in Latin America this quarter was primarily due to increases in colocation and data center as well as IP and data revenue. Enterprise revenue grew 8.8% on a constant currency basis and declined 10% on an as-reported basis. Wholesale CNS revenue grew 10% on a constant currency basis and declined 4.9% on an as-reported basis. 
I'd like to take a moment to summarize the accounting changes we announced in this morning's earnings release. As we've been discussing for the past several quarters, the macroenvironment in Venezuela continues to worsen, and we believe significant uncertainty exists regarding the exchange mechanisms in Venezuela. These evolving conditions have resulted in a lack of exchangeability between the Venezuelan bolivar and U.S. dollar, and the inability to repatriate earnings from Venezuela back to the U.S. 
As a result, effective September 30, 2015, the company decided to deconsolidate its Venezuelan subsidiary from its consolidated financial statements. Going forward, Level 3's reported financial results will not include revenue adjusted EBITDA and cash flow from Venezuela. Additionally, as we noted in our press release earlier today, this deconsolidation resulted in a onetime charge of $171 million. We remain committed to our operations, employees and customers in Venezuela and will continue to provide communication services there. 
Moving on to Slide 5. Wholesale Voice Services and other revenue or WVS declined 19% to $116 million in the third quarter of 2015. We expect continued double-digit rates of decline in WVS revenue. 
Turning to Slide 6 and revenue results by product group. We have provided growth rates on both, on an as-reported basis and constant currency basis. My remarks reference the growth rates on a constant currency basis. IP and data services, which grew 9%, continue to drive the company's growth led by growth in VPN services and Internet access for enterprises. 
Within IP and data services, CDN declined year-over-year but grew 5.9% on a sequential basis. transport and fiber grew 3.8% and within that group, dark fiber grew 6.4%. Colocation and datacenter services grew 2.1%, and voice services grew 0.6%. Consistent with previous quarters, we continue to see little change in the overall pricing environment. Each quarter, we analyze pricing dynamics and take a market-based approach to pricing our solutions looking at particular geographies, products, verticals and other factors. 
Turning to Slide 7. Network Access Costs was $706 million in the third quarter of 2015 compared to $717 million on a pro forma basis in the third quarter of 2014. Network Access margin expanded to 65.8% compared to 64.8% on a pro forma basis in the third quarter of 2014. For the third quarter 2015, excluding noncash compensation expense and integration-related expenses, network-related expenses were $356 million. This compared to $365 million on a pro forma basis for the third quarter of 2014. 
SG&A, excluding noncash compensation expense and integration-related expenses for the third quarter 2015 was $325 million. This compares to $336 million for the third quarter of 2014. We also saw utility costs increased sequentially this quarter in the mid-single digit millions of dollars, lower than usual given the relatively cooler summer. 
Turning to Slide 8. Adjusted EBITDA, including integration-related expenses, was $657 million for the third quarter 2015. Excluding $18 million of integration-related expenses, adjusted EBITDA was $675 million. This compares to $670 million for the second quarter 2015 or $665 million, including $5 million in integration costs and compares to $620 million for the third quarter 2014 or $612 million, including $8 million in transaction and integration costs that quarter. 
The integration-related expenses this quarter of $18 million split into $8 million are network expenses and $10 million of SG&A. Integration related expenses this quarter were higher compared to the $5 million per quarter in the first half of the year due to an increase in headcount-related integration expenses. We expect that integration-related expenses in the fourth quarter will return to a run rate similar to what we saw in the first half this year. 
Adjusted EBITDA margin, including integration-related expenses improved to 31.9% compared to 30.0% for the third quarter 2014. Excluding integration-related expenses, adjusted EBITDA margin was 32.7% compared to 30.4% for the third quarter of 2014. 
Moving to synergies. At the end of the third quarter, we have achieved $170 million of run rate savings. We are running ahead of schedule in terms of reaching our 18-month target of $140 million by the end of the first quarter 2016. We remain confident in hitting our overall synergy target of $200 million. 
On Slide 9, capital expenditures were $328 million in the third quarter 2015 and are 15% of total revenue year-to-date. We continue to expect CapEx of 15% of total revenue for the full year 2015. 
The company generated strong free cash flow of $247 million in the quarter compared to $139 million from the year-ago quarter. As of September 30, 2015, the company had cash and cash equivalents of approximately $691 million, which benefited from our free cash flow during the quarter and was negatively impacted by $83 million as a result of the deconsolidation of our Venezuelan subsidiaries. 
Turning to Slide 10. We exited the quarter with our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio at 4.0x. This compares to 4.1x at both the end of last quarter and from the year-ago quarter. We remain focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 5x. Additionally, during the quarter, Level 3's corporate credit rating was upgraded by Moody's to BA3 from B2. Both Standard & Poor's and Fitch radar corporate credit at BB-. 
We are confident in our full year financial performance despite the change in economy for our Venezuelan operations and continued currency headwinds. We have updated our outlook and now expect 215 (sic) [ 2015] adjusted EBITDA growth of 15% to 17% compared to our previous outlook of 14% to 17%. We continue to expect to generate $600 million to $650 million of free cash flow for the full year 2015. All other outlook measures remain unchanged. 
In summary, while we still have work ahead of us on integration, we made a fair amount of progress. From a financial perspective, we are seeing steady performance in the business and remain focused on delivering profitable growth. With that, I look forward to providing everyone an update on our full year results in February. I will now turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sunit. As you heard from Sunit's remarks, we saw a good performance in all of our regions this quarter. While our results are rarely linear and frequently lumpy from 1 quarter to the next, we continue to drive profitable growth and are successf
componenttext:
Thank you, Sunit. As you heard from Sunit's remarks, we saw a good performance in all of our regions this quarter. While our results are rarely linear and frequently lumpy from 1 quarter to the next, we continue to drive profitable growth and are successful in converting that growth into strong free cash flow. 
As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, we're a few days away from the 1-year anniversary of the tw telecom acquisition. Overall, I'm pleased with the progress of the integration. 
Before I get into the integration details, though, I'd like to announce that John Blount, our North America regional President, will be retiring at the end of 2015. I'd like to personally thank John for all of his contributions. Early on in the acquisition process, John and I both saw the fundamental role he could take and the importance of his leadership during the integration. Even prior to closing, John spent 6 months or so leading the integration planning from the tw telecom side. Over the last year, John has been a tremendous asset in guiding our North America business and many of our integration efforts. John is committed to a 6-month consulting agreement, so I feel very fortunate that I'll have the benefit of his advice and perspectives well into 2016. 
From an integration perspective. While we have more work to do, we've made significant progress across numerous fronts. During the last year, we've combined 2 large sales organizations, realigned around a common general manager structure, implemented a uniform go-to-market strategy, established a global account management team to serve our largest customers globally, standardized sales compensation and deployed a single CRM platform meanwhile, maintaining voluntary sales attrition well within our expectations and continuing to grow sales production each quarter. 
We defined and deployed a global purpose-built Ethernet platform. It's not a hodgepodge deployment of new and old technologies that form the foundation of many Ethernet networks. This is a fully architected SDN-enabled platform, designed to deliver Ethernet services and a differentiated customer experience to our enterprise and wholesale customers. 
We've merged the spirit IP, MPLS and voice networks across the company, reducing complexity and costs and increasing flexibility going forward. We combined our service insurance internal ticketing systems in North America and are working on a consistent global environment. 
We completed the integration of our global ERP systems into a single platform worldwide and are well on our way to consolidating the former tw telecom billing system into the go-forward Level 3 billing environment. And lastly, we are pleased with the synergy realization that all of these initiatives have made possible. Again, while integration is not complete, we are well on our way and are pleased with the progress we've made. 
With respect to the replacement for John, 80% of our revenues in North America and almost all of our integration activities are focused here. As you might imagine, I already spent a significant amount of time focused on the region. John's leadership team is excellent with broad experience and focused on delivering for our customers. As a result of these 2 factors, I do not intend to appoint an interim lead. Until we replace John, I will continue to spend my time ensuring we are driving our growth and executing our integration plan within the region. 
We do have a number of excellent internal candidates, and we'll look externally as well but will not be in a rush to fill the position. 
I'll move on now to a question many of you asked me from time to time. You ask, why does Level 3 win? There are really 2 parts to the answer. The first is about the market. The need for the services and capabilities Level 3 provides is strong and growing. The second is about Level 3 itself. Our ability to effectively meet those customer needs is also strong and growing. 
You've heard me talk about technology transitions accelerating and how the move to a digital world affects every aspect of our work and lives. As a result, the operating environment for CIOs is becoming more and more complex. The demand for ever-increasing capacity and bandwidth has not slowed. Just a few years ago, explosives bandwidth demand was limited to a few industries, like social media, financial services and health care. Today, you'd be hard-pressed to find an industry that does not require scalable, reliable bandwidth to meet their needs for growth. Until a few years ago, CIOs controlled the applications of an enterprise, the hardware those applications ran on and the devices we use to connect with them. 
Today, the applications may be homegrown or cloud-based. Even homegrown applications are likely to run somewhere in the cloud over virtualized computing resources, and we all bring our own devices to the workplaces. 
Meanwhile, security threats continue to escalate. DDOS attacks had more than doubled over the last 12 months and system intrusions and data exfiltration have become almost a commonplace. Security is a critical focus for our customers and they recognize the need for securing their services in multiple ways within the enterprise, at the interface between the enterprise and the network provider and within the core of the network itself. While the environment is more complex, CIOs are also being asked to improve overall performance of their systems and reduce expenses at the same time. 
So that's the environment, but why do we win? Level 3 is invested in our products and our capabilities to take advantage of these dynamic environment and continually improve our execution and the customer experience we provide. First of all, we are 100% focused on the wireline needs of enterprise customers. We're not distracted by wireless, by consumers or by pay television. We do sell wholesale customers, but even then, we're really targeting the needs of enterprises that those wholesale providers serve. Wireline enterprise network isn't a piece of our business. It isn't an add-on to our business. It is our business. 
Level 3's expertise and experience in deploying and managing large-scale, complex global IP and optical networks is not easy to come by and allows us to provide a differentiated experience for our customers. We're not mired in technologies of the past, rather we continually look at where customers needs are going and now -- how our technology should evolve. 
We have a product portfolio available globally that's designed to create comprehensive solutions for customers. Whether dark fiber, Ethernet transport, public IP, CDN or a host of voice services, we're able to implement a wide range of network solutions to meet an enterprise's global needs. 
We're not standing still leader. We're heavily investing in integrating SDN and the virtualization of network functionality into our product portfolio and our operating environment, preparing Level 3 for the next wave of dramatic network evolution. 
Our operating model and our go-to-market strategy are aimed at providing an excellent customer experience with regional and local management focused on where customers buying decisions are made. 
From a security perspective, we have the situational awareness and the ability to implement security capabilities at the edge and in the core of the network to assist and securing enterprises digital environment. The bottom line is we have an integrated and comprehensive approach to addressing our customers network challenges and the fiber-based network to meet those needs around the world. 
Sunit has already covered our results for the quarter so I won't spend time repeating, but I'll add a couple of comments. Looking at North America, enterprise CNS revenue continues to be the key. This quarter, we grew at 2.6% sequentially or 8.3% year-over-year. In EMEA, I believe we're making progress. We have an excellent team in place, and excluding the U.K. government, we are stabilizing the business. The team has done a good job of extending the life of several of the U.K. government contracts, but as Sunit mentioned, we continue to expect double-digit declines. 
Moving to Latin America. I'd like to comment on the accounting change related to Venezuela. Let me reiterate that we remain committed to the market, particularly to our employees and customers in the country. I'd like to thank our employees in Venezuela for their ongoing commitment to providing excellent service to our customers in a very difficult environment. 
For the region as a whole, the macroenvironment continues to be challenging. As I noted last quarter, the demand for our services remains strong and we still see opportunity to grow the business to meet our customers needs across the region, as we saw from our results in the quarter. 
Before I open it up for questions, I'd like to take a moment to commend the SEC for their action earlier this month to investigate incumbent special access terrorists. Level 3 strongly supports a competitive marketplace, and we believe the elimination of these demand lock-up agreements will create a more competitive industry and fuel investment and innovation. 
Now we'll open it up for your questions. Operator, will you explain the process?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 questions, if I could. First, maybe on the synergy realization. Obviously, a very strong quarter for the exiting run rate, and I think you've now moved past your initial OpEx expectations for the synergy guidance that you set. Maybe talk a littl
componenttext: I guess 2 questions, if I could. First, maybe on the synergy realization. Obviously, a very strong quarter for the exiting run rate, and I think you've now moved past your initial OpEx expectations for the synergy guidance that you set. Maybe talk a little bit about where you're seeing the benefits coming in faster and how we thinking about the timing of how that hits EBITDA. It seems like maybe it's a little bit more fourth-quarter-weighted. And then second question on North America enterprise. Jeff, we appreciate you weighing out the Y Level 3 wins. And I guess, as we start to head into year-end and look into 2016, and growth looks to be shaping up around 8% in North America enterprise, do you think the market, as we head into 2016, could support the same type of growth, or maybe even something faster going forward?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I will answer the synergy question. So I think, I mean, if you look at the mix we had in the earnings presentation, we've been doing quite a bit better on the operating expense side. I think the network expense side has been running at or a little s
componenttext:
Okay. I will answer the synergy question. So I think, I mean, if you look at the mix we had in the earnings presentation, we've been doing quite a bit better on the operating expense side. I think the network expense side has been running at or a little slower than the pace we'd like, but we've been running quite a bit of ahead, and I think a lot of that, as Jeff pointed out, has to do with a lot of the platforms we put in place already, which allows us to cut a lot of work internally and to be -- to drive that. 
In this quarter in particular, as I said, the synergies came more from the headcount-related side expenses so we had some reductions in various areas as we have integrated the platforms. And I think as we look out -- yes, we're certainly running ahead of the $140 million we said. We had hit at the end of the first quarter next year, and I think that we're certainly running quite a bit closer to the ultimate $200 million target that we had set for ourselves. I would say ahead of schedule at this point.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to North America enterprise, first of all, we've never said 8% as guidance. We said that's our goal, and that -- some -- we may see that. We may fall short. We're not giving that as guidance. That is our goal as an organization. We had 8.3% t
componenttext:
With respect to North America enterprise, first of all, we've never said 8% as guidance. We said that's our goal, and that -- some -- we may see that. We may fall short. We're not giving that as guidance. That is our goal as an organization. We had 8.3% this quarter year-over-year. So we certainly think it's achievable for us, but it's a goal rather than guidance. 
Secondly, I believe in everything that I said about the market and where the market is going and what the needs of the markets are. And I believe everything I said about our ability to satisfy those needs. And if you look historically, we've been able to satisfy those needs better than our competitors. So I believe in our position, our competitive position in the market, and our ability to continue to satisfy customers and grow the business. Now it's always up to us to execute, and we have to continue to execute, but I do not see factors in the market that would prevent us from continuing to drive outperformance and from us, continuing to grow in the market. It's up to us to make sure we continue executing them.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Interested in your comments on the special access actions of the FCC. Perhaps you could just help us understand any potential financial benefits or flexibility benefits that might come if indeed they move as they're talking about doing. And then yesterday
componenttext: Interested in your comments on the special access actions of the FCC. Perhaps you could just help us understand any potential financial benefits or flexibility benefits that might come if indeed they move as they're talking about doing. And then yesterday, Comcast talked about moving upmarket into the Fortune 1000 space. Perhaps you can just comment on the competitive environment from the cable companies and how much impact you expect to have from that versus your ability to continue to take share from the bells and others.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. First, with respect to the SEC, and I won't quantify what it means for us, but I'll talk about the environment that it creates. Today, many of the incumbents have what we considered demand lock-up agreements. It prevents customers from going to some
componenttext:
Sure. First, with respect to the SEC, and I won't quantify what it means for us, but I'll talk about the environment that it creates. Today, many of the incumbents have what we considered demand lock-up agreements. It prevents customers from going to somebody else because they lose discounts in all of their services. It takes a little bit of their services with some other their provider. That constraints stray. That constraints the ability of customers to move their traffic to Level 3. So if we eliminate those demand lock-up agreements, and the FCC is investigating them, and they're asking the appropriate questions about them, if they were to decide to eliminate those demand lock-up agreements, then there's a lot of opportunity for us. But today, it's is not really addressable. Even though companies want to move services to us, even though we can provide a better solution for them, they don't have the ability to move because they lose their discounts on their embedded base of services if they do. So we think it's a very positive event. We look forward to the SEC making final rulings, and we'll be very actively participating in their process to provide them with our insight and our input in the process. 
With respect to Comcast, Comcast is a very good company. They're an excellent customer of Level 3. They're a vendor to Level 3. They're a partner of Level 3. So they're a very good company. They've done a very good job at the small end of business customers that we don't take them lightly and don't discount them in any way whatsoever. However, Level 3 already operates in a very competitive environment and its competitive environment globally for capabilities delivered around the world, not just in North America, not just in EMEA, but around the world, our customers need our services and capability. 
We are very good at competing with companies that have been doing this for 100 years, companies that have major shares of the market, and we've been -- we've exceeded their performance if you look at ours versus theirs over the past few years. And so we're very comfortable about our competitive position and about the products and services that we sell to those customers. And so this feels like -- we have competitors come and go in the market, and this feels like more of the same. We'll continue to focus on our execution on our products and services into delivering a customer experience that no one can match over a network that no one can match.

componenttext: Yes. So professional services, including -- including a wide range of things as a critical part of our services where we could be helping customers -- help with technology transitions as a more -- from where they are today and where they want to go, providing engineered solutions. So I think that was in North America professional services predominantly from the track segment. In the EMEA, it was from -- both from professional services, some settlement. The quantification is about $5 million or $10 million, but honestly, it's tough to say. In general, it's a lumpy but growing part of our business as more and more customers trying to figure out whether they -- how do I get into the cloud, how I deal with my changing needs, and Jeff can add to that, but this fits in that range.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a -- just going forward, professional services is part of our strategy, and we talked about it a lot internally. How do we help the customers make the transitions that they need to make to new technologies, new platforms? And so Sunit's right. It'
componenttext: Just as a -- just going forward, professional services is part of our strategy, and we talked about it a lot internally. How do we help the customers make the transitions that they need to make to new technologies, new platforms? And so Sunit's right. It's a lumpy part of the business, but it's something that you'll continue to see us focus on in trying to help customers make the transitions that they need to make.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe one bigger-picture question for Jeff. There's been a lot of activity in the datacenter space over the last year, both in terms of M&A and announced investments people are making. I was wondering if you could update us on your s
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe one bigger-picture question for Jeff. There's been a lot of activity in the datacenter space over the last year, both in terms of M&A and announced investments people are making. I was wondering if you could update us on your strategy for that segment. Are you happy with your portfolio positioning? Are your customers satisfied with the suite of services you're offering, where their needs are to migrate?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that overall, we're happy with the portfolio of services we have. It's a little different, Nick, if you look at each of our regions. Our datacenter strategy is tightly coupled with our regional strategy. If you look in Latin America, datacent
componenttext:
Yes, I think that overall, we're happy with the portfolio of services we have. It's a little different, Nick, if you look at each of our regions. Our datacenter strategy is tightly coupled with our regional strategy. If you look in Latin America, datacenter is an integral part of the way customers buy our other services, our transport services, our -- the various long-haul capabilities and other metro services. It's integral to the way that they want to buy. 
In North America, it's not as integral. Customers want to buy datacenter separately. They don't care if it's connected. It may be separate, they don't care of its connected the transporter long-haul are any of those other services. 
EMEA is a little bit in between the 2. So our strategy varies a little bit based on the market that we're talking about and how we're cooperating. But in general, we're pleased with our data center portfolio. It tends to be a little more telco-based than the high-end data centers with all the newest capabilities. So we tend to be a little bit lower than those really high-end datacenters. But when our customers need those types of services, we're very good at partnering with other companies to make sure that we have datacenter space that's appropriate for our customers. As a good example, there's a datacneter in Omaha that's a world-class datacenter. We were one of the anchor tenants in there. So that we took down space so that when our customers have a need for that, we can easily put them in there, and then we can grow and expand our capabilities to match the needs that we have in the marketplace. 
I want us to be better, frankly, in datacenter revenues. I think we can do better in selling the services and growing the business. But overall, we're pleased with our portfolio and have an answer for getting into the really high-end datacenters that may be building ourselves doesn't make sense.

componenttext: Okay. That's fair.

componenttext: Before I get into my question, just a point of clarification on that last question. I think what people are trying to make sure is that $5 million to $10 million in professional services and termination fees, is that part of the going-forward part of the business, that's the normal course of business, if you will, so we don't necessarily have to be backing that out of our fourth quarter numbers. Or is that something that you would recommend that we should be backing out? And then on my actual questions, obviously, as you guys are starting to generate more and more free cash flow optionality, becoming a bigger part of the discussion, both on the buy side and the sell side, Jeff I was hoping you could provide to us with the company's current policy is around things like buybacks and so forth. And if there isn't one in place or view now, when can we expect you to have a more formalized approach to that? And then my second question is, your EBITDA went up in terms of the low end of year guidance. You maintained your free cash flow guidance. I'm guessing there might have been something there as it relates to Venezuela in terms of why free cash flow didn't also go up. Probably a little bit more clarity on that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So I think, one, with respect to the $5 million to $10 million, it's tough to tell. I mean, until the end of the quarter, you don't know what ends up being the case until you finish the quarter. So I think what we're is seeing some of the partic
componenttext: Yes, yes. So I think, one, with respect to the $5 million to $10 million, it's tough to tell. I mean, until the end of the quarter, you don't know what ends up being the case until you finish the quarter. So I think what we're is seeing some of the particular strength in the third quarter came from the areas that I mentioned. I won't comment specifically on whether you backed that out into fourth quarter, but obviously, you saw particular strength. We were above the sort of goal of 2% sequential growth or 8% year-on-year in enterprise. And then, I think on your questions on free cash flow and EBITDA guidance, I see a lot of things happening. Clearly, you saw the -- most of the EBITDA in Venezuela does translate to the cash flow line because there wasn't that much in capital spending there. And so that was a negative. We obviously had higher cash integration expenses here in the third quarter. So I think as we added up everything together, we still think the free cash flow range we had continues to be the right range, which is why we reaffirm that. And then as it pertains to our cash flow and returning capital, I'll make a few comments, and Jeff can add onto that. But I think in general, we -- Level 3 is a growth company. We focus on growth and we get pretty high operating and investment leverage from the existing networks we have. We get very high returns so we prefer to do that. Beyond that, as you've seen, we participate historically in a table of consolidation and acquisition that continues to be a good use of money to deploy large amounts of capital at pretty attractive returns. If we're not as successful in putting everything of our money to work there, certainly, buybacks make a lot of sense. Or if your share prices do not value our growth prospects properly, returning capital to shareholders through buybacks certainly make a lot of sense, and that would be our preference versus dividends, for example. So at least that's our current thinking. Having said that, as Jeff has mentioned in the past, as we have undergone this cash flow transformation, this is a subject that we would love more to speak about over -- talk about in the next few quarters.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any changes going forward to the sales approach or organization after John retires? And congratulations, John, by the way. And then secondly, where are you seeing most of the growth in CNS? Which industry verticals are you getting the most traction with n
componenttext: Any changes going forward to the sales approach or organization after John retires? And congratulations, John, by the way. And then secondly, where are you seeing most of the growth in CNS? Which industry verticals are you getting the most traction with now -- currently?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to our sales approach, we believe strong, and I will -- John is not here, I will say thank you on John's benefit -- on John's behalf. But the -- with respect to the sales approach, we believe strongly in the GM market. And we have, within the
componenttext: With respect to our sales approach, we believe strong, and I will -- John is not here, I will say thank you on John's benefit -- on John's behalf. But the -- with respect to the sales approach, we believe strongly in the GM market. And we have, within the last month or so, modified our organizational structure to put all the GM's into one single organization under the guy whose historically run our federal business as well, Ed Morse. And so Ed has responsibility for all of the GM's and all of the enterprise growth that comes from that North American sales team. But our approach is still very much the same. It's to go in and understand our customers' need with a direct sales force that talks to our customers and listens to our customers and comes up with solutions not, not just, "we're going to sell this services and that product." We want to come up with solutions that meet their needs. And so that sales approach continues to be the same. We challenge our customers to make sure that they're building their networks properly, and we work with them very closely to assist them in the design and construction of their infrastructure to support their businesses. So nothing really changes about that. We will continue to be focused on a direct sales force through the GM structure. They also serve wholesale customers and we have indirect channels that we use, all of those things will continue. All of those things are working for us and we'll continue with them going forward.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on your question on where the growth's coming from, I'll divide my comments into 2 categories: One, from a product perspective; and then two, from a vertical perspective. From a product perspective, I would say that the biggest thing driving us is ent
componenttext:
And on your question on where the growth's coming from, I'll divide my comments into 2 categories: One, from a product perspective; and then two, from a vertical perspective. From a product perspective, I would say that the biggest thing driving us is enterprise's need for IP and data. And as enterprises move to more hybrid networks, it's both in IP VPN networks, Internet access or enterprises good growth areas for us, security and CDN, our emerging services, but we see good growth from that especially CDN. Sequentially, we think that will continue. As I said earlier, professional services is lumpy, but in general, that's a good category for us as people transition to more cloud-based solutions. 
The story is little bit different by region, as Jeff pointed out, for datacenters in Latin America. From an industry vertical perspective, I think the biggest growth driver continues to be from the technology and media software sector. So some of the big West Coast companies are driving a fair bit of growth, and then also some of the big media companies as they move to virtualize their platforms and have them in the cloud. Some of you, for example, might have noticed things like the NFL game in London over the weekend carried over  the Internet, which is plus. So those sorts of things, generally, we are a beneficiary of. 
More recently, we've seen also good growth from the manufacturing sector, the automotive sector being one of them. Healthcare continues to be a growth sector for us, as the financial sector. We see a lot of opportunity over the next years in areas like energy, where we have a low market share, where energy companies are looking to save a lot of money as they transition their infrastructure, so the emerging sectors where we have a low market share that we see as good growth areas for us.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins from Citi.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give us more insight into the capital spending. A couple of respects: One would be ongoing maintenance versus the growth initiatives.  And maybe you can also give us some insight into how you're spending capital geographically o
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give us more insight into the capital spending. A couple of respects: One would be ongoing maintenance versus the growth initiatives.  And maybe you can also give us some insight into how you're spending capital geographically or in certain product areas or for certain strategies, like to expand location, just so we can get a better appreciation for the types of investments you're making and to think about how that can drive the rest of the model.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll start off, and Jeff might have other things he wants to add. But I think in terms of ongoing maintenance capital, roughly 15% of revenues, it's about $1.2 billion plus of CapEx on an annual basis. And I would say that maintenance CapEx is proba
componenttext: Okay. I'll start off, and Jeff might have other things he wants to add. But I think in terms of ongoing maintenance capital, roughly 15% of revenues, it's about $1.2 billion plus of CapEx on an annual basis. And I would say that maintenance CapEx is probably about $300 million to $350 million in that range, which includes upgrading some of the basic infrastructure, whether it's replacing our factory plants certain back of the factory plants and locations, that sort of thing. Geographically, I think we -- most of our CapEx is success-based. So it's driven by where the businesses is coming from. So you -- as you would expect, the vast majority of our capital goes into North America. But areas like Latin America, which are growing at faster growth rates, we tend to allocate capital at a higher percent of revenue. Areas like EMEA, where we are trying to reposition the business for growth, we're allocating capital at higher percent of revenues than their revenues compared to the overall '15. This year, there's a lot of comical being spent on integration. You heard Jeff talk about all the various platforms that we are consolidating. That effort will continue over the next couple of years in areas like order entry to provisioning to inventory over the next year or 2, some efforts in billing. And then in terms of product areas, we -- as we indicated earlier this year, we made a pretty significant investment to expand the capacity of our CDN network. That was $50 million over the last year, so we invested about $35-plus million to build a branch off of our subsea network in Latin America into Colombia with the lending station. We have spent money in expanding our datacenter capabilities in Latin America. We have spent money in terms of doing network expansions in the U.S. We're still maintaining a base of adding 2,500 to 3,000 new buildings a year. I think this last quarter, we added about 700 buildings, our net buildings to the network, so that continues to be a focus for us. The other area we've spent money is in the security area. And as we look at next year, I think we see continued expansion in our security capability, including CDN. And then for the network expansions in Europe, where -- on Continental Europe as we look to expand our presence there. So these are some of the areas. And Jeff might have other things.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think that Sunit touched on all the areas. I'd just look at the list of things that I talked about earlier with respect to the market needs, and then how Level 3 wins and recognizes, that's how we spend our capital. Sunit mentioned added buildings.
componenttext:
No, I think that Sunit touched on all the areas. I'd just look at the list of things that I talked about earlier with respect to the market needs, and then how Level 3 wins and recognizes, that's how we spend our capital. Sunit mentioned added buildings. We want to get to our customers to provide our net services. Sunit mentioned expanding in markets whether it's in the U.S. expanding fiber footprint in the U.S. or in EMEA or in Latin America. It's about reaching our customers with our fiber infrastructure. I talked earlier about the Ethernet deployment that we had and integrating SDN into our capabilities so that we can make our services more accessible to our customers, easier to use, easier to implement within their infrastructures. 
Sunit talked about CDN and security. Those are the types of things we're investing in are the things that we see as fundamental needs for our customers, and we want to bring those capabilities through an on-net presence to them across the globe. So I think you touched on all of them pretty accurately.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- I kind of like to extend this discussion around how you're investing your capital, and just within the concepts of as we get into maybe this time next year, your liquidity is going to be expanding significantly. You're going to have this you ch
componenttext: I think -- I kind of like to extend this discussion around how you're investing your capital, and just within the concepts of as we get into maybe this time next year, your liquidity is going to be expanding significantly. You're going to have this you challenge of making sure you're allocating it correctly. And so do you feel like in all those growth areas you outlined or you're making investments, that you are making as full an investment in those areas as you think you need to? Because if that's the case, it would suggest that having extra liquidity going into next year opens up a lot of other things you could do. For example, maybe you could be a little bit more thoughtful around inorganic growth, or maybe just go right to buybacks. And so I'd just be interested in hearing around if you're going to put more capital into the business, including potentially trying to make in organic investments around areas where you see potential, how do you think about that over the next couple of years?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I think, in general, 2 points: One, I think the capital intensity that we've talked about this year, we think that, obviously, it's providing the room to make those investments, and accommodating integration CapEx for example, this yea
componenttext: Well, first of all, I think, in general, 2 points: One, I think the capital intensity that we've talked about this year, we think that, obviously, it's providing the room to make those investments, and accommodating integration CapEx for example, this year. So next year, as we have a little less integration expense, so we'll be able to continue to accommodate fairly good amount of investment in all the areas that I outlined. And if by inorganic investments, you mean the M&A, certainly that's something that Jeff can talk more about.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, when we spend 15% of our revenue today in capital, that's the guidance that we've provided for you, somewhere in that range, we better be good at allocating capital and allocating correctly today. That's a lot of money. We need to be g
componenttext:
Well, first of all, when we spend 15% of our revenue today in capital, that's the guidance that we've provided for you, somewhere in that range, we better be good at allocating capital and allocating correctly today. That's a lot of money. We need to be good at it. I always think that we could be better at finding opportunities to invest that capital. I think we invested very well on the opportunities we see. I want us to get better at finding opportunities to invest the capital, both inorganically and organically. But organically first. How do we find more buildings to add? It's not our limitation in building -- adding buildings. This tends not to be our ability to execute. It tends to be our ability to find them and source them and really put them on the list. How do we find those opportunities to really invest? So we'll continue to try and get better at that, Brett. I mean, it's something that we think has to be a core competency, and we'll continue to look at, how do we find opportunities invest? 
With respect M&A, we're always going to be an inquisitive company. We've talked about that for a number of years. We're going to be opportunistic about it. We're also going to be disciplined, though. We don't feel that we have to go buy people for us to grow. So we'll be disciplined, making sure that there are good opportunities for -- if there are good opportunities for us to put plenty of use in use by inorganic means, then we will . We'll also make sure that any money we've spent in the past for example, tw telecom, that the for succeeded in integrating that to a point where anything else might not be a distraction. And so we're going to continue to try and find ways organically and inorganically to put money to work, and then Sunit talked about buybacks and our thoughts on those earlier. So we'll give you more guidance over coming quarters as those things firm up more.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I can just ask a follow-up around a specific example, where you can maybe invest more in the business. You've talked about how the operational performance of EMEA has improved as you've brought in a new management team, but it's still a business that i
componenttext: If I can just ask a follow-up around a specific example, where you can maybe invest more in the business. You've talked about how the operational performance of EMEA has improved as you've brought in a new management team, but it's still a business that is sort of subscale underperforming relative to your other regions. Do you look at that as an area where you can get to the level of growth and performance? You think it's capable of just through ongoing day-to-day, improvement and execution? Our do think ultimately, it's an area you'd like to maybe put a lot more capital to at an attractive return to get to the real potential of what that region can do.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we can put more capital to work there at attractive returns to live up to our full potential. And I like that you chose that word to use because that's the word I use internally. We have not yet lived up to our full potential in EMEA, and I want u
componenttext: I think we can put more capital to work there at attractive returns to live up to our full potential. And I like that you chose that word to use because that's the word I use internally. We have not yet lived up to our full potential in EMEA, and I want us to do that. And so I think their opportunities for us to put capital to work in EMEA. Andrew Crouch and his team are intensely focused on doing exactly that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Funk from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could, please. One of the large incumbents this quarter, I think, for the first time highlighted market share loss as a driver of their enterprise business declines. With that being, like I said, a different commentary from them, I just wanted t
componenttext:
Two, if I could, please. One of the large incumbents this quarter, I think, for the first time highlighted market share loss as a driver of their enterprise business declines. With that being, like I said, a different commentary from them, I just wanted to know your comment on new opportunities that you guys are seeing in the enterprise space, if you are seeing opportunities at larger customers, given the combination? I'd love to hear more thoughts there. 
And then second, while I talk about Comcast, others coming into the fortune 1000 space, historically, you have worked with Comcast in providing network infrastructure they might have had themselves, but you signed an agreement back in '04 for dark fiber. So maybe your thoughts around kind of viewing Comcast as a competitor versus the opportunity to maybe leverage your own assets and help them move, we're already going anyway, and benefit from that move.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. First of all, market share loss of our competitors, I think that speaks for itself. I mean, if you look at outperformance over the past few years, we've been growing revenue in -- with enterprise customers. Overall, we don't think enterprise spend is
componenttext:
Yes. First of all, market share loss of our competitors, I think that speaks for itself. I mean, if you look at outperformance over the past few years, we've been growing revenue in -- with enterprise customers. Overall, we don't think enterprise spend is increasing. So if we're growing revenue, and spend is staying flat, let's say, then by definition, we're growing share. So we're very comfortable with our position there.We're very happy with the opportunity in front of us. With think there's a lot of opportunity for us to continue to help enterprises, make the transition from older traditional technologies to IP optical services and continue to drive growth. We're happy with our capabilities, and the position that we have in the market now are competitive position in the market, and it's -- we've said for a long time that our ability to grow is based in our ability to execute. We think the market going where we wanted to go, where we are good at serving them, and we'll continue to try and drive that. 
When it comes to Comcast. Michael, you just described the wholesale provider dilemma, and it's something that we're very good at. We enable our competitors each and every day. We sell services on a wholesale basis to many of the companies that you guys with this is our biggest competitors and WeList is our biggest competitors. 
So we're very good at that and, recognize that we can win in 2 ways. We can win by helping make Comcast more successful, by helping make somebody else more successful. But we can also win because we have capabilities that others don't have, and we can win directly with enterprise customers by providing those services that, in a way, that others don't or others can't. And so we're pretty pleased with our overall position that we have. And again, Comcast is an excellent company, but so are our other competitors.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we have important differentiators, if you look at the score coupon. I mean, compared to anyone. Not Comcast, in particular, but if you look at the scope of our network and the comprehensive portfolio of product and services, we have lived quite a numb
componenttext: And we have important differentiators, if you look at the score coupon. I mean, compared to anyone. Not Comcast, in particular, but if you look at the scope of our network and the comprehensive portfolio of product and services, we have lived quite a number of differentiating elements that continue to help us. And the add-up has been in the marketplace last years.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Could you talk a little bit about interconnection. I know you've signed some agreements recently, and just if you're starting to see any benefit there? Or you can expect with those new contracts. And then just in terms of M&A, while you're talking ab
componenttext: Yes. Could you talk a little bit about interconnection. I know you've signed some agreements recently, and just if you're starting to see any benefit there? Or you can expect with those new contracts. And then just in terms of M&A, while you're talking about more opportunistically I guess, in Europe, but given what's going on in Latin America and the problems they're having there, do you think that kind of creates more probably inorganic opportunities down the road?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to interconnection, yes, we have reached agreements with many of the large incumbents and cable companies in the U.S. We still have 1 or 2 holdouts in North America that we're working with to reach interconnection agreements with, but we stil
componenttext:
With respect to interconnection, yes, we have reached agreements with many of the large incumbents and cable companies in the U.S. We still have 1 or 2 holdouts in North America that we're working with to reach interconnection agreements with, but we still have issues in other parts of the world as we try to interconnect with PTTs and others out there. 
And so interconnection is not behind us. Do we see benefits? We see disadvantages to consumers and to the marketplace when companies refuse to interconnect. And so customers that want content to download WIN, companies refuse to connect with Level 3, their customers suffer. And so as we go out and we talk to our peers in the industry and those other parties, that's what we focus on. It's not a benefit for Level 3, it's the benefit for their customers because their customers are the ones that are disadvantaged. And we deliver content that their customers want and their customers, request.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have paid for.
componenttext: And have paid for.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have paid for. And the better job that we do of interconnecting with them, recognizing -- we're not trying to ask anybody to build network on our behalf. We invest our own capital, build our own network, but we're trying to help them deliver a better
componenttext:
And have paid for. And the better job that we do of interconnecting with them, recognizing -- we're not trying to ask anybody to build network on our behalf. We invest our own capital, build our own network, but we're trying to help them deliver a better services to their customers. 
And so that's really how we focus on interconnection. We'll continue to focus, and there are a few standouts that we will continue to work on to get better interconnection with them. 
With respect to M&A. In any particular region, we just look at the opportunities that are out there and respond to those opportunities. I've said it before, but you have to have a willing buyer and a willing seller, and so in some markets, there may be more willing sellers than were a willing buyer. In other markets, that may not be opportunity for us to buy something that we find compelling. So we're opportunistic. We stay in touch and engaged in all of the various regions across a range of things, not just fiber providers, but security, managed services, professional services. We pay attention to a range of different things, to see if there's something out there that make sense for us. But we are opportunistic, and we'll continue to be so. 
With that, thank you very much, James for the final question. I'd like to close the call with just a few thoughts. We delivered a solid quarter of growth in our enterprise business. While we have more to do, we've made good integration progress since the closing of the tw telecom acquisition a year ago. We continue to demonstrate our ability and our discipline to ramp free cash flow through our focus on profitable CNS revenue growth, synergy realization, other cost optimization initiatives and reducing interest expense, we remain firmly committed to increasing free cash flow on a per-share basis. 
At the same time, we're investing in the business for future revenue growth and to meet the demanding and evolving needs of enterprise customers. As always, thank you for joining in today's call and for your support of Level 3. Operator, that concludes the call.
